HEADLINE: Declines on Homes And Durable Goods 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24 

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods and sales of new houses fell in March, reports from the Commerce Department showed today, indications that the pace of economic growth was slowing.
 Orders for typically expensive items like automobiles, computers and machinery declined 0.6 percent, to $173.4 billion, after a 2.7 percent increase in February. 
 Purchases of new single-family homes fell 3.1 percent, to an annual pace of 878,000, a separate report said. It was the second decline this year.
The durable goods report for March was unusual in that it excluded computer semiconductors, which typically account for about 4 percent of orders. Totals for all durable goods in the previous two months were adjusted to omit chips.
Demand fell for machinery, computers, motor vehicles and communications equipment. Orders excluding transportation equipment fell 0.1 percent in March, the fourth straight decline, after falling 1 percent in February.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Signs of Strength in Some Regions"A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve Board's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday. Minneapolis -- Residential real estate was strong, and improve-ments were reported in tourism, consumer spending and mining. San Francisco -- There was slow, steady growth in the economy. Commercial real estate continued to weaken, while home sales were fairly strong. Chicago -- Consumer spending was mixed. Home sales and construction slowed. There were reports of more hiring. Cleveland -- The economy improved, but some businesses voiced concern that the rate of growth had slowed from its pace earlier in the year. Boston -- The economy was mixed, with strong growth in residential real estate. Retail sales were unchanged from a year earlier. New York -- Consumer confidence was up, and retail sales were close to forecasts. The office market in Manhattan remained slow. Philadelphia -- The economy improved, with manufacturers reporting increased orders and shipments. Job cuts were slowing. Richmond, Va. -- Manufacturers orders and shipments increased for the third consecutive month. Retailers reported an increase in sales. Atlanta -- Businesses were generally optimistic. Retail sales were higher, and the residential real estate market was strong. St. Louis -- The economy picked up considerably, with manufacturers expanding production and hiring more workers as orders increased. Kansas City, Mo. -- The economy, while still somewhat weak, showed signs of improvement. Retail sales and residential real estate were strong. Dallas -- The economy started to rebound. Manufacturing and retail sales showed signs of a recovery, but businesses' outlook remains cautious. (Source: Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: After Welfare, Working Poor Still Struggle, Report Finds 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 24 

 BODY:
The welfare rolls in seven Midwestern states shrunk by two-thirds over the past eight years, but many of the two million former aid recipients remain in poverty, struggling to pay utility and grocery bills as they juggle part-time, temporary jobs, according to a report released here today.
 Five of the seven states showed an increase in welfare caseloads in 2001, with Indiana's and Wisconsin's rolls growing by about 13 percent, the study shows, suggesting that the deep declines of previous years may have had as much to do with the buoyant economy as with welfare-to-work programs. In all the states, those who left welfare have faced barriers to employment including child care, transportation and educational deficits, the report says. 
 "The bottom line is things have gone very well, but the job is not finished," Jennifer Phillips of the Joyce Foundation said in a news teleconference announcing the results. "The majority of welfare recipients in the Midwest did what the nation asked in 1996: they went to work. The next challenge is to keep former welfare recipients working and moving up so they no longer need government assistance."
Focused on the Midwest, which has led the nation with state programs to move people from public assistance to payrolls, the report pulls together 24 studies, by a variety of academics, consultants and research organizations, most of them financed by the Joyce Foundation, an institution based in Chicago that supports programs to reduce poverty and violence and improve schools.
As Congress begins debate on reauthorizing the landmark 1996 federal welfare law, the report calls for a new safety net to support the working poor, with more investment in education and training.
The report shows that Illinois and Wisconsin reduced their welfare rolls by more than 70 percent each, while Minnesota and Iowa cut theirs by a third, and Indiana by 11 percent. Of those leaving welfare, the portion heading into employment ranged from just under 50 percent in Minnesota to 84 percent in one study in Wisconsin.
Though programs vary throughout the region -- Wisconsin and Michigan have been strictest about pushing people into jobs, while Illinois and Minnesota are among the most flexible -- the study did not find clear patterns of results based on the different approaches. Instead, there were consistent themes: salaries below the federal poverty line of $14,630 for a family of three, and trouble paying routine bills were common.
Researchers found average incomes of $12,000 in Iowa and Ohio and $14,000 in Indiana and Minnesota. In Michigan, 49 percent of those who worked full time, 88 percent of those on welfare and 71 percent of those combining welfare and wages remained in poverty.
Half the former recipients in some states said they were unable to buy food, pay rent or pay utility bills, and a similar number reported their phone service being cut off for more than 24 hours. Several studies found that 1 in 10 former recipients had been evicted or become homeless. 
"They're barely better off," Ellen Aberding, president of the Joyce Foundation, said of those who left welfare for work. "They really need the additional supports that have been put in place in some states to keep them where they are and to bump them up."
But Douglas Besharov, a welfare expert at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research organization, said that the research remained unclear as to why the rolls had shrunk so much, and that redefining the law as a post-welfare poverty program was "moving the goal posts in the middle of the game."

HEADLINE: A Mayor Is His Own Inspiration; 
James Trumpets His Record and Newark's Future

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 24 

 BODY:
Three days from now, Mayor Sharpe James will push a dummy plunger and watch as three hulking structures disappear in a cloud of dust.
 The implosion of the Stella Wright Homes, once the shame of this famously blighted city, will mark the end of a troubled era in high-rise public housing here and pave the way for what is billed as a quite different vision: a sprawling $200 million collection of neo-colonial town houses, gracious parkland, a new high school and a library. 
 For the mayor, Saturday morning's demolition will serve as a fitting symbol of a political career that has seen Newark go from a byword for urban despair to an intriguing place positioned somewhere between the decay of the 70's and 80's and the renaissance Mr. James sees as his legacy.
On his watch, 40 brick behemoths have been dynamited, an ailing downtown has pulsed with new life, and thousands of homes have sprouted on a landscape once scarred by riots and abandonment. 
"When I became mayor in 1986, you couldn't say the word Newark without embarrassment," he said from the faded splendor of City Hall, an architectural showpiece that, like most of Newark, awaits restoration. "Today, people are proud to say they live in Newark. We've gone from urban blight to urban bright."
But 16 years after he unseated an four-term incumbent with the promise of boundless prosperity, the mayor most residents simply know as Sharpe is fending off a challenger who is wielding the same argument he used against Kenneth Gibson, Newark's first black mayor. Like Sharpe James in 1986, Mr. James's opponent, Cory Booker, says the current mayor has served long enough.
After three decades as a political mainstay in New Jersey's largest city, Mr. James is clearly unnerved by his younger, better-financed opponent, a 32-year-old Rhodes scholar who arrived here in 1996, promptly won a seat on the City Council and then cultivated a national reputation as an up-and-coming innovator. A proud, sometimes imperious man, Mr. James calls his rival disrespectful, and views his candidacy as an affront to the mayor's hard-fought victories.
"Cory Booker has done nothing for Newark," Mr. James said with contempt. "He has no record of achievement, no commitment to the people, no love for Newark."
Like Newark itself, the incumbent can be read in many ways, but no one doubts his love for the city. It is a mutual admiration, readily apparent whenever the 66-year-old mayor is on the street, where he is greeted with kisses, handshakes and countless requests for mayoral intervention.
"You've seen us through the good and the bad," said Martha Johnston, 74, as Mr. James worked a center for the elderly in the Central Ward one recent afternoon. "We're not going to let you down, not ever."
But Newark's by-the-bootstraps patriarch and most prominent defender is also an imperfect leader whose triumphs and stumbles mirror this city's harrowing downfall and wobbly rebirth.
"I don't know many people in this country who have sustained themselves through so much political turmoil," said Walter Fields, a campaign consultant and former head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in New Jersey. "He hasn't come through unscathed, but he managed to walk through the flames a survivor."
A fast-moving man with a gravelly voice and gap-toothed grin, Mr. James maintains his smile even when absorbing unpleasant news. In the early years of his administration, he took on the comics and columnists who treated Newark as a punching bag. He once called up Phil Donahue after the talk show host made disparaging remarks about the city. Mr. Donahue apologized on the air.
In the late 1990's, Mr. James kept his composure as a series of federal corruption investigations took aim at City Hall. Mr. James's chief of staff, the police director and two Council members were eventually convicted of wrongdoing, but the mayor was never indicted. He consolidated his power and went on to win a seat in the State Senate in addition to the mayoralty.
Mr. James is supremely confident in his achievements and begins every public appearance with a list of cheery facts and figures: crime down 52 percent; 30,000 new jobs; and a downtown arts center and minor league baseball stadium that many critics said would never be built.
"Newark is not heaven on earth," he said, strolling through his City Hall office, its walls lined with scores of groundbreaking shovels. "We still have our problems, but I think what I've done is an inspiration to every mayor in America."
Mr. James's battle against Mr. Booker is a battle between a political leader molded during the civil rights years of the 60's and one able to reap that era's rewards. Mr. Booker graduated from Stanford, Oxford and Yale Universities, and by his own account, never faced discrimination or economic adversity.
By contrast, Mr. James's mother, Beulah Fluker, raised her two sons alone in a racially divided city, their home a cold-water apartment with a potbellied stove and a backyard outhouse.
"The thing about Sharpe that appeals to so many of us is he struggled to get out of poverty, got himself an education and fought to find acceptance by doing the right thing," said Representative Donald M. Payne, a Newark Democrat who first met Mr. James in the mid-1960's. "He comes from the first generation of black men who were privileged to go to college."
Mr. James, who was born in Jacksonville, Fla., never knew his father, who died of pneumonia before his birth. Ms. Fluker fled an abusive second husband and took her sons north, eventually settling in central Newark. 
After serving in the Army and graduating from Montclair State College, Mr. James became a college physical education instructor and joined an emerging movement among young African-Americans to gain a political foothold in a city dominated by Italian-Americans. As he tells it, even during the 1967 riots, he tried to stop a mob by telling them: "You can't win by force. We'll win with the ballot box." 
Three years later, he was part of a slate that catapulted Mr. Gibson to the mayoralty and Mr. James to a seat on the Council. A civil engineer by training, Mr. Gibson brought stability to Newark, but after four terms in office, many residents were troubled by a sense that Newark's resurgence had hit a wall.
"Gibson had stopped a calamitous downward spiral, but there was no up," said Michael Redmond, 52, then a music critic for The Star-Ledger and the organizer of a community group. "There was a restlessness throughout the city, and here was Sharpe James, vibrant and dynamic."
Where Mr. Gibson was placid, and at times passive, Mr. James was a whirl of optimism. Mr. James, whose slogan was "Sharpe Change," won in a landslide.
"We thought it was a real beginning," said Claude Coleman, a superior court judge who was in the fledgling James administration, first as fire director, then police director. "Sharpe was like a new promise for rebirth and we were proud to be in the vanguard of change."
Mr. James reinstated the mounted police units, streamlined the city's permit process and became a one-man cheerleading squad, talking up the city to anyone who would listen. He knows how to massage a crowd, throwing out snippets of Yiddish, Spanish or Italian, depending on his audience. "Ken would show up at an event, say a few words and leave," Mr. Coleman said. "Sharpe would schmooze everyone, stay for the whole party, and be the last one to leave."
His persuasiveness helped woo corporate tenants to a once-ghostly downtown, among them the telecommunications company IDT, Blue Cross-Blue Shield and Verizon. He trumpeted Newark as the logical home for the state's performing arts center. He coined the phrase Newark Renaissance, and made it stick.
"There would be no arts center in Newark without Sharpe James," said Lawrence Goldman, its executive director. "Once he's convinced of something, he's a real bulldog."
But that same tenacity can also be directed at his enemies, earning Mr. James a reputation as a bulldog who does not tolerate disloyalty or dissent. "Sharpe is fiery, competitive and he plays to win," said Senator Ronald L. Rice, a longtime friend who made the mistake of challenging him for mayor in 1998. "You don't want him as your enemy."
Mr. James has also been criticized for his $248,000 salary, making him the highest-paid elected official in the state, and for turning City Hall into a patronage center for friends and allies. Liz Del Tufo, the retired director of the Newark Boys Choir, who volunteered on his first campaign, said the quality of the mayor's inner circle has harmed Newark.
"He's got some very good people around him and he's got some terribly mediocre people around him," she said. "As a result, City Hall doesn't operate as efficiently as it could." 
With less than three weeks before the election, Mr. James is counting on help from the state's top elected officials, eager for Newark votes, and residents thankful for their municipal jobs.
But to win another term and become the longest-serving mayor in Newark history, Mr. James will have to convince a wider audience that he still has vision and dynamism. He will also have to defend his integrity and accomplishments against an opponent as skilled and politically nimble as he is.
"Lose?" he asked, responding to the question of what life after City Hall might entail. "That's not even an option."
But he seemed especially troubled by the notion that someone younger and less experienced than he could take his place.
"You don't fix something that's not broke," he said. "You don't change horses in the middle of the race."

HEADLINE: Housing Pinch on L.I. Causes New Group to Push for More Rentals 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., April 24 

 BODY:
Ronald J. Caputo works on Long Island, where he was born and grew up, but he says he can no longer afford to live here.
 Mr. Caputo, his wife and four children were told last year that they would have to leave the house they rented in Port Jefferson, which the owner was selling to take advantage of soaring real estate prices. Desperate to stay within their budget, the family scoured the region and eventually moved to a house renting for $1,150 a month -- in Mount Pocono, Pa. 
 His resulting commute is a nightmare. He drives 105 miles through New Jersey, New York City and Nassau County to his office in Suffolk, averaging about three hours, with a return trip to match.
"I couldn't find anything on Long Island under $2,500," said Mr. Caputo, 37, an organizer for a painters' union who says his family income is a bit over $80,000 a year. "I'd never be able to save to buy a home."
The Caputos are not the only refugees of high rent flocking to Pennsylvania. "Everybody we meet in that area, guess where they are from?" he said. "New York. Predominantly Long Islanders, working in Manhattan."
There is a reason. As the nation's first post-World War II suburb, Long Island enshrined the single-family homeowner and generally barred multiple dwellings. Today the Island has one of the nation's smallest supplies of rental housing. The few that exist carry exorbitant price tags, making the Island the nation's fifth most expensive metropolitan area for rentals.
Despite past political prohibitions of multiple-family housing, now there is a major new effort to build more. A new group called the Long Island Campaign for Affordable Rental Housing gathered here today to announce a push for more low- and moderate-income rentals.
"There is no more important human or economic problem confronting Long Island today than affordable housing," said Matthew Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, a leading business group that has joined in the new organization, a coalition of religious, government, civic, labor, environmental and nonprofit groups.
"Families have been dislocated, families are spread all across the U.S. because children who grew up on Long Island cannot afford to live here," Mr. Crosson said. "This cannot continue."
The shortage of rentals is also crimping business because employers have a hard time recruiting workers and paying the salaries to meet housing costs. "We are strangling ourselves," Mr. Crosson said.
To foster new rentals, the coalition proposes tax abatements for developers, using surplus public land for housing, redeveloping downtown areas and a model zoning law enabling higher density and requiring developers to include housing for a range of income levels or, alternatively, to pay fees to a housing trust fund.
Most early Long Island suburbanites came from New York City to escape the density of high-rise buildings and multiple dwellings. Zoning laws here imposed their wishes, and so only 20 percent of Long Island's housing is rental property; in New York City the rate is about 66 percent, and nationwide is 33 percent.
The unintended consequence is that Long Island has few rentals for the elderly, singles, newlyweds and service workers with modest paychecks.
"Many people left New York City to find an idyllic suburban environment," the Suffolk County executive, Robert J. Gaffney, said today. "We became exactly what we wanted to be, but we found that it no longer works."
On a personal note, Mr. Gaffney added: "I speak to you not only as the county executive but as the father of a married daughter who lives in Colorado and who explored the options of affordable rentals in Suffolk County and found that there are virtually none."
Individual stories like that may help turn the tide against town and village zoning restrictions and against school officials' fears that more rentals will produce a surge of new students -- fears that housing proponents say are unfounded.
"I have seen a real change in resistance" to housing proposals, said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group. "Everybody has someone who can't find a home. It's the same people who advocated exclusionary zoning whose children now can't afford to live here."
Home-ownership costs have soared; selling prices average nearly $240,000 in Suffolk and more than $300,000 in Nassau. Rentals offer little relief. Federal statistics show that the fair-market rent for a two-bedroom apartment on Long Island is $1,230. To afford that, according to federal guidelines, a tenant should be earning $23.65 an hour -- nearly five times the minimum wage.
The only areas in the nation where tenants need to earn more than that to pay local rents are Oakland, Calif., $23.90 an hour; Stamford-Norwalk, Conn., $26.62; San Jose, Calif., $30.62, and San Francisco, $33.60.
Over the years Long Island governments and religious and other nonprofit groups have built some subsidized apartments, especially for the elderly. Planners say tens of thousands more are needed, just to meet existing needs.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Pressed Again, This Time on Disclosure and Derivatives

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The simmering debate over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored companies that help finance home loans, is heating up again, this time over the companies' disclosure policies and exemptions from securities rules.
 Banks and some lawmakers have long complained that Fannie and Freddie get hidden government subsidies that give them an unfair edge over other financial companies. Fannie and Freddie, which were created by Congress but are owned by public shareholders, buy mortgages from banks and other lenders and either hold the mortgages themselves or resell them to investors with a guarantee that they will not default. 
 The government does not guarantee the debt issued by Fannie and Freddie. But it does provide the companies with some special privileges, including exemption from state and local taxes, that critics say leads investors to believe that Washington would step in if the companies had financial trouble. As a result, Fannie and Freddie can borrow more cheaply than almost any other company, giving them a crucial edge. 
But the subsidy issue has had little traction in Congress, where Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have convinced lawmakers that they strengthen the housing market and lower mortgage rates for homeowners by funneling money from investors around the world to borrowers in the United States.
With housing among the brightest spots in the economy, Congress is ill disposed to take any step that might make mortgages less affordable. In 2000, a big effort to rein in the companies' privileges went nowhere.
"The decision was made a long time ago to support the housing market and home mortgages in the United States," said Alec Crawford, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities.
Now, in the wake of the Enron collapse, the argument over the companies has taken a new turn. Instead of taking on Fannie and Freddie over subsidies, their critics are arguing that the companies, which are exempt from Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure rules, do not give enough information to regulators or investors.
Together, Fannie and Freddie guarantee nearly $3 trillion in mortgages. Because they are so large, even a small misstep by them could be disastrous, said Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican. Mr. Shays has introduced legislation to require Fannie and Freddie to register their bond issues with the S.E.C.
"Disclosure is essential," he said. "It's just hard to justify why anyone would be against disclosure."
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, expressed a related concern in a speech Monday night to the Institute of International Finance. The banks that sell derivatives to Fannie and Freddie, he said, might take on too much risk because they believe that Fannie and Freddie are implicitly supported by the government.
Because the two companies carry a triple-A credit rating, they usually do not put up collateral for their derivatives positions. Lower-rated institutions, including most big commercial and investment banks, generally do put up collateral.
"The broader risks for financial markets and the economy result from the perception of government support for these corporations," Mr. Greenspan said.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac respond that they already disclose huge amounts of information about their portfolios and derivative exposure, and that the fuss over the implicit government support and the companies' use of derivatives is a red herring. "There's not a real systemic-risk concern here," said Arne Christenson, Fannie's senior vice president for regulatory policy. "We are a fundamentally very strong financial company." 
Wall Street seems unworried about the new controversy. Though shares in both companies fell Tuesday morning, after Mr. Greenspan's comments, by day's end both stock and bond investors had shrugged off the speech. Shares in Fannie closed slightly higher, while Freddie was barely off. Yesterday, Fannie closed at $80.63, down 7 cents, while Freddie finished at $66.03, up 26 cents.
"I don't think he said anything that was new," said Stephen Mahoney, a portfolio manager at the Glenmede Trust Company in Philadelphia who owns more than $400 million in Fannie and Freddie bonds. "Most of the things that he talked about have already been addressed."
Still, by making derivatives and disclosure, rather than the subsidy itself, the center of debate, the critics have for the first time in two years put some real pressure on Fannie and Freddie.
In the last month, both companies have given investors more information about their derivatives positions. And Fannie said in March that it would begin to disclose insider stock sales and purchases by its executives, something it had not done before.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Internet: Latest From Google: For-Pay Search 

BYLINE:  By Saul Hansell (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 Google, a World Wide Web search engine that steadfastly believes that the Internet bubble never burst, has quietly introduced another service. This time, it is Google Answers (answers.google.com), which lets users post questions and name a price they would pay for an answer. 
Answers are provided by a group of independent researchers screened by Google. Three-quarters of the fee goes to the researcher; one-quarter goes to Google, along with a 50-cent nonrefundable fee even if the question is not answered. One user offered $20 to find out how an American company could accept German credit cards. An unanswered question is why Google thinks it can succeed when others who tried much the same business, like InfoRocket and expertcity.com, did not. Saul Hansell (NYT)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Straddling a Fault Line Between Islam and the West

BYLINE:  By RICHARD EDER

 BODY:
WEST OF KABUL, EAST OF NEW YORK
By Tamim Ansary
292 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.
 In the weeks after Sept. 11, when the television screens were filled with the certainties and chiseled uncertainties of the talking heads -- invariably in upper case -- a round-featured and bespectacled head would occasionally pop up. It did not so much talk as question and remember: in lower case. 
 For those moments, Tamim Ansary delivered us from text into context, from crisis into history, from isolation into geography, from a world shattered to one that, having lived through millennia of shatterings, stays mournfully round, and around.
 Born and brought up an Afghan, he could tell of a country that was something other than a cause and a target. A longtime American, he could speak to a country that never thought much about anywhere else, until anywhere else flattened part of Manhattan.
His college basketball coach, observing an oddly inflected movement or two, once demanded: "Where have you been all your life, Afghanistan?" Having thought to suggest the figurative moon or ultima Thule, the coach was taken aback to hear: "Yes."
Mr. Ansary, a California writer and editor, has put this and much else into "West of Kabul, East of New York," a book that steadies our skittering compass. Pointing east and west it signals not galactic opposites but two ends of a needle we can hold in our hand. Mr. Ansari loathes Osama bin Laden and fears what he stands for, something lucidly set out at the end. But it is part of himself that our bombs hit, as well. No windy feeling, this, but as homely as his reaction to a talk-show caller who suggested nuking:
"I saw my grandmother K'Koh, elfin soul of the Ansary family. Oh, she died long ago, but in my mind she died again that day, as I pictured the rainfall of bombs that would be coming." 
"West of Kabul" is Mr. Ansary's effort to ponder and set down what he had improvised in those post-September television interviews: "The dissonance between the world I am living in now and the world I left behind." It speaks with modesty of tone and is all the more resonant for that reason; it searches by sifting. Its unforced findings are at times inconclusive, and glitter at times.
The beginning depicts Tamim's first 16 years, spent in the Afghanistan of the 1950's where his father, member of a distinguished family, was a poet and literature professor and later a government official. He'd met Tamim's Finnish-American mother while studying in Chicago, and taken her back to live in the Ansary family compound in Kabul.
The second part tells of Tamim's move with his mother and sister to the United States in 1964, of his counterculture years at Reed College in Oregon, and of settling down as an editor in San Francisco, and marrying.
In the early 1980's the Iran revolution awoke memories of his Islamic childhood; he took a kind of roots-seeking trip through North Africa and Turkey, talking to fundamentalists and painfully discovering how alien they were, not just to his adult American life but also to the Islam he remembered from prewar Afghanistan.
There is humor and perceptiveness in the pain, as there is in the last section telling of efforts to organize the splintery Afghan community on the West Coast to assist refugees from the Soviet invasion and the civil wars that followed.
A committee was formed; a larger rival committee was formed. To match it, the first group sought recruits, only to find them reluctant because, already seeing themselves as some future government, they complained that the good posts were all filled: president, vice president (premier, that is), treasurer (minister of finance), secretary (foreign minister). Finally, two were brought in by naming them ministers of defense and interior. The account comically and disastrously prefigures today's nation-building. 
Perhaps it is the childhood memories that are most revealing; Mr. Ansary, who can be rather flat writing about the United States, makes the lost ways of the Ansary compound magically familiar. He evokes a virtually medieval Kabul: unpaved roads, little electricity, no running water. No garbage service because -- ecologist's dream -- "we didn't produce any garbage." 
Each compound was a world of its own; an extended family that lived communally once within its walls. "To hear our own thoughts," he writes, Americans require moments of privacy. "My Afghan relatives achieved this same state by being with one another. Being at home with the group gave them the satisfactions we associate with solitude -- ease, comfort and the freedom to let down one's guard." 
He writes of religion unforcedly practiced: prayers by most, kneeling and facing Mecca-ward in the common room, while a few quietly occupied themselves otherwise. "With so many people praying at once, at home, in the courtyards, in public buildings, five times daily, prayer became the respiration of a whole society." 
It was a very different Islam, rigid and punitive, that he encountered later, in his travels. He writes suggestively and with alarmed understanding of the radical fundamentalists he talked to (among them his brother, now estranged). In the Taliban followers he sees a generation of displaced children, their zeal armed and instructed in the Pakistan refugee camps and untempered by the social context of the prewar Afghanistan they never knew.
It is not Islam that is the threat, he writes, but Islam deracinated by poverty, war and social and economic displacement, and finding its strength and justification in a Manichaean view of history.
No doubt Mr. Ansary's family memoir displays an element of nostalgia for a peaceful and something of a privileged time. Nostalgia can be as truthful as memory, though. It is optimism toward the past, and perhaps less deluded than optimism toward the future.
Once out of his teens, the half-American boy couldn't wait to shake the venerable golden dust off his feet and get to the United States. He is firmly planted here, but in one respect he grows a little higher than the rest of us. His book sees things we cannot make out, and need to.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
More Jitters About Profits Knock Dow Closer to 10,000

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for the fifth trading session in the last six yesterday as confidence in a rebound in corporate profits waned. Exxon Mobil led the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest level in more than two months.
 "I can find tons of things to sell, but I can't find anything to buy," said Donna Van Vlack, head trader at Brandywine Asset Management. 
 The Dow slid 58.81 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,030.43, with Exxon Mobil accounting for 12 percent of the drop. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.82 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,093.14. Computer-related shares contributed almost half the decline as Microsoft tumbled to its lowest level in six months. 
The Nasdaq composite index retreated 16.95 points, or 1 percent, to 1,713.34, its lowest since October.
Shares of Wall Street firms declined as the investigation by New York State into brokers' research widened, and the chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said revenue from sales and trading was falling. Morgan Stanley dropped $2.51, to $50.99. 
Merrill Lynch lost $2.49, to $44.65. New Jersey and California will join New York in leading a 50-state investigation into whether the company and other securities firms violated laws by misleading investors with biased stock research.
Citigroup, owner of Salomon Smith Barney, declined 80 cents, to $44.70, and Lehman Brothers fell $2.37, to $60.15.
Exxon Mobil declined as gasoline futures fell after the American Petroleum Institute reported an unexpected rise in inventories last week. Exxon fell $1.05, to $40.30. 
AOL Time Warner rose 19 cents, to $19.30. After markets closed, AOL, the biggest Internet and media company, posted a loss of $54.2 billion, or $12.25 a share, one of the biggest in American history, on costs related to America Online's purchase of Time Warner last year.
AT&T, the biggest long-distance telephone company, had a wider loss and forecast a plunge in consumer long-distance sales will accelerate this year, underscoring concerns that broader profit growth will be slower than expected. It fell 10 cents, to $13.75.
"People are coming to the realization the economy is not likely to be as robust as many would expect," said Jim Luke, a fund manager at BB&T Asset Management in Raleigh, N.C.
Some 1.38 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Advancing and declining stocks were about even on the Big Board.
Microsoft led software shares lower. Bill Gates, the chairman, who has been testifying this week in the company's antitrust case, said it would pull its flagship Windows operating system from the market if a penalty plan offered by nine states was approved.
The shares have fallen 7.3 percent this week; yesterday, Microsoft fell 97 cents, to $53.02.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Reuters) -- Weaker economic data, a well-received two-year note auction and planned buybacks of long-dated securities by the Treasury pushed bond prices higher yesterday and yields to their lowest levels since early March.
The Treasury sold $25 billion of new two-year notes at auction at a price to yield 3.375 percent. By late in the day, the price of the note improved to yield 3.30 percent. The current-issue two-year note also rose to yield 3.22 percent from 3.32.
The benchmark 10-year note rose 14/32, to 98 7/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.11 percent from 5.17 percent. The 30-year bond increased 20/32, to 96 19/32. Its yield declined to 5.61 percent from 5.66 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Hewlett Executives Defend Decision Before Vote

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., April 24 

 BODY:
In a series of combative courtroom exchanges, Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, today defended a decision not to disclose to shareholders internal reports that raised doubts about the benefits of a merger with Compaq Computer.
 At one point, Ms. Fiorina, visibly irritated by the questioning, summed up the essence of the suit brought by a dissident director, Walter B. Hewlett. "Sir," Ms. Fiorina told Mr. Hewlett's lawyer, "you are accusing the chief executive officer of a publicly traded company of lying." 
 In his suit, Mr. Hewlett is seeking to have the results of a shareholder vote in favor of the Compaq merger tossed out, contending that Hewlett-Packard's management withheld information from shareholders that might have prompted them to oppose the deal. As it was, the company apparently won approval for the merger by a slender margin, about 45 million shares out of some 1.6 billion shares voted, according to a preliminary tally by independent inspectors.
The issue that the judge, William B. Chandler III, must decide is whether Hewlett-Packard managers had a "duty to disclose" the reports by teams from both companies that were planning how to make the merger meet the financial goals used to justify the deal.
Those documents, mentioned as the trial began on Tuesday and discussed in greater detail today, portrayed the growing concern of some managers that sales and cost-savings goals for the combined company were too optimistic. Memorandums and e-mail messages assessed the prospects as "ugly" or called a detailed study "a frightening reality check."
In testimony today, Ms. Fiorina and Robert Wayman, the chief financial officer of Hewlett-Packard, described these qualms as the natural reaction of managers confronted with the internal goals required to meet and perhaps exceed the publicly stated goals for the combined company.
Typically, the executives said, managers of business units set conservative goals -- a tactic called sandbagging -- because they know their compensation will be based on exceeding the goals. But it is top management's job to obtain maximum performance.
Referring to the comments in some documents, Mr. Wayman said, "This is a planning exercise in process; it's a constant tension."
The anguished memorandums, Ms. Fiorina said, were not only selective "snapshots" of the process, but they also came from managers looking at individual businesses in the two companies. What they did not see, she added, were the broader savings and efficiencies the larger company could achieve in areas like procurement, finance and information technology.
A work-in-progress, she said, should not be passed on to shareholders. "Because it is not a forecast," she said, "I don't see why we should disclose it."
At no time, Ms. Fiorina and Mr. Wayman testified, did they have any serious doubts about the merged company's ability to reach the two crucial financial goals promised publicly -- annual cost savings of $2.5 billion by 2004, and lost revenues of no more than 4.9 percent after combining sales and eliminating overlapping product lines.
Under questioning from Mr. Hewlett's lawyer, Stephen C. Neal, the executives acknowledged that some financial models sent to shareholders did, for example, translate the 4.9 percent revenue loss into $4.1 billion in fiscal 2003, which begins in November 2002. 
As the economy deteriorated and technology spending stagnated after September, when the merger was announced, some estimates showed the total revenue-loss figure increasing by an additional $3.5 billion in fiscal 2003.
Mr. Neal repeatedly suggested that Hewlett-Packard should have disclosed the information. Ms. Fiorina and Mr. Wayman replied that those higher estimates were based only on the reports of unit managers and were too pessimistic.
Mr. Neal also asked the Hewlett-Packard executives if they could point to any document that said the work of the unit managers -- called the "value capture teams" -- was an incomplete picture of the planning process or reassuring managers that the merger plan was on target. There was no succinct "reply document," they said, though they pointed to the minutes of an executive meeting that said some estimates from the teams seemed too pessimistic.
In the afternoon, Mr. Hewlett took the stand. A Hewlett-Packard lawyer, Steven M. Schatz, tried to portray Mr. Hewlett as someone using a suit as a tactic to reverse a shareholder vote he lost. Under questioning, Mr. Hewlett acknowledged that before the vote on March 29, he already had documents raising concerns that the merger planning was not going as well as Hewlett-Packard's management had suggested. 
But he said he did not communicate what he had found to the rest of the board partly because he had not looked into the documents. 
Besides, he said, "communications between me and the rest of the board had broken down; we were in the middle of a proxy fight."

HEADLINE: The Prince and the President 

 BODY:
President Bush faces no shortage of work today when Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia visits him at his Texas ranch. The Israeli-Palestinian standoff remains acute. There is belligerent talk that unless Washington presses Ariel Sharon to restrain his military and convenes a Mideast peace conference, Saudi Arabia might reduce oil exports and military cooperation with Washington, including American use of a critical Saudi military base. The threats fail to recognize Saudi Arabia's own responsibility for deteriorating relations, and we hope they prove to be overblown. Prince Abdullah appears to be relatively forward-looking, and there is reason to think that he and Mr. Bush can find common ground.
 No previous Saudi ruler has found himself in such a squeeze. Riyadh's principal ally, America, is now at war with Islamic terror, while Saudi Arabia has for years been the principal exporter and bankroller of radical Islam, including some of the most violent strains. At the same time, the crown prince feels that his successful lobbying of fellow Arab leaders to endorse a proposal offering Israel normal relations in exchange for withdrawal from virtually all the territories occupied since 1967 has been insufficiently appreciated by Washington and undermined by Israel's subsequent military actions in the West Bank. 
 There are at least some signs that Crown Prince Abdullah may be wise and skilled enough to pull his country through the current crisis. He has been running the country since King Fahd, his brother, suffered a disabling stroke more than six years ago; during this period he has made a credible start on opening a tightly closed economy and political system. He has begun to make a mark on the international stage as well, notably through his sponsorship of the pathbreaking, though far from complete, Arab League peace plan. 
Within the context of the highly conservative Saudi royal family, Crown Prince Abdullah qualifies as a reformer, albeit a cautious one. He has taken steps to discourage corruption among his royal relatives, modernize the education system, ease some restrictions on women and facilitate foreign investment. These domestic reforms are barely a beginning of what is needed to generate enough jobs for a rapidly growing population and lessen the temptations of violent fundamentalism to an alienated and underemployed younger generation. Saudi Arabia still has no democracy and highly limited respect for human rights. All real power resides with the extended royal family, which now counts some 5,000 princes and princesses. 
The crown prince is a religious man, an Arab nationalist and personally moved by the plight of the Palestinian people. Those views have sometimes made him a difficult partner for Washington, but they also helped give him the credibility he needed to persuade other Arab leaders to endorse his peace proposal. Saudi Arabia is the dominant economic power of the Arab Mideast and home to Islam's two holiest places, Mecca and Medina. Its potential diplomatic influence is enormous. It is also the world's No. 1 oil exporter and the leading purchaser of American military equipment, factors that will continue to link its fortunes to Washington despite current tensions. 
The Saudi peace plan will be a major topic of today's discussions, along with American proposals for removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. A useful next step would be for the Saudi leader to help extricate the Palestinian Authority from its fatal embrace of terrorism. It would be a mistake for him to threaten Mr. Bush with talk of an oil embargo. Popular anger is not a wise basis for policy-making, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is far from a one-sided problem. This is a moment for the crown prince to work with Mr. Bush to ease the crisis in the Middle East.

HEADLINE: U.S. Begins Issuing Data on Individual Nursing Homes' Quality of Care 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24 

 BODY:
The Bush administration released data today on the quality of care at more than 2,500 nursing homes in six states, and promised to publish similar information on those in all other states this fall, part of an ambitious project to help consumers evaluate the performance of health care providers.
 AARP, two trade associations for the nursing home industry and the Service Employees International Union, which represents 125,000 people who work in nursing homes, endorsed the project. 
 They said the new data would help people select nursing homes and would motivate homes to correct deficiencies that have persisted for decades.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, who has enthusiastically encouraged the initiative, said, "This is a huge step forward, probably the biggest step to improve the quality of nursing homes that this department has ever been involved in." 
Asked if the government intended to release similar data on the care provided by doctors and hospitals, Mr. Thompson said, "Sure, we will go as far as we possibly can."
The six states for which the government released data today are Colorado, Florida, Maryland, Ohio, Rhode Island and Washington.
The new data will be available on the Web at www.medicare.gov and through a toll-free telephone number, 800-Medicare (800-633-4227).
For most nursing homes, the government will report six types of information: the proportion of residents who have bedsores, who are in physical restraints, who have lost too much weight, who are suffering pain, who have certain types of infections and who need more help with daily activities.
Using the data, a family can see that, for example, 12 percent of the residents at Miami Shores Nursing and Rehabilitation Center have bedsores, compared with 37 percent at the Regents Park home in Boca Raton, Fla., 9 percent at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington, in Rockville, Md., and 4 percent at the Josephine Sunset Home in Stanwood, Wash. The average for the six states is 8 percent.
Tess Canja, the president of AARP, noted that the government was not disclosing data on the ratio of employees to patients or the number of consumer complaints about each home. But federal officials said they would eventually disclose those figures.
Some nursing home owners and health care experts said the data could be confusing, and Secretary Thompson acknowledged that the project "is going to be very controversial."
Dr. Andrew M. Kramer, a professor of medicine at the University of Colorado who advised the Bush administration on the effort, said, "Public reporting of quality-of-care information is a good idea," but he cautioned: "The current information is not adequately adjusted for differences in the health of individuals admitted to nursing homes. Therefore, the data could be misleading. They could make good homes look bad, and vice versa."
Janet C. Wells, director of public policy for the National Citizens' Coalition for Nursing Home Reform, a consumer group, said the data would be helpful. But, she said, people choosing a home should also ask for state inspection reports and should visit homes to observe the quality of care.
Federal officials and economists have been saying for years that health care markets would operate like other markets if consumers had more information. The new initiative will test that hypothesis.
"The data will help us identify opportunities for improvement, areas where we can do better," said Mary K. Ousley, chairwoman of the American Health Care Association, one of the trade groups that endorsed the initiative. 
William L. Minnix Jr., president of the American Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, which represents nonprofit homes, said, "If substandard nursing homes don't improve, public pressure will drive them out of business."
The statistics are based entirely on data that nursing homes report to the government as a condition of participating in Medicare and Medicaid. Homes that knowingly submit false information can be prosecuted for fraud.
The government said it had adjusted the data to reflect the fact that some nursing homes had patients who were sicker or more frail than residents of other homes, though Dr. Kramer and some other experts said the adjustment had not been sufficient. The statistical methods used to make such adjustments are complicated and imperfect.
Irene Fleshner, senior vice president of Genesis Health Ventures, a national nursing home chain, said the government's numbers did not "adequately portray the quality of care."
But Dr. Jeffrey L. Kang, chief clinical officer at the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said researchers had found that the data provided "a fair reflection of nursing home quality."
Because the government uses the same data for reimbursement, nursing homes have conflicting incentives: they receive higher payments if patients look sicker, but the quality of care appears better if patients look healthier.
Dr. David L. Jackson, medical director of HCR Manor Care, which operates about 300 nursing homes, said, "None of the quality measures are perfect, but they are good enough to make this initiative worthwhile."

GRAPHIC: Photos: One example, from Medicare's Web site (www.medicare.gov), of the government's newly issued statistics on nursing homes in six states.; Secretary Tommy G. Thompson, left, and Thomas A. Scully, the Medicare and Medicaid administrator, announcing nursing home data. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Battle for Control of Senate Makes a Stop in Sioux Falls 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 24 

 BODY:
President Bush plunged into the epicenter of the battle for control of the Senate today at a windswept plant here that turns Midwestern corn into ethanol. Senator Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader and the president's political nemesis, sat in the front row as the president spoke.
 But both men remained publicly on their best nonpartisan behavior in Mr. Daschle's home state, even though their parties have enthusiastically run television commercials attacking each other. Mr. Bush warmly shook Mr. Daschle's hand after a speech promoting the administration's farm policies at the gritty Dakota Ethanol plant near here, then patted him on the shoulder as Mr. Daschle grinned. 
 "He said he'd kiss me, but people would talk," Mr. Daschle said after his encounter with the president, and after an even cozier chat with Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff. 
But Mr. Daschle also said he had been invited to the event only after his office called the White House last week to complain that he had been excluded.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Daschle made their brief visits to the South Dakota plains today to engage in their most direct confrontation so far over the state's Senate seat, which could decide whether the Senate remains in the narrow control of the Democrats or reverts to Republican control. The White House has focused on South Dakota as one of its most important races this year. 
Both men are therefore campaigning for their political futures in a state that has been a little stunned to find itself the focus of such national attention. Mr. Bush is supporting the Republican candidate, Representative John Thune, who is the sparsely populated state's only member of the House of Representatives and whom Mr. Bush personally prodded to run. Mr. Daschle is backing his protege, the incumbent Democrat, Senator Tim Johnson.
"I'm here because I firmly believe that John Thune should be the next United States senator from South Dakota," Mr. Bush told a roaring crowd of more than 5,000 people this evening at the Sioux Falls Convention Center. "He's not afraid to stand up for what he believes, and it's refreshing to hear his voice among the shrill partisans of Washington, D.C."
Earlier, Mr. Bush spoke at a smaller fund-raiser that was to raise $350,000 for Mr. Thune's Senate campaign. "I'm going to spare you from a lot of my speech that I'm going to give a little later on," Mr. Bush said. He added, "We've got a lot on our plate and I hope to have this good man beside me in the United States Senate, just as he has been beside me as a fine member of the United States House of Representatives."
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, billed it as the largest fund-raiser in South Dakota history.
The day, like so many others on the president's schedule this year, followed a familiar pattern, layering a touch of Bush administration domestic policy onto aggressive politicking and the raising of hundreds of thousands of dollars for Republican candidates and the party.
Mr. Bush began in the grain building at the Dakota Ethanol plant, where a powerful wind swept grit through the doors, onto laptop computers and roast beef sandwiches. In a speech before farm leaders, Mr. Bush repeated his support for increased use of ethanol in the nation's fuel supply, a hugely popular position in a state where cornfields stretch for miles across the plains.
"When I was running for president, I supported ethanol, and I meant it," Mr. Bush said to applause. "I support it now, because not only do I know it's important for the ag sector of our economy, it's an important part of making sure we become less reliant on foreign sources of energy."
Mr. Bush praised Mr. Daschle for his work on promoting ethanol in energy legislation now before Congress, and then praised Mr. Thune, who was sitting on the opposite side of the grain building from Mr. Daschle, for his work on a rebate program to increase the demand and supply of ethanol. 
"It's good public policy for America," Mr. Bush said. "It's good for our air, it's good for our economy, and it's good for our national security."
Mr. Bush did not single out Mr. Thune's opponent, Mr. Johnson, for any praise. Afterward, Mr. Johnson said he did not think the president's visit would matter to the race.
"I think the election comes down to the candidates," he said. "I don't think it comes down to the White House, the cabinet or the senators who might come out here to campaign."
A provision in the energy legislation, which is nearing passage by the Senate, would triple the amount of ethanol in the nation's gasoline supply by 2012. The provision is supported by Mr. Bush and Mr. Daschle, although not by senators from New York and California, who say that it would increase gas prices.
Mr. Bush left Sioux Falls this evening for his ranch in Texas, where he is to meet on Thursday with Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Tim Johnson, left, who is seeking re-election, and Senator Tom Daschle at an event yesterday in South Dakota, where President Bush campaigned for Mr. Johnson's opponent, Representative John Thune. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: THE PRIME MINISTER; 
SHARON SUGGESTS ARAFAT COULD GO TO THE GAZA STRIP

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 24 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that he would consider letting Yasir Arafat slip out of the Israeli siege in Ramallah and move to the Gaza Strip to demonstrate whether he was willing to put his security forces there to work stopping Palestinian violence.
 Speaking in an interview, Mr. Sharon left no doubt that he expected Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to fail any such test, saying that "with Arafat, no one will be able to make peace." 
 Mr. Sharon said he had promised President Bush in their first White House meeting that he would not harm Mr. Arafat. Senior Israeli officials said that although Mr. Sharon would like to banish Mr. Arafat, he had no plans to do so.
His remarks were the first suggestion that Mr. Sharon was probing for a way out of the impasse in Ramallah, albeit one Mr. Arafat would find hard to accept. Israeli troops have imprisoned Mr. Arafat in his compound there since early December, and they have occupied the compound itself since late March, trapping Mr. Arafat in two buildings.
But Mr. Sharon has himself been boxed in by the siege of his old rival, unwilling to release him but unable to press him harder. Other governments, including the Bush administration, have not cooperated with his call to isolate Mr. Arafat, and Mr. Arafat's popularity among Palestinians has only grown during the siege, top Israeli officials acknowledged. 
Mr. Sharon accuses Mr. Arafat of harboring wanted men in his compound, but Israeli soldiers have not forced their way inside to seize them. Mr. Sharon said his pledge to President Bush not to harm Mr. Arafat had so far blocked that step, creating the present stalemate. "If that had not been my commitment," he said, "we would have taken them already a long time ago." He said that all Israeli forces would have also withdrawn from Ramallah.
Senior Israeli officials said Mr. Sharon was not yet certain how he would react if another Palestinian suicide attacker struck Israelis. So far, his cabinet has resisted his proposal to exile Mr. Arafat. 
If Mr. Arafat agreed to move to Gaza, Mr. Sharon said, he could not take any of the wanted men with him. "We are ready to consider that," he said of the proposal.
Relief from the Ramallah siege might also be in the interest of the Bush administration, which is seeking Arab backing for a possible strike on Iraq. Moving Mr. Arafat might buy time for such an operation, an Israeli official noted tonight. 
Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator, ridiculed Mr. Sharon's proposal. "He's announcing to you officially tonight that he wants to renew his occupation of the West Bank, and he wants to exile Arafat to Gaza," Mr. Erekat said. "I think this is the first time that Sharon reveals the extent of his plans."
Over the weekend, Mr. Sharon halted Israel's largest ground offensive since he led its invasion of Lebanon 20 years ago as defense minister. That time, Mr. Sharon was seeking to drive Palestinian militants back from Israel's northern border and ultimately to drive Mr. Arafat out of Lebanon, a goal he achieved after besieging Mr. Arafat in Beirut.
Mr. Sharon and other Israeli officials denied that his own bitter history with Mr. Arafat had anything to do with the Ramallah standoff. "Believe me," he said, "there is nothing personal here."
Mr. Sharon called himself one of very few Israeli leaders strong enough to persuade his nation to make the "painful compromises" necessary for peace. "I can do it -- I can do it," he said. "I wanted to do it."
"I am willing to make many concessions," he said. "And I think that the Palestinians are losing an opportunity, because with me, we could have finalized an agreement. But what can I do?"
In the interview today, conducted for 90 minutes in his modest office here, Mr. Sharon, 74, appeared weary but relaxed, referring only once or twice to notes provided by his aides and occasionally joking with his guests. 
But he spoke sharply as he described international sympathy for Mr. Arafat. "Leaders from all around the world are coming to him, embracing him, talking to him, phoning to me day and night, showing interest -- if he's got enough candles," Mr. Sharon said, recalling the sorts of concerns he had heard expressed. "What about the cell-phone batteries that are dying?"
"They never ask me about the 93-year-old lady, a survivor of the Holocaust, who was killed at the Seder on Passover eve," he said, referring to the suicide bombing in Netanya last month that killed 28 Israelis.
Even during the Israeli operation, Mr. Sharon's son, Omri, met last Saturday with a top Palestinian official, Muhammad Rashid. The Israeli Army had not pushed into the Gaza Strip as it had into the West Bank, and Omri Sharon was seeking assurances that Palestinian security would crack down on violence there. Prime Minister Sharon said he received such assurances.
But "the terror became more intense," Mr. Sharon said. "They haven't taken any steps." The Israeli government has not ruled out a large-scale raid of the Gaza Strip.
Palestinian officials have said that the Israeli offensive crippled Mr. Arafat's security forces in the West Bank. That claim could not be made in Gaza, Mr. Sharon said. In fact, he said, he specifically instructed his troops "not to react in Gaza" once he heard the Palestinian claims about the West Bank. 
But Mr. Erekat said Israeli bomb and rocket attacks during the 19-month conflict "have literally left not a building of the security forces standing up in Gaza."
Israeli soldiers have arrested hundreds of Palestinians accused of terrorism. Soldiers also killed an unknown number of civilians along with many fighters. Israeli soldiers detained at least 3,000 Palestinian men, later deemed innocent and released, and they put whole cities under curfew, demolishing or damaging hundreds of homes, particularly in the refugee camp city of Jenin. 
Mr. Sharon said Mr. Arafat was solely responsible for Palestinian suffering, and he said Palestinians shared this view. "They know exactly that, the suffering of the Palestinian people, he causes it," he said.
Mr. Sharon has proposed a regional summit meeting, including Israel and Arab states under the sponsorship of the United States, to discuss economic development and peace. In the interview, he said for the first time that such meetings should be held every several months to create "infrastructure for relations between the countries."
Mr. Sharon also praised a recent initiative by Saudi Arabia, adopted last month at the summit meeting of Arab nations in Beirut, to normalize relations with Israel in exchange for an Israeli withdrawal to its borders before the 1967 war and to resolve the plight of refugees from the 1948 war.
"The fact that an Arab country, an important Arab country, comes out with a vision of peace, it's very, very important," Mr. Sharon said. But, he said of the 1967 boundaries, "Israel would not be able to survive with these borders."

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Just When the Big Idea Seemed Academic . . .

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
CALL it a failure of will, a lack of imagination or a bow to political and economic reality, but what passes for master planning in recent decades has often been more like tinkering than rethinking.
 That is why the prospect faced by the City University of New York -- to plan a whole new campus on Governors Island -- warrants attention. And that is why it will be worth watching in the next few days to see whom Dr. Matthew Goldstein, the chancellor of the university, appoints to the steering committee charged with preparing the plan. 
 Will it be possible for committee members to recover the lost art of thinking big and devise an academic mission commensurate with the extraordinary setting in New York Harbor? Or will they be so constrained, by outlook or exigency, that Governors Island simply becomes an adjunct to the existing system, useful as that may be?
"This is a very big idea," Dr. Goldstein said this month as he toured the island with Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. "It's probably the largest idea I have seen in the history of City University, certainly recent history."
How that idea is translated into physical reality will be the work of a committee with perhaps 15 to 20 members, representing the state and the city, the board of trustees, the faculty and the student body. Management consultants are to help with the complex regulatory, transportation, financial and political issues.
Mayor Bloomberg's voice on the committee will be Joshua Sirefman, chief operating officer of the Economic Development Corporation. Other members are likely to be announced next week.
The chancellor already has some ideas of his own.
He envisions a graduate-level science park of such intellectual prominence that it would draw biotechnology and computational science companies to Lower Manhattan. This could be undertaken in partnership with private institutions, he said, like Columbia University, New York University or Rockefeller University.
Dr. Goldstein also imagines subsidized housing on the island for teachers as an incentive to lure them from around the country to New York City. "The school system has an insatiable appetite for teachers," he said.
"My mind is swimming in possibilities," Dr. Goldstein said. Understandably. Although he does not expect CUNY to use all 172 acres of Governors Island, even if the university winds up on just half the acreage, it would have a new campus as large as three City Colleges.
Or, for comparison's sake, 20 Barnards.
Barnard College has just hired Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates to prepare what it describes as its first master plan in 98 years. But the phrase "master plan" may be a bit too grand; the planners and architects will not have much room to maneuver in that densely packed four-acre campus along Broadway, between 116th and 120th Streets.
"We really can't afford to make mistakes," said the Barnard president, Dr. Judith Shapiro.
As it stands, Barnard is a three-dimensional lesson book in planning history, mistakes and all.
At the north and south ends, it reflects the Beaux-Arts approach taken at the turn of the 20th century, when the architect Charles Rich prepared a master plan in which the campus was to face the Hudson River and turn its back on Broadway and Columbia University.
Rich's plans were effectively abandoned in 1916, when the financier Jacob Schiff offered to donate $500,000 to build Barnard Hall but insisted on choosing his own architect, Andrew S. Dolkart wrote in "Morningside Heights: A History of Its Architecture and Development" (Columbia University Press, 1998).
FROM then on, it was catch-as-catch-can. Lehman Hall of 1959 observed the scale but not the architectural flavor of its predecessors. A concrete tower and pavilion from 1969, Altschul Hall, and the McIntosh Student Center repudiated the past entirely. A 1988 dormitory, Sulzberger Hall, towered over its neighbors but also deferred to the original red-brick, quadrangle spirit.
Much as they might like to, the architects at Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer cannot think about tearing down the massive and uncompromisingly modern Altschul Hall, which pretty much sundered the old campus. (It may be forbidding, but it is an efficient science building.) Nor will they be looking at dormitories. (Those are already the subject of another plan.) And they would uproot old trees at their peril. (Verdant space is precious.)
"Our purpose is not to wipe out the past in favor of a brilliant future," said the architect Hugh Hardy. "This is not an excuse to transform Barnard into something new."
Their mission, instead, is to find ways to squeeze an extra 77,000 square feet of administrative and academic space onto the campus, perhaps by replacing the McIntosh building and Lehman Hall, while improving the landscaping along the main north-south axis and strengthening the communal character of the public space.
This is a far cry from the rare opportunity that CUNY has to create a real master plan in the kind of bold strokes that Barnard cannot afford. Nonetheless, Dr. Shapiro insisted that she did not envy CUNY, and that more minutely calibrated planning better suited her institution.
"The very compactness of the Barnard campus means we can achieve a kind of community and sense of cohesion," she said. "We're not starting from an empty field. We're starting from a campus that has some beautiful things already and some unfortunate things that we want to make better."

Diagram shows the Barnard campus as envisioned and as developed.

HEADLINE: 2nd Safety Agency Nominee Is Facing Less Opposition 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24 

 BODY:
President Bush's second nominee to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission comes to Congress on Thursday for his confirmation proceedings, facing none of the opposition so far that derailed the White House's first choice.
 Last summer, the Senate rejected Mary Sheila Gall, the agency commissioner, for being too weak on safety issues. President Bush then nominated Harold D. Stratton, a former attorney general from New Mexico and longtime critic of regulation. 
 Although he philosophically shares many of the skeptical regulatory views of Ms. Gall, he has not faced the same kind of opposition from Senate Democrats and consumer groups. The difference, they say, is that Mr. Stratton has a more sparse record on product safety issues than Ms. Gall, a commissioner of the agency for the last decade who infuriated consumer groups by repeatedly voting against recalls and safety standards and frequently attributed children's injuries to negligent parents rather than products that safety experts said were faulty. 
Moreover, Congressional officials said, Senate Democrats are reluctant to challenge a second candidate after rejecting the first. Finally, if Mr. Stratton is not confirmed, the agency will be paralyzed next month because it will lack a quorum.
Administration officials said that Mr. Stratton's background made him well qualified for the job.
"As a former state attorney general who ran an efficient and highly productive office, he has both the consumer protection experience and administrative experience to head the C.P.S.C.," said Anne Womack, a White House spokeswoman. "He has a substantive consumer protection record." 
As attorney general, Mr. Stratton brought a variety of consumer fraud cases, including one against a Ford dealership for high-pressure sales tactics and others involving telemarketers and art fraud. His strong opposition to regulation has won him praise from some business interests and raised concerns among some consumer groups.
An administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said Mr. Stratton and Ms. Gall were similar in that they both were qualified to lead the agency and that they both believed in personal responsibility and opposed what they considered overly burdensome regulation.
But typical of the difference between the Stratton and Gall nominations is the view of Consumers Union, which campaigned against Ms. Gall but so far has remained neutral on Mr. Stratton's nomination.
"We're extremely concerned that he seems ideologically committed to reducing or eliminating the role of government and we fear he will fail to use his role as head of the Consumer Product Safety Commission to monitor the market where it has failed to get rid of faulty products," said Sally Greenberg, senior product safety counsel in the group's Washington office. "But we have not opposed the nomination because, unlike Mary Sheila Gall, he has no track record. It's very hard when somebody has no track record."
Mr. Stratton, following the tradition of other nominees with pending confirmations, declined to comment. He has told lawmakers and others that while he is philosophically skeptical of government regulation, he has different views when it comes to product safety.
"I have a 6-year-old and a 2-year-old daughter," he said when the White House announced he would be nominated last fall, "and this is an opportunity to do something for them. We all believe in the safety of our consumer products when it comes to kids."
Mr. Stratton, who was co-chairman of a group of New Mexico lawyers supporting George W. Bush in the 2000 election, has repeatedly criticized government and advocated greater individual responsibility. When he was the attorney general of New Mexico, he alienated many Democratic and Republican state prosecutors by regularly attacking the National Association of Attorneys General.
During the Reagan administration, a band of Democratic and Republican state law officials tried to counterbalance what they perceived as a void in regulatory oversight by bringing antitrust and consumer cases. Mr. Stratton was one of two state attorneys general who were critical of those efforts. He took on a bipartisan group of 44 state attorneys general who had signed a compact setting standards for examining corporate mergers. 
"They are using the cover of 'consumer protection' to impose their own antibusiness, pro-government regulation views on the entire nation and are bypassing the legislative process to put in place 'enforcement guidelines' that Congress itself refuses to pass," Mr. Stratton wrote in an op-ed article in 1988 in The Wall Street Journal. "We have enough government interference in our economy without a new group joining the antibusiness parade."
He was also sharply critical of his colleagues in other states for waging an effort to impose airline advertising standards and eliminate what the other states saw as deceptive advertising.
More recently, he founded an organization, the Rio Grande Foundation, which according to its Web site is a research and educational organization that "promotes public policy founded upon the principles of limited government, economic freedom and individual responsibility." He has also served on the board of Defenders of Property Rights, a group that describes itself as opposed to "a broad range of regulations" and committed to "private property rights" and "free market principles." 
The Consumer Product Safety Commission, one of the smaller federal agencies, is responsible for watching over about 15,000 products. Created in the 1970's, the commission was nearly eliminated in the Reagan administration, and after its budget was drastically cut and it was filled with relatively ineffective officials, frustrated consumer groups contemplated recommending that it be eliminated. 
Under Ann W. Brown, who was appointed by President Bill Clinton to head the agency in 1994 and stepped down last year, its profile rose considerably. Ms. Brown, a former official at the Consumer Federation of America, sparred repeatedly with manufacturers, opening investigations into products and proposing rules that prodded industries to formulate their own guidelines.
Experts say the agency is in the midst of several significant inquiries and proposed rule making that would be affected by Mr. Stratton's confirmation. The agency is now considering whether to impose tougher standards for flammability for upholstered furniture, arsenic in wood playground structures and leaded-wick candles.
