HEADLINE: As Questions Persist, Tyco Halts Breakup 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Tyco International, one of the world's largest conglomerates, abruptly reversed business strategies yesterday for the second time this year amid persistent questions about its accounting practices and its management credibility.
 Just three months after saying it would split into four pieces and sell a fifth division, Tyco said that the plan was a mistake and that it would break off only one unit. At the same time, the company said that it would lay off 7,100 workers to cut costs and that its profits this year would be much lower than expected. 
 The announcement drove Tyco's stock to its lowest level in four years and left some stock analysts questioning whether Tyco, which is burdened with $23 billion in debt, can survive. Once one of the stock market's 20 biggest companies, Tyco has lost 65 percent of its value this year, costing shareholders $76 billion, almost as much as was lost in the collapse of Enron. 
Tyco's sudden fall from favor is another sign of investors' skepticism about companies that have accounting practices that are confusing and executives who appear less than forthcoming. For most of a decade, Tyco prospered, and was strongly supported by Wall Street analysts, despite nagging questions about its financial reporting.
But after Enron's collapse, many big companies, including AOL Time Warner and General Electric, have fallen under a cloud because of their opaque financial reports, and the cloud over Tyco shows no signs of lifting. 
Though most stock analysts continue to support Tyco, its stock is tumbling. Its board is facing tough questions from investors unhappy about the company's poor performance and the rich pay packages of its top executives.
"What is this company going to say in four months?" asked Richard H. Koppes, a corporate governance expert and the former general counsel of the California Public Employees Retirement System. "The board doesn't seem to have a clue about the people they are supposed to be representing."
Under L. Dennis Kozlowski, its charismatic chairman and chief executive, Tyco has been an aggressive buyer of other companies since the early 1990's. Based in Bermuda with headquarters in Exeter, N.H., Tyco has 240,000 employees and makes everything from security systems to telecommunications equipment. Its best-known brands include ADT, a security company, and AMP, a big electronics manufacturer.
Because it is incorporated in Bermuda, the company avoids paying American taxes on its profits generated overseas, and also shelters some United States income from taxes. It says that being a Bermuda corporation saved it more than $400 million last year alone. This year, Tyco says its overall worldwide tax rate will be about 18 percent, about half the corporate tax rate in the United States.
Mr. Kozlowski has spoken repeatedly of his ambition to build a conglomerate that rivals Berkshire Hathaway or General Electric.
But when Tyco's stock dipped in January after a series of negative news articles, Mr. Kozlowski suddenly announced that Tyco would break into four companies. Mr. Kozlowski, and Tyco's investment bankers, expected investors to embrace the change in strategy, even though it appeared to be mainly a response to its declining stock price, not a change in business fundamentals.
Instead, the breakup announcement fed questions about whether Tyco's earnings were as good as they had appeared. The disclosure that Mr. Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, Tyco's chief financial officer, had sold more than $500 million in stock to the company since 1999 while saying they rarely sold shares further damaged management's credibility.
Now Tyco's stock stands at less than half the level it was on Jan. 22, when the breakup was announced. Tyco fell $5.15 yesterday, closing at $20.75, down 19.9 percent.
"The breakup plan was a mistake, and I take full responsibility for that mistake," Mr. Kozlowski said. "It was the wrong idea at the wrong time." Instead, Mr. Kozlowski said, Tyco will split off only its big financing division, the CIT Group. Tyco bought CIT for nearly $10 billion last year. Tyco, which initially hoped to sell CIT in its entirety to another company, now plans to sell it to investors in an initial public offering, which will cost hundreds of millions of dollars in fees. Tyco hopes to raise about $7 billion in the offering, money it will use to shore up its balance sheet and pay down debt.
Some stock analysts questioned whether Tyco would be able to get that much for CIT.
Tyco badly needs to sell the unit to raise cash to strengthen its balance sheet, said Nicholas Heymann, a stock analyst at Prudential Securities. With the Middle East in turmoil and the economy's recovery slowing, Tyco may run into a cash squeeze if it does not raise more equity soon, he said. "You really got to get much more liquid here," Mr. Heymann said. "If you don't get liquid with CIT prior to having a real credit freeze-up, you might be on a different path. It might end up that the keys get turned over to the creditors."
Mr. Kozlowski called such concerns nonsense. Tyco continues to generate cash, he said, and its balance sheet is strong.
Tyco has suspended its previous plan to sell its plastics unit because it could not find a buyer at a reasonable price, Mr. Kozlowski said. He said buyers were willing to pay no more than $3 billion for the unit, which generates about $400 million in cash flow a year.
Tyco's electronics and telecommunications divisions, meanwhile, are sputtering. As a result, the company said yesterday that its earnings before one-time charges would be less than $2.70 a share for the fiscal year that ends in September, down from $2.81 a share last year. After those charges, to cover such things as office closings and severance costs, Tyco expects earnings to be about $1 a share this year, down from $2.17 last year. Only a few months ago, analysts had projected $3.70 a share.
Tyco also said it planned to lay off 7,100 employees, or 3 percent of its work force, mostly in its electronics and telecommunications units. As it tries to get business back on track, Tyco will essentially stop making acquisitions, Mr. Kozlowski said.
Tyco's problems are a sharp comedown for a company that was one of Wall Street's highest fliers in the late 1990's. From 1997 through 2001, an acquisition binge pushed Tyco's sales to $36 billion from $17 billion. Its reported income soared to $5.1 billion from $1.2 billion. With Tyco's earnings soaring, Wall Street happily supported Mr. Kozlowski's dreams with ever higher valuations and buy recommendations, even though a series of companies suffered spectacular failures a generation ago in trying to acquire their way into being industrial conglomerates.
Short sellers, who bet on a decline in a stock's price, said that Tyco appeared to use aggressive accounting to generate big gains in profits and that most of its sales growth had come from acquisitions. Tyco said its accounting was proper. But the company's long string of profit growth has come to an end.
Tyco's sliding earnings and plunging stock are another black eye for Wall Street analysts, who have come under heavy criticism recently for the poor quality of their research.
Tyco has been one of Wall Street's most recommended stocks in recent years. Even this winter, as questions mounted about the company's accounting practices and the disclosure of the stock sales by Mr. Kozlowski, most analysts retained their buy ratings on Tyco. Among the most bullish was Phua Young of Merrill Lynch, who put out dozens of reports recommending the company. Like several other analysts, Mr. Young did not return calls for comment yesterday.
But off Wall Street, comments were easier to come by. Graef Crystal, an executive pay expert, said Tyco's plunging stock proved that Mr. Kozlowski did not deserve the hundreds of millions of dollars in pay he had received.
"He's just a big pig," Mr. Crystal said. "The only thing that has protected him is the stock price."

HEADLINE: State Budget Talks Stumble Over Tax Receipt Shortfall 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Negotiations over a state budget stalled yesterday as legislative leaders and the governor wrestled with a new shortfall of at least $700 million caused by dismal tax receipts in April.
 Lawmakers also continued to work with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on a plan to grant him control over the city's schools system. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, again made it clear that any extra infusion of cash to city schools would be tied not only to giving the mayor the final word on educational policies, but also to compelling the city to maintain a high level of financial support for schools. 
 Despite high hopes on Wednesday night that a deal might be within grasp, Mr. Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, left an hourlong meeting with Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday afternoon empty-handed. Both acknowledged that the weak April tax collections had dampened hopes for an accord. 
"We have an outline and understanding of what we would like to do," Mr. Silver said. 
As they entered the meeting in Manhattan, the two legislative leaders had reached a tentative agreement with the Republican governor on about $1.2 billion worth of spending above the $88.6 billion plan the governor proposed in January, aides familiar with the talks said. But they have so far been unable to agree on how to pay for the new spending, which includes the restoration of some of the money that the governor proposed cutting.
The major hindrance has been a greater-than-expected drop-off in income tax receipts during April, when taxpayers must file their returns. The checks have been trickling in at a lower rate than even the ever-pessimistic governor had predicted, leaving a gap of about $700 million, legislative aides close to the talks said.
"There has always been a concern that we live within our means," Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman, Michael McKeon, said.
To make matters harder, the recent federal law aimed at stimulating the economy changed the depreciation rules for business assets like machinery and plants. The changes affect the state's own assessments of these assets and will reduce business taxes by at least $220 million. Neither the governor nor the legislative leaders are willing to pass a law making businesses use the old rules when figuring state taxes.
Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno have offered the governor a range of ways to find extra revenues, including a general amnesty program for people who owe back taxes, allowing deadbeat taxpayers to pay up without interest or penalties. Budget experts say the amnesty could raise $150 million. 
The legislative leaders have also proposed tapping a $2 billion balance in a special account set up to finance health-care programs that the administration has been loath to touch, legislative aides familiar with the negotiations said.
The proposed budget deal now being negotiated includes about $515 million more in state aid to school districts than the $14.2 billion in the governor's January proposal. Because the state's fiscal year ends on March 31 and the school year continues into the summer, only about $360 million would actually be spent in this year's budget. The rest would be pushed into next year.
The leaders also plan to use about $110 million in unspent school construction aid from last year for operating costs this year, easing the pressure on the state's general fund.
The proposed accord provides about $200 million in extra help to New York City's school system by speeding up state reimbursements for debts from prior years. 
The aid for city schools will not come without strings. It is tied to a proposal that would give Mayor Bloomberg control over the city's huge and troubled school system. It would also be linked to a promise from the city to restore most of the $358 million that Mr. Bloomberg cut from the school budget.
Mayor Bloomberg said yesterday that if the city got all the aid it was seeking from Albany, then any cuts to the classrooms would be prevented in the next school year. "I don't think anyone would like to cut education," Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday at a brief news conference. Asked about Mr. Silver's conditions, he said, "Speaker Silver has a right to his opinion."
Yesterday, an official close to discussions on how to give the mayor control of the schools said the Bloomberg administration and Mr. Silver were considering a plan that would expand the Board of Education to 12 members, from 7. The five borough presidents would each appoint one member of the expanded board, and the mayor would appoint seven. The mayor would also appoint the schools chancellor, who would count as one of the mayor's board members and serve as chairman of the reconfigured board, the official said.
Aides to Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Silver have not decided what powers the board would have, but they have agreed that the mayor would probably control the budget and operations, the official said. The board's role would be limited to major policy changes, although the two sides have not decided how to define such changes. 
The legislative leaders and the governor are also considering setting aside a cigarette tax increase, which the mayor has sought, for education. That would help ensure that City Hall supports its schools.

PERSON: Michael A. Cardozo 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Baseball on His Mind, but the Law in His Genes

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
THE slight, smiling lawyer in navy suspenders and jumbo aviator glasses seems not to mind being temporarily upstaged by the view -- breathtaking in a bad way -- from the corner office at 100 Church Street that comes with his clout-laden post as corporation counsel for New York City. 
 Want to see what a job-defining view looks like? 
 "Just look out this window," says Michael A. Cardozo, who takes pains not to and doesn't have to when seated at his desk, which faces away from ground zero (though there's no escaping the bangs and booms of demolition).
"I've gone from being one of the deans, I guess, of the sports-world bar to being a lawyer who represents the city on every conceivable legal issue to arise from Sept. 11: downtown economic development, property rights, lawsuits filed on behalf of victims, 1,300 claims filed against the city for damages that occurred post-9/11, extraordinary insurance issues that total over a billion dollars. The breadth of this job is unbelievable. There's a new controversy every day." 
And not all of them were spawned by the trade center attack.
The rabid Yankee fan lurking within the outwardly temperate Mr. Cardozo was reminded of that on April 5, when instead of attending the home opener, he found himself testifying before the City Council on the hot-button controversy of that day, the guardianship of the archives of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani: "I never knew I'd be in the middle of that."
Then there is the mandate from his budget-conscious boss, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, to reduce the staggering sum that City Hall spends on legal fees and settlements, which according to Mr. Cardozo was more than $550 million last year. He says lawsuits filed against the city make up a hardy 20 percent of the caseload of city courts, and this week Mr. Cardozo riled his brethren, the trial lawyers, by going to Albany to try to convince the Legislature that the city is operating on an uneven playing field. "We're not trying to prevent someone who's been injured from receiving compensation; what we're saying is that the law is too favorable to plaintiffs."
Too, Mr. Cardozo wants to undo what he believes is the city's overreliance on, and in some instances subjugation by, the courts in matters of social policy. "The homeless system has been subject to a judge's order since the late 70's, and the prisons have been run by the courts since, I think, 1975. It hamstrings our commissioners. If the city's argument is right, we're not going to roll over and play dead, but if I believe the city is wrong, let's resolve it so we don't end up having the court hound us for the next 20 years. Commissioners should be deciding policy, not the courts." 
Mr. Cardozo, 60, says the mayor gave him simple instructions for a complicated job. "He basically said, 'Michael, I don't know how to run a law department. You supposedly do, so go ahead and run it; just make sure to save money, be efficient and win the case.' "
If Mr. Cardozo is daunted by the legal conundrums he inherited, he is not divulging it. "I'm like a kid in a candy store," he says. "Taking this on was a no-brainer." 
For $162,800 a year, mere peanuts to senior-partner-types like him, Mr. Cardozo took control of the city's $94 million Law Department and its 650 lawyers. Within two weeks of being hired, he not only withdrew from the firm where he had spent 35 years in private practice, but also uprooted himself and his wife, Nancy, from their home in Scarsdale, which they now use as a weekend place, to Midtown.
HE figures his role model, Cyrus R. Vance, with whom he worked on Gov. Hugh Carey's Task Force on Court Reform, would approve the transition. "When I was a kid, I wanted to be shortstop for the Yankees, so I guess I played out my fantasies as a sports lawyer, but I always did public service on the side, so to speak, and now I'm doing it about 20 hours a day."
Mr. Cardozo made his name as a litigator at Proskauer Rose, specializing in sports law for clients like the National Hockey League, Major League Soccer and the National Basketball Association; he and his Scarsdale neighbor, David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, were classmates at Columbia Law School and on the same partner track at Proskauer. "The XFL was my only failure," he jokes, "but I didn't invent it; I just did the legal work."
When he moved into this office two weeks ago (it was shuttered after Sept. 11), he hung photographs of his great-grandfather's first cousin, United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo, and John F. Kennedy. His photographer uncle took the Kennedy picture and is one of the very few Cardozos not to go into law; Mr. Cardozo's dad, a real estate broker, was another rebel.
Mr. Cardozo grew up in Manhattan until junior high, when the family moved to Westport, Conn. His parents, both Democrats, were active in local politics, and "there was no question" that he would be a lawyer. The genes run in the family, not all of them unimpeachable. Benjamin N. Cardozo's father, Albert, a New York judge, was thrown off the bench in 1871, a casualty of the Tweed scandal.
"They formed the bar association in order to get rid of corrupt judges, and he was one of the first to go, so it was kind of ironic that over 100 years later I became president of the bar," says Mr. Cardozo, who served from 1996-98. "Albert was the black sheep lawyer of the family, and whether anything rubbed off on me, I'll leave for someone else to decide."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New Jersey: State Bond Rating Is Lowered 

BYLINE:  NYT (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 A Wall Street bond-rating agency lowered the rating on $3.4 billion in New Jersey bonds yesterday, citing the methods government officials used to balance the budget. 
Fitch's Ratings cited borrowing against the federal tobacco settlement and other measures as reasons for concern. It dropped New Jersey's grade from AA+ to AA on general bonds and lowered the rate for other types of debt. Bond ratings help lenders set interest rates when the state borrows money. A less favorable rating can make borrowing more costly, which could hinder the forthcoming $135 million bond sale by the Sports and Exposition Authority planned for next week.

HEADLINE: Aetna Health Care Unit Posts A Profit, Ending Its Drought 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Aetna reported a turnaround in its troubled health insurance business yesterday, reflecting sharply higher premiums and the loss of millions of members that it said had been money losers. 
 Aetna shares rose $5.93, or 13.5 percent, to $49.91, leading a surge in health insurer stocks. 
 It was the first profitable quarter for Aetna's health care business since December 2000. 
Now the nation's second-largest health insurer with 15 million members, behind the UnitedHealth Group, Aetna said operating profits in the first quarter were $64.9 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $84.6 million, or 59 cents a share, in the preceding three months. Most of the profit came from health care. Aetna lost $36.6 million, or 26 cents a share, in the 2001 first quarter.
With membership lower, revenue was $5.26 billion, down 18 percent from $6.43 billion in the 2001 quarter.
The company reported a net loss for the quarter of $2.83 billion, or $19 a share, after it wrote down $2.97 billion in good will remaining from past mergers to comply with a change in accounting rules. 
Despite weakness in the economy, Aetna, which is based in Hartford, and other health insurers have been able to raise rates in the high double digits. The California Public Employees Retirement Fund said last week that it faced 25 percent increases in health maintenance organization premiums for next year.
Aetna said its premiums would rise 18 percent this year, ahead of medical costs, which are expected to grow 15 to 16 percent. The company expects to earn about $200 million, or $1.25 to $1.35 a share in 2002.
Dr. John W. Rowe, chief executive of Aetna, said that as premiums rose many employers were passing some costs to employees. Workers, who are paying more in premiums, deductible amounts and copayments, may hesitate before going to a hospital emergency room for, say, a sprained ankle, he said.
"We are giving people some skin in the game," a personal financial interest in being cautious about seeking care, he said.
Wall Street analysts praised the Aetna results, which far outstripped their profit predictions: 3 cents a share, on average, according to a survey by Thomson Financial/First Call.
Todd Richter, a health care analyst at Banc of America Securities, said Aetna had "a terrific quarter."
But he said there was "still a fair amount of risk in the story."
"They won't know until next summer what their underlying costs are," he said, when the company finds out if its remaining members are healthier or sicker after the departure of four million members in 15 months.
Roberta Goodman, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, noted that Aetna's medical cost increases of 15 to 16 percent were still substantially above other companies' increases, suggesting that Aetna might have to raise prices faster than competitors.

HEADLINE: Cooperation on Energy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Former Vice President Al Gore should know that our air quality has improved dramatically in the last 30 years ("The Selling of an Energy Policy," Op-Ed, April 21), and that this has occurred even as our population, economy, jobs and energy consumption have grown. In fact, history shows that without economic growth, there are no appreciable environmental improvements. 
 Our best manufacturers and engineers work constantly on the next generation of cleaner, more efficient energy technologies and look forward to the day their products are economically viable. But for now, our economic health is tied to fossil fuels. 
Mr. Gore complains about a conspiratorial executive branch. He should instead work with business to improve energy conservation and supply.

JERRY JASINOWSKI
President, National
Association of Manufacturers
Washington, April 22, 2002

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Rivals Try to Redefine Their Party 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 22 

 BODY:
It can seem a money-devouring, slow-motion daydream as Edward G. Rendell, the garrulous, risk-friendly former mayor of Philadelphia, and Robert P. Casey Jr., the cautious, earnest state auditor general, slog along in the Pennsylvania Democratic primary for governor. 
 The candidates maintain their well-mannered encounters in occasional civic forums where even Mr. Rendell has been caught dozing off. Their television advertisements wage the more visceral and costly battle. 
 The party money raisers have reached $25 million and counting for this nationally watched race. But until this week, the rivals were not even certain of the climactic May 21 primary date because of a court challenge to the state's new reapportionment plan.
"The time is now," Mr. Rendell, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared on Sunday in a public television debate as the redistricting court prepared to let May 21 stand.
"People are focused on the race," Mr. Casey agreed, looking toward the four-week homestretch of a race that is rated a tossup in opinion polls.
Attorney General Mike Fisher, the Republican candidate for governor who has no primary challenger, awaits the victor as his party's strategists hope the two Democrats deplete themselves and their coffers.
For all the uncertainty and ennui that has marked the primary, the stakes are stark for those intent on defining how Democrats can best renew their party.
Mr. Rendell, the 58-year-old urban tactician who put a fresh gleam on downtown Philadelphia, is fighting for a larger arena to try out such typically ambitious ideas as a New Year's special legislative session to overhaul education by cutting local property taxes while raising state aid through higher cigarette and gambling revenues.
Mr. Casey, the 42-year-old son of the late Gov. Robert Casey, the populist rebuffed by national Democratic leaders for his fervid anti-abortion stand, is fighting with much of his father's determination for a revival of the party's old blue-collar basics, leading with a proposal for a $1 increase in the state minimum wage.
The campaign's subtext is all about the post-Clinton definition of a victory strategy for Democrats in Pennsylvania and beyond. The state hung in for Vice President Al Gore in 2000, with Chairman Rendell at his side, compounding its importance this year for battle-testing party ideas for 2004.
Studious, patient and polite, Mr. Casey has been promising a new party commitment to "stand in the shoes" of working families in seeking economic, education and health care improvements. Endorsed by the state party leadership, Mr. Casey is running strong in much of the socially conservative, rural and industrial heartland. 
Rumpled, backslapping and kinetic, Mr. Rendell accuses his rival of nothing more than "the standard talk you've heard from politicians for years."
"They didn't take risks," Mr. Rendell says, offering a gravelly voiced prescription: "You've got to be willing to use the power the voters give you."
In their separate ways, both men can claim headway. Mr. Rendell, the initial underdog with three decades of campaign experience, has been roaming the state for months in a John McCain-like bus caravan. He has managed to catch up in opinion polls that currently suggest a Democratic victory in November. 
Mr. Casey, a Scranton native in only his fifth year of elective experience, is trying to hold down the pro-Rendell vote in Philadelphia. He has gained significant endorsements there from labor and black church leaders with bitter memories of Mayor Rendell's pro-business, budget-cutting initiatives.
Mr. Casey is gentlemanly on the stump. But he has no-holds-barred lieutenants filming every minute of Mr. Rendell's roamings. They fed the news media taped excerpts of Mr. Rendell briefly nodding off at one polite forum. His glazed look was welcomed more as a comic respite than a gotcha scandal. 
Mr. Rendell accuses Mr. Casey of "the worst type of campaigning" in running negative advertisements about the Rendell mayoralty in most markets but Philadelphia. Sensing a close vote, Mr. Rendell has invited moderate Republicans in the Philadelphia suburbs to switch enrollment to make sure they have him as a more attractive option in the November election. 
"What we have here is Rendell, a lifelong pol who first came on as 'America's mayor,' versus Bob Casey, the squeaky-clean newcomer from a beloved party family," said Mayor John D. W. Reiley of Pottsville, boiling down the choice for the estimated one million Democrats who might vote.
Mayor Reiley has endorsed Mr. Casey. Yet he says he can never forget how Mr. Rendell quietly visited his son, Terry Reiley, a Rendell worker, when the son was dying from leukemia. "That's the nature of politics," the mayor said.
In attacking Mr. Rendell's stewardship of Philadelphia, Mr. Casey emphasizes that the state recently took over the city's troubled public schools. "I think he misled the people," Mr. Casey declared of Mr. Rendell's claims to have improved the schools even as he tried to sue the state for a better financing formula.
Mr. Rendell implicitly underlines Mr. Casey's inexperience by speaking of the "tough and unpopular" fights that the Rendell administration waged to turn Philadelphia away from bankruptcy.
Mr. Casey, dogged as his father, keeps up the ideological pressure, identifying Mr. Rendell as a principal in the Clinton era's compromising over issues like welfare reform and globalization.
"You might as well not have a Democratic Party," is his ultimate criticism of Mr. Rendell.
But Mr. Rendell, a battle-hardened loser and winner in primaries past, leaves no doubt what party earned him his scars.
"It's fair to look at what I've done," he declares as the homestretch looms. "But let's look at the plans for the future." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert P. Casey Jr., left, and Edward G. Rendell at a debate. Each seeks the Democratic nomination in Pennsylvania's race for governor. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Court Reverses Direction 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court acted wisely this week to preserve the ability of states and localities to institute land use and zoning regulations to control growth and protect the environment. In doing so, the court dealt a major setback to the conservative-led property rights movement, ending its string of recent Supreme Court victories elevating the rights of individual property owners over valid planning and community needs.
 At issue in the new case was a temporary moratorium on development along the shores of Lake Tahoe, which straddles the California-Nevada border, imposed by the regional planning agency charged with protecting the lake's environmental health. Owners of undeveloped lots along the scenic lake contended that the prolonged restriction depriving them of "all economically viable" use of their land while the agency addressed environmental problems that threatened the celebrated clarity of Lake Tahoe's waters amounted to an official "taking," entitling them to "just compensation" under the Constitution. 
 Fortunately, six of the nine justices disagreed. The majority opinion, written by John Paul Stevens and joined by Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony Kennedy, David Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer, is not unsympathetic to the plight of landowners left in limbo by the moratorium. But the decision recognizes the larger practical harm to the public interest of treating temporary government freezes on development as seizures of private property requiring compensation, as if they were the same as a permanent physical taking.
"Land-use regulations are ubiquitous and most of them impact property values in some tangential way -- often in completely unanticipated ways," Justice Stevens wrote. "A rule that required compensation for every delay in the use of property would render routine government processes prohibitively expensive or encourage hasty decision making."
At last a majority of justices has confronted the practical implications of the court's recent property rights jurisprudence and restored limitations that respect the public, not just private property.

HEADLINE: Fox's Wooing of America Brings Him Woes at Home 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 25 

 BODY:
In his 18 months in office, President Vicente Fox has tilted Mexico in a new direction: an open embrace of the United States. 
 The Mexican revolution is 92 years old, and Mr. Fox has retired its war horses. The facade of anti-Americanism, maintained for seven decades by the old ruling party, has vanished. The flag of Latin American solidarity against Yankee imperialism is furled. 
 In their place stand the pursuit of free trade, foreign investment and now, for the first time, human rights. Mexico's unusual criticism of its old friend Fidel Castro in recent days is the latest sign of that cultural revolution.
"The world has changed," Mr. Fox said Wednesday. "We have changed -- I'd say in a radical way -- Mexico's foreign policy," and done so despite "a lot of resistance."
Now that resistance is rising right and left, as skeptics ask what Mr. Fox has to show for his stances beyond pleasant promises from his friend President Bush. His fiercest critics say he is making Mexico a 21st-century banana republic, at the service of the United States. 
"It doesn't seem that he is promoting Mexico's interests," said Jorge Chavez Presa, one of the old ruling party's leaders in Congress. "We want to play a role in the world, but not if that means accepting orders from the United States." 
Past presidents of Mexico pretended to keep a distance from their northern neighbor. But they have become much closer since the 1980's. President Carlos Salinas spent most of his six-year term fighting to win the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States. When Mexico's economy collapsed in 1995, President Ernesto Zedillo turned to Washington for a huge bailout.
"Salinas got Nafta, Zedillo got $40 billion," but Mr. Fox has gotten almost nothing from the Bush administration, said Arturo Valenzuela, President Clinton's National Security Council officer for Latin America.
Although Mr. Fox is well regarded by his fellow Latin American leaders, and polls suggest a majority of his countrymen support him, the younger and better-educated Mexicans who helped elect him fear that he has won little return for his political investment in American policies and trade practices.
"Fox is selling Mexico to the United States," said Ursula Diaz, a sociology student at Metropolitan Autonomous University in Mexico City. "Previous governments hid their relationship with the United States. Fox apparently no longer wants to conceal it." 
Her classmate, Fabian Ovalle, 22, said: "When Fox speaks to Mexicans he speaks in terms of sovereignty and development. But when he goes to the United States, he talks about harmony and ceding to American interests."
As a result of Nafta, Mexico's economy is now fueled by $250 billion a year in commerce with the United States. But for all his salesmanship, Mr. Fox has yet to strike the political deals he needs to convince his public at home about the new relationship. His ministers have told the White House that if it does not help him win legal status for Mexican migrants, for example, Mr. Fox will be in political trouble at home. 
Mr. Fox's foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda, contended in an interview that "the polls -- our polls, public polls, opposition polls -- show that public opinion in Mexico overwhelmingly supports President Fox's foreign policy."
"But that does not translate into legislative support" in Congress, he conceded.
That is an understatement. The domestic fight over his foreign policy is becoming "a very strong struggle for power in Mexico," said Mr. Valenzuela. 
The old rulers of Mexico, the past and present leaders of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI, want their country back from Mr. Fox, who deposed them in 2000 after 71 straight years in control. In Congress, where the PRI still holds a plurality, Mr. Fox's foes are quashing almost all of his proposed economic and political reforms, and bashing him for favoring the United States.
The fight erupted again this week after Fidel Castro released a secretly recorded telephone conversation in which Mr. Fox asked the Cuban leader not to "complicate" things for him in front of President Bush at a summit meeting last month in Monterrey, Mexico.
The old Mexico, pretending to be aloof from the United States, publicly admired Mr. Castro's revolution. The new Mexico, openly attracted by American power, condemns the lack of democracy in Cuba.
But the domestic consequences of his foreign policies may leave Mr. Fox with fewer political allies at home, crippling his ability to change the way Mexico works.
So Mr. Fox, with no real political coalition inside or outside his Congress, keeps looking to Washington to help him gain and use power. But President Bush, who once said that "those who ignore Latin America do not fully understand America itself," has offered little to his friend in need. 
"The opposition hits Fox where it is most effective, in his relations with the United States, a vulnerable flank," said Jorge Chabat, a political analyst in Mexico City. "If their bets pay off, they could win back the presidency."

HEADLINE: City in Talks to End Lawsuit Over Community Gardens 

BYLINE:  By ANNE RAVER and JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The Bloomberg administration is negotiating with New York State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer to put to bed one of the most rancorous legal battles left behind by the previous administration, one that pit gardens against low-income housing, Bette Midler against Rudolph W. Giuliani, and the city against various plantiffs.
 The Giuliani administration had adopted a policy that city lots, which over the years had become speckled with tomato plants and sunflowers, should cease being community gardens and be used instead for housing or economic development or put up for sale. 
 Environmentalists and community groups fought the city, asserting that the tiny plots were the closest thing that poor neighborhoods had to a park. Lawsuits ensued, including one brought by Mr. Spitzer arguing that auctioning off the lots violated state environmental laws. 
Bette Midler bought some of the plots. In July, a judge in Brooklyn denied the Giuliani administration's request to lift a court order protecting more than 400 gardens. 
But now the Bloomberg administration and Mr. Spitzer have begun negotiations that both sides hope will result in some gardens reverting to the city for development of low-income housing, and some going to communities, officials from both sides say. Mr. Bloomberg has said recently that he believes that community gardens are viable in some situations, but that housing is preferable in others.
"We are in discussion with the attorney general's office, to see if the suit can be resolved," said Jeffrey D. Friedlander, a lawyer for the city. "I don't know the numbers precisely, but some gardens would be developed and some would not."
He added: "We hope to resolve the lawsuit soon, in discussions, and the sooner the better."
City officials would not comment on whether those gardens not slated for development would be sold to a land trust, like the New York Restoration Project, which bought 111 gardens for $1 million in May 1999. 
But Joseph Pupello, the president of the Restoration Project said: "I will probably be able to talk about it next week. If there's a way that we can preserve a high number of gardens in one fell swoop, it would be absolutely amazing."
The city gained legal ground with an April 8 ruling by Judge Leon Ruchelsman of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn that rejected a suit brought by the Green Guerillas, a community garden advocacy group, to block the development of the city's 600 community gardens without an environmental review process, because they are "dedicated parkland." 
That argument was a keystone to the lawsuit brought by Mr. Spitzer's office, which prompted Justice Richard D. Huttner to issue a preliminary injunction in 2000, barring the auction of city gardens.
"I don't know when he will rule on the attorney general's suit," Mr. Friedlander said. "One of the issues that is common to both is the question whether these gardens are dedicated parkland. If they are, then parkland is unalienable and cannot be sold. But that claim was rejected by the judge."
The Bloomberg administration, which has been trying to settle various pieces of litigation from the previous administration -- and to prevent certain types of other suits from beginning -- was receptive to the idea that they could develop housing on the sites of some gardens, as long as they followed state laws dictating that environmentalists study the land first, the officials said. The Giuliani administration resisted this idea and wanted to begin development unfettered; as such, the two sides were never able to meet.
The city's law department and officials from Mr. Spitzer's office resumed discussions three weeks ago. The discussions, officials on both sides said, are going well but are far from over, and will resume next week. "We are hopeful of working with the administration to resolve the matter," said Darren Dopp, a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron with Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:
Ubiquitous Bubba
 What did Bubba think of the high-wattage celebrities at the PEN American Center's dinner at the Pierre Hotel on Wednesday? RON HOWARD was there. So was SALMAN RUSHDIE, saying that his next book would be a collection of essays titled "Step Across This Line." Honorary chairmen included LAUREN BACALL, BILL T. JONES and JESSYE NORMAN. 
 Bubba seemed to be snarling at his mate when the question crossed the questioner's mind, so the question went unasked. And the novelist AMY TAN's Yorkshire terriers, Bubba and Lilli (short for Lilliput, said Ms. Tan, left), went back to whatever they were doing in the over-the-shoulder bag that was their home away from home for the gala. 
She had taken Bubba (but not Lilli) to the premiere of the WOODY ALLEN film "Hollywood Ending" on Tuesday, where she talked about the time she carried him through the Oval Office. A friend who worked in the Clinton White House showed her around; the president was away that day. Socks, the Clintons' cat, was oblivious, she said.
PEN gave a $25,000 award to VANESSA LEGGETT, a freelance writer who was jailed for refusing to surrender her tape-recorded interviews to a grand jury. "When I was in jail," she said, "I really didn't think my life could get any more surreal."

A Wing and a Chair
This is why RON FRIED'S newly won Emmy has a broken wing, and why he had a hole in his hand.
Mr. Fried, a vice president of the Metro TV cable channel, collected the Emmy as executive producer of the weekly series "Subway Q and A."
When he got up in the middle of the night after the award presentations, he bumped into the chair on which he had hung his tuxedo. "You know how Emmys have wings?" he said. "You know the flesh between my ring finger and my pinkie finger? It went in one side and out the other." And broke off from the Emmy.

A Tennessee Story
Here are two facts about FAYE DUNAWAY: (1) She and Tennessee Williams were friends. (2) When she decided to direct a short film, she chose his short story "The Yellow Bird." (The film will be shown on Sunday on WE, the women's entertainment cable channel.)
"He gave me his recording of this short story, which was the most delightful, larky, kick-up-your heels story," she said. She shot the film in four days after persuading JAMES COBURN to star. "I sent him a lot of orchids, that's what I did," she said.

Checking Out la Source
JEAN-MARIE LE PEN, the far-right candidate for the French presidency, attributes one of his homilies to MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG.
Mr. Le Pen said last week that he was "socially on the left, economically on the right and nationally French." Agence France-Presse said the remark drew fire from many who believed it paraphrased Hitler. The news agency quoted Mr. Le Pen as saying: "It wasn't from Hitler that I got my references, it's from Bloomberg, the Jewish mayor of New York." Mr. Le Pen said he noticed the line in an Air France in-flight magazine.
In fact, the most recent issue of the Air France magazine does feature a profile of Mr. Bloomberg, which says he once stated "with total assurance that he was 'socially a Democrat, fiscally a Republican,' " but the quote ends there. Mr. Bloomberg often says that he is socially liberal and fiscally conservative. He tends not to use party terms in that description.
"We're flattered his ideology has won international acclaim," said the mayor's spokesman, EDWARD SKYLER. Referring to Hitler, he added, "I can promise you the mayor's remarks were not inspired by that despicable murderer." And Mr. Bloomberg's view of Mr. Le Pen? Mr. Skyler did not say.
Sometimes children can uncover as many facts as grown-up reporters do. Yesterday Mr. Bloomberg and his daughter, EMMA BLOOMBERG, 22, who also works at City Hall, were interviewed by a large group of children who were taking part in Take Your Child to Work Day. It was thus learned that he has no favorite color; that, like much of his audience, he enjoys peanut butter and hot dogs (no relish, thank you very much); that he still supports the idea of school uniforms; and that his favorite baseball team is whichever team is playing on the day he is asked. With Jennifer Steinhauer

HEADLINE: Tax Revenues Lag, Threatening to Double Deficit 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
Tax revenues have been flowing in to the federal government at far lower levels than anticipated, raising the possibility that this year's budget deficit could be twice as big as projected, government and private analysts said today.
 A big portion of tax receipts reach Washington in the weeks after the April 15 tax-filing deadline, and the analysts said it would be another week or two before a definitive tally is available. But they said the trend so far suggested that receipts could end up as much as $70 billion lower than expected. 
 A shortfall of that magnitude would equal a little less than 5 percent of anticipated revenues of $1.42 trillion from personal and corporate income taxes. But it would roughly double the projected deficit for the current fiscal year, which stands at $73 billion after accounting for a corporate tax cut enacted last month and President Bush's request for $27 billion in additional spending this year, using Congressional Budget Office figures. 
A $70 billion shortfall in tax revenues, combined with deficit projections, would produce a deficit of more than $140 billion for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.
"It's too early to know for sure, but if these trends continue, this is bad news for the budget, no question about it," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee.
Officials at the White House and the Treasury Department declined to comment, saying it was too early to draw any conclusions about how much revenue the government would collect.
Analysts said the government had processed about two-thirds of this month's tax receipts. 
If the early indications of a substantial shortfall hold up as the Internal Revenue Service finishes opening envelopes and depositing checks from taxpayers, it would suggest that last year's recession eliminated or reversed the positive revenue surprises of the last five years. For reasons that are still partly unexplained, tax receipts in much of the economic boom of the late 1990's ran at higher-than-expected levels, playing a crucial role in the swing from budget deficits to surpluses. Though figures are still sketchy, the shortfall this year appears to be largely from nonwithheld individual tax payments, a category that includes taxes on capital gains, stock options, dividends, real estate sales and other nonwage income.
But analysts said tax refunds had also been larger than expected, suggesting that wages last year might have fallen more than other economic statistics had captured.
Economists at Goldman Sachs, the investment firm, said nonwithheld receipts appeared to be running about 30 percent below projections, implying that the deficit would be $40 billion or so higher than anticipated.
Other analysts said refunds had been running about $20 billion more than anticipated going into April, and that revenue from withholding for some individual and corporate tax payments was about $10 billion lower than expected. It is unclear how much of the likely shortfall stems directly from corporate rather than individual tax payments. As a result, they said, it was possible that the total shortfall could come to about $70 billion.
"We're getting close to the time when these numbers get pretty firm," said Jan Hatzius, an economist at Goldman Sachs. "It's trending pretty negative at this point, at a time when government spending is still on an upward path."
The government ran surpluses for the last four years. But even before this year's likely revenue shortfalls became apparent, the government was expected to be in the red for at least the next several years.
The turnabout was due to a combination of the $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut signed into law last year by President Bush, the weak economy and increased government spending after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
The re-emergence of deficits has had little economic impact so far. But the political implications, though muted by the bipartisan consensus after Sept. 11 that the government should spend whatever is necessary to fight terrorism, could still be substantial.
Should the deficit grow this year, Democrats said, it would strengthen their case that last year's tax cut was fiscally irresponsible and that there was no room for the additional tax cuts the administration is seeking.
"It's bad news for those who are pushing for new tax cuts," Mr. Spratt said.
Any additional tax cuts, he said, would mean "more borrowing and more spending of the Social Security trust funds" -- a theme that Democrats have already been hitting hard in an effort to beat back Republican efforts to make last year's 10-year tax cut permanent.
But Republicans are sure to use any deterioration in the fiscal outlook to argue against further increases in spending beyond what Mr. Bush has sought for the military and increased domestic security. Without referring to any revenue shortfall, Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, warned members of the appropriations committees from both parties today not to tack any extra spending onto Mr. Bush's request for an additional $27 billion to cover antiterrorism programs through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30.
"If we are to reinvigorate our economy, it is imperative that we take steps to control spending," Mr. Nussle said.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo; 
Economic Revival Poses a Problem for Bush

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
On Friday morning, the government will release figures expected to show that the economy came roaring back in the first three months of this year, bringing a curtain down on the recession and giving cause for optimism to workers, businesses and investors.
 But for President Bush, who distanced himself from the weak economy even before taking office and has since avoided blame for the rise in unemployment, the good news presents a quandary. 
 Should he take credit for the rebound and embrace the economy as his own? Or should he remain mindful of the economic and political risks, including the possibility that joblessness could remain elevated all this Congressional election year, and emphasize the negatives?
It is an issue that has been much debated in the administration, where the politics of the economy are viewed through the prism of the experience of the president's father. 
A decade ago, Democrats portrayed the senior President Bush as blind to the economic strains on people even after the official end of the last recession. Failing to counteract that attack may have cost him re-election, a lesson that has permeated this White House's strategy.
Administration officials said today that Mr. Bush's comments on Friday would depend to some extent on the strength of the figures for the gross domestic product in the first quarter. 
But they suggested that Mr. Bush would try to have it both ways. They said he would most likely hail the improvement as evidence that his policies, especially last year's tax cut, are working, despite new evidence that the budget deficit may be growing to higher-than-expected levels. At the same time, he will emphasize that the economy's performance is not good enough. He also will probably reiterate his message that the best available insurance against many of the risks still facing the economy would be to pass the many elements of his agenda that have been blocked by the Democratic-controlled Senate, including further tax cuts, reduced barriers to trade and more domestic oil exploration.
Emphasizing that he did not yet have advance knowledge of what the economic growth figure would be, Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic policy adviser, said in an interview today that it was "almost certainly good news" and would underscore the value of last year's tax and interest-rate cuts.
But he said the data, which Wall Street economists expect to show that the economy grew at around a 5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, would largely reflect a one-time boost to the economy from businesses restocking their inventories.
It is unclear, Mr. Lindsey said, whether the recovery will remain as robust as the year progresses, especially given the uncertainty about factors like oil prices and the possibility of another terrorist attack.
"So we should not be complacent about the future," he said. "I certainly don't think the president is."
Even before the presidential election was decided, Mr. Bush emphasized that the downturn had begun on President Bill Clinton's watch. He has recently dismissed economic statistics as important only to "bean counters," saying he recognizes that times are tough for many people no matter what the numbers say.
But if his presentation is intended in part to show that he has the empathy his father was accused of lacking, it also seeks to advance his party's election-year attacks on the Senate as obstructionist.
It is the Senate, administration officials said, that killed Mr. Bush's plan to decrease dependency on foreign oil by drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. It is the Senate, they said, that has held up legislation to help businesses get insurance against terrorist attacks, a problem they said was damaging construction by making it hard for developers to get loans.
Democrats dismissed the implication that the remaining risks to the economy are their responsibility. They said they would battle the president and Congressional Republicans over the economy, whether or not the statistics remain strong.
They said they intended to focus on pocketbook issues like health care costs rather than the overall state of the economy. "On the pocketbook issues, Democrats have an opportunity and an advantage," said Michael P. Meehan, the polling and message director for the Democratic National Committee.

HEADLINE: As Egypt Curbs Dissent, Critic Fears His Fate at Trial 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 24 

 BODY:
Egypt's most prominent democracy activist looks tired.
 Saad Eddin Ibrahim moves slowly around his airy apartment here, his shuffling a reminder of small strokes he says he suffered during a recent eight-month prison stay. He is bracing for a new trial scheduled to start on Saturday, before a judge with a reputation for severity. And he is discouraged by what he sees as the government's effort to contain the outrage of his countrymen over Israel's treatment of the Palestinians. 
 "The security services are getting stronger," said Mr. Ibrahim, an Egyptian-American sociologist who is widely known abroad. "Political parties are getting weaker. Civil society organizations are being muffled. Human rights groups are being intimidated again."
Egypt's leaders are not doing so well, either, he said. "The saddest thing is that they are wasting opportunities that this country has to be better, because of a hardening of the political arteries, because the elite is not getting any oxygen," he said. "I may have been having these small strokes, but they have been having big ones."
Mr. Ibrahim, 63, is one of many Egyptians who now see a difficult time ahead, one in which public anger over the conflict in Israel threatens to spark a tinder of domestic grievances about a stagnating economy and autocratic governance.
In the past several years, the government of President Hosni Mubarak has extended its authoritarian hand, taking on not only Islamist militants but also human rights activists, intellectuals and gays.
Since his first arrest in June 2000, Mr. Ibrahim has been a symbol of that shift. Along with 27 others connected to the Cairo research center he founded, Mr. Ibrahim was put on trial in February 2001 on charges that included sullying Egypt's reputation, accepting foreign donations without permission and embezzlement. He was convicted and sentenced to seven years in prison.
The case resonated in part because of the many protest flags that Mr. Ibrahim has hoisted -- for open elections, human rights, an end to discrimination against the Coptic Christian minority -- and because his voice has easily carried abroad.
The prosecution was also striking because Mr. Ibrahim had enjoyed access to the inner circles of Egyptian power, at times even acting as an adviser to Mr. Mubarak.
Mr. Ibrahim's prison sentence prompted complaints from governments and human rights groups abroad. In February, the verdict was overturned by an appeals court.
But preparations for the retrial of Mr. Ibrahim and some of his co-defendants have not indicated any softening of approach. The new proceeding was scheduled quickly in the Supreme Security Court, and petitions by Mr. Ibrahim's lawyers that he be allowed to travel to the United States for medical treatment have gone unanswered.
"It is part of their trying to teach me a lesson," Mr. Ibrahim said, "and the learning curve is very low."
But since his release 10 weeks ago, Mr. Ibrahim has not been his old sharp-tongued self, at least in public. His colleagues, who have had to defend themselves without access to the support Mr. Ibrahim can command, appear even more chastened.
"This case has been a blunt message to young researchers that we will not be allowed to do fieldwork in areas like human rights and political awareness," said Khaled Fayyad, 30, who directed a project on political education and voter rights for Mr. Ibrahim's Ibn Khaldun Center for Development Studies. 
Mr. Fayyad also said he would not work again with Mr. Ibrahim, whom he accused of failing to look out for subordinates. "He was supposed to be the captain of the ship," Mr. Fayyad said. "Instead, he acted like any other sailor, worrying only about his own rescue."
Mr. Ibrahim has disputed the assertion that he did not worry about the others, about half of whom received suspended sentences and will not be retried. But he agreed that the case is about more than just himself. During the early 1990's, he said, while the government was fighting Islamist militants, it was happy to have him on prime-time television to criticize Islamist violence from a liberal perspective.
"As soon as they thought they had gotten the Islamists under control and I began monitoring the 1995 election, they canceled the program," he recalled.
Although the current crisis in Israel "gives civil society a moment when it can reassert itself with legitimate dissent," Mr. Ibrahim said, the government remains wary that such dissent will spread. That risk, he added, is rooted in the government's long reluctance to give Egyptians a clear picture of its foreign policies or military strength.
Egyptians, he said, "don't know that war is not an option." He added: "They don't know that the peace treaty with Israel is still binding. Most of those kids demonstrating weren't even born when that peace treaty was signed. They see the Palestinians resisting the Israelis with no arms, with nothing, and they ask, 'What are all these armies we have for?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Saad Eddin Ibrahim has been supported by human rights advocates. (Norbert Schiller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Seeking Ways to Slow Growth of Hospital Outlays Under Medicare 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26 

 BODY:
House Republicans said today that they were drafting legislation to slow the growth in Medicare payments to hospitals and had discussed the idea of charging elderly people a modest co-payment for the use of home health care services.
 Home care is one of the few services for which no co-payment is now charged. 
 The proposals are being considered as part of a Medicare bill that Republicans say they intend to push through the House before the Memorial Day recess.
The centerpiece of the bill is a proposal to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare. As a corollary, House Republicans plan to alter the formulas for paying hospitals, doctors, nursing homes, home health agencies and health maintenance organizations, all of which are lobbying for more money. 
White House officials have insisted that such changes must not produce a net increase in Medicare spending beyond what is envisioned under existing law. Increases for some health care providers would thus have to be offset by cuts in payments to others.
Many lawmakers say their top priority is to increase Medicare payments to doctors. In recent months, some doctors have refused to take new Medicare patients, saying Medicare paid too little to cover their costs. 
Medicare cut payments to doctors by 5.4 percent this year. With no change in current law, the fees paid for each physician service will be reduced in each of the next three years, for a total decrease of 17 percent from 2002 through 2005.
Lobbyists for Medicare beneficiaries, hospitals and home health agencies protested today after learning of the Republican ideas. Medicare accounts for nearly one-third of hospital revenues, on the average, but at some inner-city and rural hospitals, the proportion is far higher.
The ideas emerged from weeks of discussions by the House Ways and Means Committee and the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which share authority over the Medicare program.
Medicare is a potentially explosive issue. Any proposal for new co-payments would be highly contentious. 
Ken Johnson, a spokesman for Republicans on the Energy and Commerce Committee, said: "We intend to produce a Medicare reform bill next month. A wide range of options have been discussed, but no decisions have been made yet on how to proceed. Admittedly, some of these ideas are very controversial politically. There has been some discussion of co-payments for home health care, but an issue of that importance will be decided only by the members."
In the past, Democratic members of Congress and lobbyists for the elderly have complained that the sickest patients would be hardest hit by co-payments. In 1997, the Senate voted to establish a charge of $5 a visit for home care services under Medicare. President Bill Clinton objected, and the idea was dropped in negotiations with the House.
This year, House Republicans said, they are considering a flat co-payment for each 60-day period in which a person receives home health care. They said the amount would be modest.
The overall Medicare bill is expected to pass the House on a party-line vote. Members of both parties see a political imperative to add drug benefits to Medicare. But some Congressional aides and lobbyists said today that many Republicans would be reluctant to vote, in this election year, to cut the scheduled increases in payments to hospitals and other health care providers.
Proposals developed by the two House committees are subject to review by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, who could suggest changes to ensure that the package would be politically acceptable.
Under existing law, hospitals are scheduled to receive an increase in Medicare payments to account for the full effect of inflation -- about 3 percent a year -- from 2004 to 2007. The preliminary House Republican plan would reduce the update by one-half of a percentage point each year, saving $5 billion over five years.
Hospitals say they cannot absorb such cutbacks when their costs are rising rapidly. The new costs are for prescription drugs and blood products, nurses' salaries, bioterrorism preparations and insurance.
Charles N. Kahn III, president of the Federation of American Hospitals, said: "Hospitals are still recovering from previous Medicare cuts and face mounting new cost pressures. So we believe that a full inflation update is in order for 2003, and that cuts should not be considered for future years."
A Republican working on the legislation said it would not actually cut payments to hospitals, just slow the rate of growth.
Thomas P. Nickels, senior vice president of the American Hospital Association, who talks frequently with House Republicans drafting the legislation, acknowledged that "there would be an increase in overall Medicare payments from year to year." But Mr. Nickels insisted: "There would be a decrease from what the government promised hospitals. The government would pay us less than inflation."
William A. Dombi, vice president of the National Association for Home Care, said: "We have concerns about the impact of a co-payment on Medicare beneficiaries. We don't want a new tax on people who use our services. Most of the people we serve are poor or nearly poor."
Medicare spending on home health care dropped to $9.1 billion in 2001, from $17.5 billion in 1997. But the Congressional Budget Office predicts that it will climb to $12.5 billion next year and $17 billion in 2005.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: KYRGYZSTAN; 
A Bustling U.S. Air Base Materializes in the Mud

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: PETER J. GANCI AIR BASE, Kyrgyzstan 

 BODY:
Four months ago, this was a muddy prairie next to a sleepy airport in what used to be a nearly forgotten part of the Soviet Union.
 Today it looks like a scene from "M*A*S*H" and is at the new front lines of the American military presence. Nearly 2,000 soldiers, about half of them American, are camped out here in air-conditioned tents. 
 At the landing strip nearby, FA-18 fighter jets and French Mirages take off on daily sorties over Afghanistan, rattling the windows of nearby farmers as they roar into the sky. Spanish, Dutch and Danish cargo planes fly in and out as well, along with KC-135 tankers to provide the combat jets with in-flight refueling. 
"Everything you see here has literally been done since the middle of January," said Gen. Wayne Lloyd, who returned to active duty with the Air National Guard to take on the job of base commander in mid-March. "This was done in the dead of winter, in the middle of frostbite-freezing cold."
Officially, the air base here, named after the New York City Fire Department's highest-ranking uniformed officer, who died in the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11, is only temporary and will be closed after the war in Afghanistan has ended. But no one knows just how long the mission will last, or even how its end will be defined.
"We will stay as long as it takes," General Lloyd said. "I can't say when that will be, but I don't think it will be in the next few weeks."
Kyrgyzstan, a impoverished former Soviet republic with five million people, is one of several Central Asian countries that have abruptly become important strategic allies of the United States. It shares a border with Afghanistan and quickly opened itself to the American-led military coalition that declared war on the Taliban regime.
About 2,000 American troops are also stationed in neighboring Uzbekistan, at Hanabad, near the border with Afghanistan. A small contingent of American soldiers is in Tajikistan, one of the poorest and most chaotic countries in Central Asia.
Though almost everyone here lives and works inside tents, the elaborate infrastructure implies a more extended presence.
The base has a central power plant, its own hospital center, two industrial-sized kitchens, a recreation center and an expansive fitness center. Soldiers can watch live American sports on wide-screen television sets. They can send e-mail at what amounts to an Internet cafe. They can work out on weights, treadmills and cycling machines.
The population has grown so quickly that French forces here decided to set up the second of those kitchens, catering to French tastes.
"I could tell from the start that this would be one of the better bases," said Clint Parks, an airman who came here two months ago and had previously worked at the air base in Kuwait. "The living conditions are great here. I was surprised by how much they have."
Inevitably, the buildup here and in neighboring countries has provoked uneasiness. 
Russian leaders have been remarkably supportive of the effort, given how intensely they resisted the expansion of NATO into Poland and the Czech Republic. But diplomats and regional experts say that both Russia and China are uncomfortable about American forces so close to their borders, and they predict that tensions will escalate if the bases stay in place longer than expected.
Air Force officials here estimate they have already pumped more than $13 million in cash into Kyrgyzstan's economy. A single takeoff or landing can cost as much as $7,000 in fees paid to the government. The base has spent millions of dollars on everything from gravel and jet fuel to televisions, computers, cell phones and even guided tours.
That is a lot of money in a country where the average person earns about $270 a year and the national debt is equal to about $300 a person.
American officials have also increased economic aid sharply, not just to Kyrgyzstan but to Uzbekistan and Tajikistan as well. The State Department also recently announced plans to provide about $30 million to help Central Asian countries fight trafficking in weapons, and $20 million to help Uzbekistan strengthen export controls and border inspections.
In theory, the flow of new money ought to make life better for people in these countries. But none of the Central Asian countries are bastions of good government.
Kyrgyzstan remains one of the world's most impoverished countries. It has made a genuine effort toward democracy and Western-style economic reforms, but it can hardly yet be called democratic. In March, the police killed seven people and wounded more than a dozen others who were protesting the imprisonment of a member of Parliament.
Uzbekistan remains notorious for brutal political repression as well as for corruption and hostility to market-opening economic reforms. Tajikistan, which was embroiled in civil war for five years, remains a major corridor for heroin traffickers and so hostile to economic reform that Western aid institutions have almost stopped providing help.
It is perhaps not surprising that people who live near the new air base here fail to see it as a boon to their pocketbooks.
"When the Mirages take off, the noise rattles the windows," said Sonya, a woman in the nearby village of Mramornoe who was unwilling to give her last name. "They take off at all hours of the day and night, and it really bothers me. It also bothers the animals. The hens are not laying eggs."
A Kyrgyzstani public television station recently reported that 60 percent of people surveyed around Bishkek, the capital, which is nearby, would just as soon not have the base. 
Local villagers are quick to explain why. Dirt roads and open fields near the airport have been cut off. Local people who board buses at the airport for the ride into Bishkek now have to show their identity papers because the airport has become a restricted area. Furthermore, although the foreign soldiers seem friendly, they spend little money locally.
"We don't see any benefit to us," said Nina Grigorevna Haritonona, a retired doctor in Mramornoe. "They don't spend any money here. They even have their own food."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 29, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about United States troops in Kyrgyzstan, a country that has abruptly become a strategic ally of the United States, misstated its proximity to Afghanistan. Afghanistan and Kyrgyzstan do not share a border.
