HEADLINE: City Limits 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
MICHELLE CAPUTO, 28, has visited New York City a half-dozen times in her life. On its face, this would hardly seem unusual. She prefers to take getaway vacations to more tranquil locales, most recently to Florida, Cancun and the Bahamas. 
 But Ms. Caputo has lived her entire life in Rutherford, N.J., a 15-minute drive into Midtown Manhattan. 
 She doesn't even pop into Manhattan for a night out. For her, the city's bother -- traffic, crowds, expense, parking problems -- outweigh its benefits. 
"Honestly? It's just inconvenient," said Ms. Caputo, who is a billing auditor at a Paramus telecommunications company. "You have to deal with getting there and getting back. You're surrounded by people and you can't do anything. I hate standing in line. I don't want to wait a half-hour in a station for some train. Here, I can get into the car and go where I want in a half-hour, park right in front, and not deal with a million people."
Ms. Caputo is not alone. Sure, there are tourists who travel thousands of miles and spend thousands of dollars to visit New York City. There are young people in small towns all over America for whom New York is a mecca, whose fervent dream is to move to the city to live, to work, to reinvent themselves. Yet many suburbanites within clear view of the Manhattan skyline remain virtual strangers to the city, rarely venturing in. For many of them, visiting New York City was something you did as a child, going to see the Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall or taking out-of-town relatives to the Empire State Building. 
Easy access to Manhattan is something people pay dearly for. The city bestows upon its suburbs -- north in Westchester and Connecticut, east on Long Island, and north, west and south in New Jersey -- some of the highest housing prices, taxes and costs of living in the world. And indeed, most suburbanites are on familiar terms with that place known to all simply as the City. Yet there are people who do not know the Bronx from the Battery and do not care to. There are plenty of suburbanites, sane, sociable, sophisticated, who will look you in the eye and tell you they simply do not see what the fuss is over Manhattan. 
Burta E. Smith, 70, a retired accountant, lives in Fairfield, a 75-minute train ride to Grand Central Terminal. She is active (she baby-sits full time) and adventurous (last summer, she drove her car to Texas), but she has visited Manhattan only about four times since she moved to the East Coast in 1991 from the Los Angeles area.
Once, she was "bribed" to visit the city with tickets to "Cats," she said, and the other times she agreed to accompany sightseeing relatives.
"I would never go into the city on my own, either by car or train," she said. "I'm really not a city girl. It's nothing personal. I just like my peace and quiet. I have pretty much everything I need here."
Avoiding Manhattan was understandable during the city's more dismal days, when its streets were dirty and crime-ridden, when going through a tunnel meant fending off squeegee men, when the subway was scrawled with graffiti, and the sidewalks were full of stereotypically rude, rushing New Yorkers.
The image of the pushy New Yorker may never change, but the city has. Manhattan is much safer and visitor-friendly now. Since Sept. 11, many now regard the city with greater sympathy. But for many of those who once shunned or feared it, the disaster has reinforced their aversions to New York.
Many experts say a suburbanite tendency to avoid the city may be more pervasive than ever. Partly, it is a reflection of societal shifts over recent decades. As the city's economy has decentralized, more jobs have spread to the suburbs. It is no longer so necessary to commute to the city. Many services, once considered the exclusive domain of Manhattan, including fine restaurants and shopping, cultural and fine arts offerings and state of the art hospitals, are now suburban staples as well.
But avoiding New York City seems to have more to do with mindset. Those who shun the city offer various reasons: Some don't want to go; some don't need to; others are afraid to. Some lack the time, others the money. Some have been unnerved by bad city experiences or the terrorist attacks. Certainly, many suburban families have tight schedules, and Manhattan winds up getting pre-empted by a regimented lineup of children's soccer games, karate practice and birthday parties.

Strange People, Tall Buildings
Psychologists who practice in the suburbs say fear of New York is a common condition among their patients. Fears range from becoming lost or trapped or mugged in the city to being surrounded and suffocated by crowds of strange people and tall buildings. Some patients have been taught by their parents to be wary of the city, and speak of New York as a terrifying foreign land, said Peter S. Kanaris, a Smithtown, N.Y., psychologist who uses various techniques, including relaxation and meditative breathing, to get patients to be able to travel into Manhattan. "When you think of the city, you think of this great diversity of people," Mr. Kanaris said, adding that a typical patient's reaction to that is: "It's a place where I'm going to encounter many types of different people and that feels dangerous to me." 
Beth Wilson, 57, of Amityville, N.Y., said she has visited the city about 10 times in the past 10 years. Each visit has caused panic attacks, she said, a vertigo that can be relieved only by staring down at the pavement and running "in the direction of Long Island."
"It's a claustrophobic thing," said Mrs. Wilson, a program administrator for Cablevision in Bethpage and a lifelong Long Islander. "I feel like Superman when he has the Kryptonite." 
Nina K. Thomas, a clinical psychologist who practices in Morristown, N.J., said that some suburbanites may become so cloistered that "traveling to Manhattan takes on the air of a major trip, as if to a foreign country."
This is the case for Victoria Linefsky, 44, who has basically avoided New York City since childhood and has not set foot in Queens or Brooklyn in 15 years. Mrs. Linefsky, who works part time both in a law office and a preschool, lives in Massapequa, just west of Amityville. The city is an hour's drive to Manhattan in light traffic, but it is worlds away for Ms. Linefsky, who said she has "no clue" how to navigate Manhattan, or even hail a cab. "I don't know my way around," she said. "What's uptown? Downtown? What's a good section?" Her three children, ages 18, 14 and 9, are Long Islanders, and she has no intention of making them New Yorkers. 
"My parents never raised me very culturally," she said. "I've never been to a play in the city. I've never been to Broadway."
James R. Brown, sitting at the bar at the Ninth District Veterans Club in the Glenville section of Greenwich, said of New York City: "Why would you want to go down there? To pay $6.50 for a beer?" Mr. Brown, 55, known locally as J. B., is a maintenance worker for the town of Greenwich, but is out on disability. He lives in Byram and his last visit to Manhattan occurred about 20 years ago, he said, and that was for his job.
The bartender, Joseph Salvatore, 61, of Greenwich, said he has only begun visiting the city again in recent years, to take his two young daughters who are learning about Manhattan in school. Mr. Salvatore, a local cemetery caretaker, said before that, he had not been to the city in about 15 years, "and if I wasn't taking them, I wouldn't be going down there." 

The Metropolis in the Backyard
Anti-urban sentiment is not new. After all, the suburbs sprang up largely as an alternative to city life, an escape from crowding, pollution and strangers. Immigrants who came to New York through Ellis Island worked their way from gritty urban tenements to modest, grassy plots in Levittown or New Rochelle. Many of them, and the generations they begot, have never felt the need to look back. 
"I can't tell you how many students I've asked, 'When was the last time you were in the city?' and they've said, 'When I was 5,' " said Gail Satler, a sociology professor at Hofstra University who teaches urban planning and design. Most of Ms. Satler's students have grown up on Long Island within an hour of the city. But few students were even remotely familiar with New York City, so she began planning class trips into Manhattan to introduce them to the metropolis in their backyard. 
"We were talking about it like it's so far away and it's not," she said. "Unless I make them go, most of them won't." 
In March, the class visited St. Patrick's Cathedral and Times Square. "Half of them had never seen Central Park," Ms. Satler said. "Some are embarrassed and some are proud. Their attitude is: They've never been in, and they don't have to be."
For 20 years, Mineola High School in Nassau County, has offered its senior-year students a one-semester class on New York City. The curriculum covers everything from night life to architecture. Students are taken on monthly trips into the city. Paul Pereira, a social studies teacher who teaches the class, understands the suburban mindset from firsthand experience. "The only time I went in as a kid is when I went in on a bus for a school trip," he said. "Most of these kids think it's scary and dangerous and dirty like they see in the movies, and that's why we teach the course."
His own parents were from Portugal. "They were happier sending me in my teens the 3,000 miles to see Portugal than sending me 30 minutes on the train to the city," Mr. Pereira said."A lot of kids pick up stereotypes about the city from their parents who were born and bred here. For them the suburbs equal a better quality of life. But culture's not out in Mineola or Massapequa. It's just lawns and shopping malls and storefronts here. There's no character.
"I get parents coming up and asking, 'Do you offer this class for adults?' Even parents who work in Manhattan, a lot of them just go in and come right out again."

The Suburb to Suburb Commute
Over recent decades, the activity that was once the sole province of New York City has decentralized, allowing people to settle in the suburbs and shun the city, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. 
"The suburbs have become self-contained universes," he said. "There are very few unique things in the city now that suburban people feel they have to access on a regular basis." 
Professor Hughes noted, for example, that in 1950, New York City had 3.4 million jobs, and the state of New Jersey had 1.7 million. But in 2000, New Jersey had 4 million jobs compared to the city's 3.7 million. The trends were similar in Long Island, Westchester and lower Connecticut. 
The proliferation of suburban office parks in the 1980's allowed many commuters to the city to work in the suburbs instead. Mr. Hughes said that the network of office parks in New York's suburbs, including north-central New Jersey; Fairfield County, especially in Stamford, in Connecticut; the White Plains area in Westchester, and Route 110 on Long Island has the third largest amount of office space in the country, behind New York City and Chicago.
"The suburbs have really evolved into horizontal cities, replicating the urban market place," Professor Hughes said.
Now most people, he continued, are commuting from one suburb to another. Most people now work in the county in which they live or in an adjacent one. There are now about 50 large regional malls outside Manhattan, accounting for roughly 50 million square feet of retail space. And some New York City dwellers even travel to the suburbs to shop at big box stores like Ikea in Elizabeth, N.J., and Home Depot in Yonkers. 

'Everything I Need Is Here'
 Some simply stay in the suburbs because of the comforts: the grass, the trees, the space, the privacy -- and the familiarity. 
Patrick Driscoll lives in Millburn, N.J., a half-hour drive from Manhattan. Mr. Driscoll co-owns a bicycle shop in Millburn. His wife is pregnant with their third child. Apart from a few business obligations, he has hardly visited the city in the last five years. "I really don't go in any more of my own accord," he said. "The city is just not something we really think about much. I'd rather not deal with that many people. I like a slower environment and having a million people waking around you on the sidewalk, I'd rather be sitting in the backyard in a small town, relaxing." 
Taking the trains can be a deterrent, especially negotiating transfers. "It's not just the people you don't know," he said. "It's a whole system you don't know." 
Suburbanites are used to the privacy of their cars, essential in suburbia but often an impediment to navigating Manhattan, where there are more aggressive drivers and fewer parking spaces. 
Dan Rattiner, editor and publisher of Dan's Papers, a free weekly newspaper distributed on eastern Long Island and in parts of Manhattan, moved from Greenwich Village to eastern Long Island in the early 1980's and did not return to the city for 10 years. 
"I decided I didn't need to go back at all, I was so happy here," Mr. Rattiner recalled. "The closest I'd get was J.F.K. Airport. I traveled all over the world but never to New York. I would fantasize that it didn't exist at all, that it was just a big, cardboard skyline." 
Mr. Rattiner said he now visits the city about every three weeks, but added, "I know people, adults, who've never been out of the Hamptons, much less to New York City." 
Those who do go into the city regularly, just because they want to, not because they work there, are sometimes met with surprise. Geoff Thompson of Briarcliff Manor in Westchester co-owns a public relations firm there whose clients are almost exclusively Westchester businesses. 
Mr. Thompson said he travels regularly into Manhattan to attend New York Rangers games, Broadway shows and films. It never fails to amaze the neighbors, he said. "When I tell them we went into the city, they say, 'Jeez, you did? We haven't gone in for years,' " he said. "I'm always astounded. There are many people who would drive to Cape Cod more readily than drive into the city and see a film. 
"You can see the Manhattan skyline from here, but for many people here, it might as well be the Land of Oz," he said. "It's funny, because so many people in Westchester originally came from New York City, and they talk about it like they moved to Vermont, instead of just Katonah."

GRAPHIC: Photos: James R. Brown, left, of Greenwich, sitting at the bar at the Ninth District Veterans Club, hasn't been to Manhattan in 20 years. "Why would you want to go down there? "It's not that we don't want to go in more, but we don't really have the time," she said. "We have four kids and we're involved in our community." HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Out of Work, but Not Rushing to Return

BYLINE:  By MARCI ALBOHER NUSBAUM 

 BODY:
IN the spring of 2000, Ned Mansour resigned as president of Mattel after Jill E. Barad, the chief executive, was forced out. Unemployed for the first time in his 27-year corporate career, Mr. Mansour, then 51, started meeting with headhunters.
 Within a month, he changed course after learning that a friend and former colleague from Mattel, Joseph McKay, had terminal colon cancer. In fact, Mr. Mansour was the first person Mr. McKay told about his illness. "He was a very private guy," Mr. Mansour said. For six months, he put his job search aside to care for his dying friend. 
 As the economy has sputtered over the past couple of years, many senior managers have found themselves in Mr. Mansour's shoes, out of work for the first time. Most have rushed to find another job, but a surprising number have decided to use the reprieve to take stock of their lives. And, they say, they have come to appreciate the chance to spend more time with their families, return to neglected hobbies and rejuvenate their lives.
Many, of course, have the cash reserves to finance the time off, and most are optimistic about their chances of returning to high perches in business. Even so, a few have decided to abandon the corporate world for another vocation.
"There is a theme here," said Steven Lesser, a consultant in New York for Right Management Consultants. "These people are very sophisticated and have always made an impact. Now some are choosing to look at life differently and make an impact in different areas."
Mr. Mansour's support for his friend ranged from handling legal affairs to picking up groceries and even administering morphine when the pain became unbearable. "I was surprised by how attached and dedicated I became to Joe," he said.
Though Mr. Mansour had little trouble switching gears, experts say many hard-driving executives need prodding to slow their pace and to reconnect with other parts of their lives. Alexandra Duran, a career coach and the principal and founder of Career Transitioning, says that when unemployed clients panic, she encourages them to think hard about the future and not to latch onto the first opportunity that comes along. Some clients even take out loans or second mortgages to finance these periods of reflection. "I help them come to terms with the fact that reassessing one's life and career is, in fact, productive," she said.
Even people with no desire to move in a new direction often find that a healthy attitude is crucial to dealing with joblessness.
Consider Kenneth Brause, 37, whose job as head of investor relations at the American General Corporation was eliminated in January when his company merged with the American International Group.
Mr. Brause feels no shame about being out of work. He talks about his unemployed status with acquaintances, many of whom are in the same boat, and he believes that his openness will improve his chances of finding a new position.
He is enjoying the interruption of a 15-year career in which he often canceled vacations and had little time with his family. He treasures doing things he could not do when he had a rigid work schedule, like taking his son to school or his daughter to a play date. "I realize that I can't spend every hour of the day looking for work," he said.
Being out of work has had another benefit for him and his wife, he said. The extra time together as a family "has been good for the healing process," he said, after his wife's stepmother was killed in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
SOMETIMES, losing a job reignites old passions. For nearly five years, Brett Kopelan, 33, was working 75-hour weeks. Then, last year, he was laid off as director of business development at beMany.com, a failed Internet company.
Knowing his job was vulnerable, he had started a job search even before the layoff. Soon, he received several offers for jobs in marketing and business development. 
It was then that he realized he didn't want to keep working at the same pace. "I wanted to take some 'me time,' " he said, "to redevelop some skills I used to have, some things I felt I'd lost over the years."
For the next 15 months, Mr. Kopelan lived on savings and spent time advising a nonprofit group and pursuing hobbies he had long ignored. He played his guitar regularly, set up a digital recording studio in his apartment, returned to his interest in photography and got a dog.
Recently, Mr. Kopelan planned his next career move. In May, he will launch a recruiting firm that will specialize in health sciences. Though he knows that running his own business may mean even greater pressure than working for someone else, he says he is committed to retaining his quality of life. "I need to remember that work isn't life," he said. "It's only a way to have one."
Mr. Mansour, the former Mattel executive, has no plans to return to corporate life. After his friend died, he began writing a short story inspired by his experience of caring for him. It became a novel, "Divided Roads," about a jaded investment banker who has a spiritual awakening when he befriends a boy with a life-threatening illness. Mr. Mansour financed the book's publishing and says he will give the proceeds to charity.
"Had I never left Mattel, I would not have made the same choice," he said. "Even though I could have visited him in the evenings and mornings, I just wouldn't have." He was so focused on work, he said, that "everything else, including family and friends, took second place."

HEADLINE: City Limits 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
MICHELLE CAPUTO, 28, has visited New York City a half-dozen times in her life. When she travels for fun she prefers more tranquil locales, most recently Florida, Cancun and the Bahamas. 
 But Ms. Caputo is not from Dallas or Des Moines. She has lived her entire life in Rutherford, N.J., a 15-minute drive from Midtown Manhattan. 
 She doesn't pop into Manhattan for a night out. For her, the city's bother -- traffic, crowds, expense, parking problems -- outweighs its benefits. 
"Honestly? It's just inconvenient," said Ms. Caputo, who is a billing auditor at a Paramus telecommunications company. "You have to deal with getting there and getting back. You're surrounded by people and you can't do anything. I hate standing in line. I don't want to wait a half-hour in a station for some train. Here, I can get into the car and go where I want in a half-hour, park right in front, and not deal with a million people."
Ms. Caputo is not alone. Sure, there are tourists who travel thousands of miles and spend thousands of dollars to visit New York City. There are young people in small towns all over America for whom New York is a mecca, whose fervent dream is to move to the city to live, to work, to reinvent themselves. Yet many suburbanites with a clear view of the Manhattan skyline remain virtual strangers to the city, rarely venturing in. For many of them, New York City was a place to be dragged to as a child, going to see the holiday spectacular at Radio City Music Hall or taking out-of-town relatives to the Empire State Building.
Easy access to Manhattan is something people pay dearly for. The city bestows upon its suburbs -- Long Island, Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey -- some of the highest housing prices, taxes and costs of living in the world. And indeed, most suburbanites are on familiar terms with that place known to all simply as the City. Yet there are people who do not know the Bronx from the Battery and do not care to. There are plenty of suburbanites, sane, sociable, sophisticated, who will look you in the eye and tell you they simply do not see what the fuss is over Manhattan.

"I decided I didn't need to go back at all, I was so happy here," Mr. Rattiner recalled. "The closest I'd get was J.F.K. Airport. I traveled all over the world but never to New York. I would fantasize that it didn't exist at all, that it was just a big cardboard skyline." 
Mr. Rattiner said he now visits the city about every three weeks, but added, "I know people, adults, who've never been out of the Hamptons, much less to New York City." 
Avoiding Manhattan was understandable during the city's more dismal days, when its streets were dirty and crime-ridden, when driving through a tunnel meant fending off squeegee men, when the subway was covered with graffiti and the sidewalks were full of stereotypically rude, rushing New Yorkers.

Certainly, many suburban families have tight schedules, and Manhattan winds up getting pre-empted by a regimented lineup of children's soccer games, karate practice and birthday parties. But avoiding New York City seems to have more to do with mindset.

Strangers and Tall Buildings
Psychologists who practice in the suburbs say fear of New York is a common condition among their patients. Fears range from becoming lost or trapped or mugged in the city to being surrounded and suffocated by crowds of strange people and tall buildings. Some patients have been taught by their parents to be wary of the city, and speak of New York as a terrifying foreign land, said Peter S. Kanaris, a Smithtown psychologist who uses various techniques, including relaxation and meditative breathing, to get patients to be able to travel into Manhattan. "When you think of the city, you think of this great diversity of people," Mr. Kanaris said, adding that a typical patient's reaction to that is: "It's a place where I'm going to encounter many types of different people and that feels dangerous to me." 
Beth Wilson, 57, of Amityville, said she has visited the city about 10 times in the past 10 years. Each visit has caused panic attacks, she said, a vertigo that can be relieved only by staring down at the pavement and running "in the direction of Long Island."
"It's a claustrophobic thing," said Mrs. Wilson, a program administrator for Cablevision in Bethpage and a lifelong Long Islander. "I feel like Superman when he has the Kryptonite."
Nina K. Thomas, a clinical psychologist who practices in Morristown, N.J., said some suburbanites may become so cloistered that "traveling to Manhattan takes on the air of a major trip, as if to a foreign country."
This is the case for Victoria Linefsky, 44, who has basically avoided Manhattan since childhood and has not set foot in Queens or Brooklyn in 15 years. Mrs. Linefsky, who works part time both in a law office and a preschool, lives in Massapequa. The city is an hour's drive to Manhattan in light traffic, but it is worlds away for Ms. Linefsky, who said she has "no clue" how to navigate Manhattan, or even hail a cab.
"I don't know my way around," she said. "What's Uptown? Downtown? What's a good section?" Her three children, ages 18, 14 and 9, are Long Islanders, and she has no intention of making them New Yorkers. 
"My parents never raised me very culturally," she said. "I've never been to a play in the city. I've never been to Broadway."
James R. Brown, sitting at the bar at the Ninth District Veterans Club in Glenville, Conn., said of New York City: "Why would you want to go down there? To pay $6.50 for a beer?" Mr. Brown, 55, known locally as J. B., is a maintenance worker for the town of Greenwich, but is out on disability. He lives in Byram, and his last visit to Manhattan was about 20 years ago, he said, and that was for his job.
The bartender, Joseph Salvatore, 61, of Greenwich, said he has only begun visiting the city again in recent years, to take his two young daughters who are learning about Manhattan in school. Mr. Salvatore, a local cemetery caretaker, said before that, he had not been to the city in about 15 years, "and if I wasn't taking them, I wouldn't be going down there."

The Backyard Metropolis
Anti-urban sentiment is not new. After all, the suburbs sprang up largely as an alternative to city life, an escape from crowding, pollution and strangers. Immigrants who came to New York through Ellis Island worked their way from gritty urban tenements to modest, grassy plots in Hicksville or New Rochelle. Many of them, and the generations they begat, have never felt the need to look back.
"I can't tell you how many students I've asked, 'When was the last time you were in the city?' and they've said, 'When I was 5,' " said Gail Satler, a sociology professor at Hofstra University who teaches urban planning and design. Most of Ms. Satler's students have grown up on Long Island within an hour of the city. But few students were even remotely familiar with New York City, so she began planning class trips into Manhattan to introduce them to the metropolis in their backyard.
"We were talking about it like it's so far away and it's not," she said. "Unless I make them go, most of them won't."
In March, the class visited St. Patrick's Cathedral and Times Square. "Half of them had never seen Central Park," Ms. Satler said. "Some are embarrassed and some are proud. Their attitude is: They've never been in, and they don't have to be."
For 20 years, Mineola High School has offered its seniors a one-semester class on New York City. The curriculum covers everything from night life to architecture. Students are taken on monthly trips into the city. Paul Pereira, a social studies teacher who teaches the class, understands the suburban mindset from first-hand experience. "The only time I went in as a kid is when I went in on a bus for a school trip," he said. "Most of these kids think it's scary and dangerous and dirty like they see in the movies, and that's why we teach the course."
His own parents were from Portugal. "They were happier sending me in my teens the 3,000 miles to see Portugal than sending me 30 minutes on the train to the city," Mr. Pereira said. "A lot of kids pick up stereotypes about the city from their parents who were born and bred here. For them the suburbs equals a better quality of life. But culture's not out in Mineola or Massapequa. It's just lawns and shopping malls and storefronts here. There's no character.
"They can't believe how safe it is, how clean it is and how much it has to offer," he said of his student's encounter with the city. "It's not what they perceived the city to be. They come in thinking the city's just dirty skyscrapers and homeless people and newspapers blowing in the wind and people walking with their heads down.
"I get parents coming up and asking, 'Do you offer this class for adults?' Even parents who work in Manhattan, a lot of them just go in and come right out again."

The Burb-to-Burb Commute
Over recent decades, the activity that was once the sole province of New York City has decentralized, allowing people to settle in the suburbs and shun the city, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. 
"The suburbs have become self-contained universes," he said. "There are very few unique things in the city now that suburban people feel they have to access on a regular basis."
Professor Hughes noted, for example, that in 1950, New York City had 3.4 million jobs and the state of New Jersey had 1.7 million. But in 2000, New Jersey had 4 million jobs compared to the city's 3.7 million. The trends were similar in Long Island, Westchester and lower Connecticut. 
The proliferation of suburban office parks in the 1980's allowed many commuters to the city to work in the suburbs instead. Mr. Hughes said New York's suburbs have the third largest amount of office space in the country, behind New York City and Chicago.
"The suburbs have really evolved into horizontal cities, replicating the urban marketplace," Professor Hughes said.
Now most people, he continued, are commuting from one suburb to another. Most people now work in the county in which they live or in an adjacent one. In the region there are now about 50 large shopping malls outside Manhattan, accounting for roughly 50 million square feet of retail space. And many New York City dwellers travel to the suburbs to shop at the malls or big-box stores like Ikea in Elizabeth and Home Depot in Yonkers.

'Everything I Need Is Here'
Some simply stay in the suburbs because of the comforts: the grass, the trees, the space, the privacy -- and the familiarity.
Patrick Driscoll lives in Millburn, N.J., a half-hour drive from Manhattan. Mr. Driscoll co-owns a bicycle shop in Millburn. His wife is pregnant with their third child. Apart from a few business obligations, he has hardly visited the city in the last five years.
"I really don't go in anymore of my own accord," he said. "The city is just not something we really think about much. I'd rather not deal with that many people. I like a slower environment, and having a million people walking around you on the sidewalk, I'd rather be sitting in the backyard in a small town, relaxing."
Suburbanites are used to the privacy of their cars, essential in suburbia but often an impediment to navigating Manhattan, where there are more aggressive drivers and fewer parking spaces. But mass transit looms large as an obstacle to those who don't go regularly to the city. 
Taking the trains can be a deterrent, especially negotiating transfers. "It's not just the people you don't know," Mr. Driscoll said. "It's a whole system you don't know."
Burta E. Smith, 70, a retired accountant, lives in Fairfield, Conn., a 75-minute train ride to Grand Central Terminal. She is active (she baby-sits full time) and adventurous (last summer, she drove her car to Texas), but she has visited Manhattan only about four times since she moved to the East Coast in 1991 from the Los Angeles area.
Once, she was "bribed" to visit the city with tickets to "Cats," she said, and the other times she agreed to accompany sightseeing relatives.
"I would never go into the city on my own, either by car or train," she said. "I'm really not a city girl. It's nothing personal. I just like my peace and quiet. I have pretty much everything I need here."
Those who do go into the city regularly, just because they want to, not because they work there, are sometimes met with surprise. Geoff Thompson of Briarcliff Manor co-owns a public relations firm whose clients are almost exclusively other Westchester businesses.
Mr. Thompson said he travels regularly into Manhattan to attend New York Rangers games, Broadway shows and films. It never fails to amaze the neighbors, he said.
"When I tell them we went into the city, they say, 'Jeez, you did? We haven't gone in for years,' " he said. "I'm always astounded. There are many people who would drive to Cape Cod more readily than drive into the city and see a film.
"You can see the Manhattan skyline from here, but for many people here, it might as well be the Land of Oz," he said. "It's funny, because so many people in Westchester originally came from New York City, and they talk about it like they moved to Vermont, instead of just Katonah."

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION / CONNECTICUT; 
College to Move Into Historic G. Fox Site in Hartford

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: HARTFORD 

 BODY:
A HARTFORD department store, G. Fox, designed by Cass Gilbert and built in 1917, has been rescued from years of abandonment by a partnership of the state-owned Connecticut Community College System and Anthony Autorino, a private developer. 
 When renovations are completed, Capital Community College, the Hartford branch of the system, will occupy 304,000 square feet of the 11-story building, and 960 Main Street, Mr. Autorino's company, will develop 421,000 square feet as a separate office, retail and restaurant complex. Another 125,000 square feet in the building is occupied by basement, utility and management space. 
 It has been undergoing reconstruction for two years at an estimated cost of $121.5 million. The state provided $56.5 million through the issuance of general obligation bonds; the developer is spending $45 million; and about $20 million is to be contributed by the state and the two-year college's fund for new equipment and furnishings. 
Capital Community College is characterized by its president, Ira Rubenzahl, as "primarily a college for working adults." He added, "The average age is 31, but we have 18- and 19-year-olds, some of whom will transfer to four-year institutions." Its student population -- 3,100 credit-earning students and an additional 2,000 noncredit students -- is expected to increase in the new site. "It is being built for a 20 percent increase in enrollment," Dr. Rubenzahl said. 
When the building opens on Sept. 1, it will be the first major project to be completed in Gov. John G. Rowland's program to revive the downtown of Connecticut's capital city, decimated over the years by the flight of residents and businesses to the suburbs. Other major efforts include Adriaen's Landing, a massive development where site work has begun for a convention center, hotel, housing, retail shops and parking; an upgrade of the Civic Center and Riverfront Park; and construction of parking garages and downtown housing.
In its heyday -- from the end of World War I through the mid-1960's -- G. Fox was one of the six largest department stores in the country and was known for its twin marquees over two Main Street entrances. The college will use one entrance, while the offices will be accessed through the other, separated by a wall. Each entrance opens onto its own 45-foot-wide-by-135-foot-long lobby lined with shops. "The message is that everybody walks through the retail areas," said Mr. Autorino, who expects a positive response from "retail-starved Hartford." 
While the building's physical condition deteriorated in recent years, a treasury of Art Deco embellishments designed by Taussig-Flesch Associates of New York during an interior renovation in 1937 have been remarkably well preserved. The original marble on walls and columns and the gray-veined pink marble floors are being restored, along with banks of three to five elevators with burnished steel doors surrounded with brass-inlaid nickel decorations set in marble. Staircases leading to a mezzanine encircling the arcade have steel, nickel and brass railings fashioned in Art Deco patterns resembling those in soigne Hollywood movie sets of the 30's.
According to Susan Chandler of the Connecticut Historical Commission, "there are not many expressions of Art Deco in Connecticut; New York was a mecca for it," but Connecticut distanced itself from urban styles. Among the rare and daring examples for their time are the interior of the Bushnell, the state's prestigious auditorium; the interior and exterior of the Polish National Home, both built in Hartford in 1930, and the Warner Theater in Torrington, now being restored. 
The most spectacular element in the college renovation is the replacement of a section of the roof with a 22-foot-wide-by-58-foot-long peaked skylight. Directly below it, open space was created by cutting away 22-by-58-foot sections of Floors 8 through 11. Daylight now floods the seventh floor Info Cafe and media center, where students will be able to have lunch while reading their e-mail at computer-equipped tables. "It took two days to drop each of the floors down one level," said the project superintendent, Dan Smith. The process produced some of the 15 million pounds of debris generated by the renovation. 
To get even more light into the building, 95 windows, 6 feet wide by 10 feet high, that had been painted over -- a practice in many department stores, where windows are masked to focus attention on merchandise -- were removed and restored. 
Most daunting, said James McManus, one of the architects whose initials form the name of S/L/A/M Collaborative of Glastonbury, "was fitting 38 classrooms; 48 computer, math, science and health labs; music and art studios; and a 16,000-square-foot library into the college space." Rooms had to be created in the wide-open floors that distinguish department store architecture. Supporting columns were worked around and those that could be removed were, along with 24 space-consuming escalators. 
An auditorium with a 350-seat capacity, marred by a previous tenant with a lowered ceiling, several portable toilets and partitions, is being restored, and a day care center and an outdoor fenced playground on a second-floor deck to accommodate more than 30 children is being installed. It will double as a training center for child-care courses in the curriculum. 
Jeter, Cook & Jepson Architects Inc. designed the office and retail space for Mr. Autorino, with Siemens Building Technology handling the mechanical, electrical and plumbing elements. While work continues, Mr. Autorino has secured new 10-year leases with two existing tenants: the Hartford Board of Education, which has two floors, and AT&T, with three floors. He has negotiated 10-year leases with a number of new tenants, including a jeweler, a computer store and companies taking space in a food court. "We are 71 percent leased," he said. Office rentals range from $19.50 to $30 a square foot annually; retail rents are $25 to $30 a square foot. 
THE store originated when Gerson Fox, a German immigrant, established a small enterprise on the site in 1845. His son Moses built the existing store after the original was destroyed by fire, and Moses' daughter Beatrice Fox Auerbach took over as president from 1938 to 1965. Innovative and civic-minded she was highly regarded as a retailer, business executive and philanthropist. In 1965, three years before her death from cancer, she retired and sold the store to the May Company for $40 million, never having to witness the store's downfall in the city's real estate debacle of the 80's.
In 1985 the May Company sold off 30,000 square feet to the partnership of Ginsberg & Schwartz, whose two-year effort to renovate and rent the space as offices failed. Unable to sell the building or maintain it, the May Company gave it to the city along with about $3 million worth of delinquent taxes and maintenance bills. The department store closed in 1993. The vacant hulk became a pariah among its prestigious neighbors that include the Wadsworth Atheneum, America's oldest continuously operating art museum; the Hartford Stage regional theater; the historic Old State House; and other cultural venues. 
"While it lay empty, the city considered several scenarios, looking for anyone who could help develop it," said Matt Fleury, public information director for the Capital City Economic Development Authority. A merger of the state's community college and technical college systems provided the impetus for Capital Community College and Capital Technical College, located in two buildings three miles apart on Woodland Street and Flatbush Avenue, to seek a single location. 
In 1999 a deal was negotiated in which the city sold the Fox building in two parts. The state bought the college portion for about $1.75 million, and Mr. Autorino took the rest for $4.75 million.
Next door, on the Talcott Street side, a new 850,000-square-foot Morgan Street Garage, built and owned by the Hartford Parking Authority, opened in January of this year. "This was very important to commuter students," Dr. Rubenzahl said. The authority will turn over a minimum of 800 spaces in the 2,300-car, nine-story parking facility for students to use free of charge. The rest is open to the public. 
A striking departure from most parking garages, the structure has nine external elevator and stairway towers of blue-green glass thrust skyward, ending in turrets above the roofline. The building itself is precast concrete in two shades of tan, colored during the mix by controlling the amount of sand and stone. "We wanted something that wasn't going to look typical or obviously a garage," said Edward Witkofsky, the project architect at Amenta/Emma Architects P.C. of Hartford.
Capital Community College will at long last have a single custom designed building and ample parking, Dr. Rubenzahl said. "I think the school will be transformed because we will be in the most important location in Connecticut -- Main Street in the capital city."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY / QUEENS; 
$82 Million Retail-Movie Center to Open in Jamaica

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER three decades and three unrealized development attempts, a two-acre city-owned site in central Jamaica, Queens, has been filled with a 411,000-square-foot entertainment and retail complex that will open next month. 
 The $82 million development, called Jamaica Center, has 135,000 square feet of retail space on its first two floors. Ten tenants have leased 80 percent of the space, including national retailers like the Gap and Walgreens. A 15-screen, 3,200-seat movie theater operated by National Amusements of Dedham, Mass., occupies the third floor, and there are two levels of underground parking for 400 cars. 
 The complex sits on a site, formerly used for parking, that is atop the Jamaica Center subway station at Parsons Boulevard and Archer Avenue. It is in the heart of the downtown shopping area -- along Jamaica Avenue -- which has struggled to rebound since the 1970's, when regional malls drained it of businesses and shoppers. 
Jamaica Center, which was developed by the Mattone Group of College Point, Queens, is the largest development financed mostly with private money in Jamaica in decades. Financing came from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Building Investment Trust and the developer's own equity, and another $14 million came from public sources.
Many local leaders hope the new stores and the return of movies to Jamaica after a 30-year absence will help the downtown to turn its fortunes around. 
"We have primed the pump with public investment since 1985," said F. Carlisle Towery, executive director of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, a nonprofit planning group. He pointed to the growth of York College on 50 acres south of the downtown and to the construction of two County Court buildings as well as of offices for the Social Security Administration and the Food and Drug Administration. 
Public investment continues in the form of a new terminal on Sutphin Boulevard at Jamaica Station for AirTrain, which is expected to start running next year. The light rail line, being built by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will link Kennedy International Airport to bus and subway lines and the Long Island Rail Road. 
Still, public investment has not been enough to encourage the more than 250 stores that line the one-mile long shopping district to stay open after the work day ends. "Most owners see Jamaica Center as providing a shot in the arm and the movie theater as giving them the choice to stay open later," said Janet Barkan, executive director of the nonprofit Jamaica Center Improvement Association, which administers the downtown's special improvement district, including the new center. 
Now other privately financed developments are also in the works. For instance, one and half blocks from Jamaica Center, plans are advancing to fill a city-owned site with two eight-story buildings with a total of 180 market rate rental apartments -- the first housing of this type in downtown Jamaica since the 1960's.
Another project in the works is a 300,000-square-foot office building on a city-owned site at 94th Street and Sutphin Boulevard adjacent to the AirTrain terminal. Late last year LCOR, a development concern based in Berwyn, Pa., with offices in Manhattan, was selected to build the project, where the Long Island Rail Road is to consolidate its scattered offices to 100,000 square feet. 
Mr. Towery said the influence of Jamaica Center could extend beyond keeping the shops open later to take advantage of the moviegoing crowd. He said that the hope was to attract more national chains to the area, as well as more restaurants, and to have shops of a higher quality replace some of the low-end retailers. 
Ms. Barkan said that because the national tenants at Jamaica Center provide "the kind of stores people go to the nearby suburban malls to find," the new development would help to capture retail dollars that now flow out of the area.
The project is expected to create 350 new jobs and provide $46 million annually in direct and indirect economic benefits to the city, said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which structured the deal with the Mattone Group. 
Other projects under way will also enhance the area's night life. They include the reuse of the empty city-owned First Reformed Church of Jamaica at 153-10 Jamaica Avenue into a 400-seat performing arts center and community space. An outdoor theater is being designed for on the grounds of the 1850's church, which is a city, state and national landmark, and construction is expected to begin in 2003. And the existing Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning, also on the avenue, is being renovated, said Hazel Ephron, a partner at Wank Adams Slavin Associates, the Manhattan architectural firm working on both projects.
Lawrence V. Anderson, managing principal at Levin Realty Services of North Plainfield, N.J., who has brokered many deals in Queens, said that while it was possible Jamaica's turnaround would happen because all the ingredients from population to transportation and night-time activity are in place, success is not a sure thing. Other retail professionals said the perception of the area as being unsafe is a lingering challenge.
It has taken six years to make Jamaica Center a reality. In 1996 the city selected the Mattone Group to develop the site after the three earlier proposals, which focused mainly on offices, failed to move forward. The company spent four years securing financing, tenants and approvals for the project, which was redesigned to the current mix when a 100,000-square-foot office component was dropped. 
The deal was finally closed in 2000, and the Mattone Group is leasing the site from the city with an option to buy it after the fifth year.
"It took a lot of convincing to draw national retailers," said Joseph Mattone Sr., chairman of the Mattone Group. He said tenants were ultimately persuaded to sign on for space by "evidence that there were enough dual-income households" nearby to support the project. A market study done for the company found some 300,000 people with an average household income of $53,743 living within a two-mile radius of the site. 
Michael X. Mattone, Mr. Mattone's son and the company's chief financial officer, said the $14 million in public funds ($11 million in grants and $3 million in a low-interest loan) helped to keep rents competitive. In turn, he said, that helped the company to secure lease commitments from tenants for a significant amount of the retail space as well as from the theater and garage operator. Annual rents will average $30 to $50 a square foot, depending on the size and location of the store, he said, adding that a percentage of the project's rental stream goes to the city to pay back the loan.
WHAT also helped fill the project is that it is in a state Empire Zone, where commercial tenants pay no state sales tax on equipment. They can also take advantage of business tax breaks and other incentives, including a discount on utility bills and a $1,500 credit against their state income tax for each new full-time employee brought onto the tax rolls.
National Amusements signed on as a tenant in 1999 after the developer was unable to come to an agreement with Sony Theaters, which earlier had been negotiating to put in a Magic Johnson movie house in the theater space. This will be the 12th theater in New York City for National Amusements, which continues to expand while the industry over all deals with an overbuilding frenzy of the 1990's that resulted in a spate of theater closings and bankruptcy filings by some big chain operators.
"We see Jamaica as a great location, with a tremendous population and access to transportation, that has been underserved for some time,"said Jennifer Hanson, a spokeswoman for National Amusements. 
Mr. Towery of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation said that seven movie theaters once operated in downtown Jamaica, but they all went dark as the area declined, with the last one closing in the 1970's. With Jamaica Center, he said, the area not only will be able "to recapture the entertainment activity, but the retail sales and jobs Jamaica has lost to suburban malls over the decades."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jamaica Center will have a 15-screen movie theater seating 3,200 as well as 135,000 square feet of retail space. (Richard Lee for The New York Times) Map showing the location of Jamaica, Queens

HEADLINE: Straight Talk, Straight Out of Newark 

BYLINE:  By LISA SUHAY 

DATELINE: VAUXHALL 

 BODY:
JACKIE HARDRICK came out of Newark to publish a book that has New Jersey teenagers and their teachers openly talking about sex, class struggles, racism, lies and consequences.
 "It's not a black thing, it's a young adult thing," Ms. Hardrick says of the topics tackled in her novel, "Imani in Young Love & Deception." "These issues are universal, but my race, African American that is, leads the nation in AIDS, high school dropouts, teen pregnancy, single-parent households and unemployment. So in that sense it does speak more to black teenagers." 
 Single and childless, in her early 30's, Ms. Hardrick now lives in Vauxhall, a well-tended North Jersey suburb, with her mother and a sister. She still gets to Newark frequently, where she lived until she graduated from college at age 25, visiting schools and libraries, running a sort of literary Scared Straight program for teenagers. 
"Now is my time to do this," she said. "I needed to take this risk and do this before I get married, have children."
Still, she says that not being a parent does not make her well of experience shallow. "All you have to do is look around, watch TV and have a background in the inner city to know what's out there," she said.
She apparently captured those surroundings skillfully, because her book has been praised by Ebony and Essence magazines. Indeed, she did so well that she left a job in human resources to lecture and lead discussions on the book and the subjects it raises.
Born in Newark, Ms. Hardrick was reared by strict Southern Baptist parents who had come North from Lumpkin, Ga. Her family rented one floor of a three-family house on Morris Avenue, next door to the Greater Bethel Baptist church, where her father, Eddie B. Hardrick, was a deacon. Though life was stable at home, the area was in what Ms. Hardrick called "a period of upheaval and decay," with high-rise housing projects being demolished and stores boarded up.
When her father wasn't at the church, he was working as a shoemaker in Edison. He died of complications from diabetes eight years ago, and the book is dedicated to him.
"I miss him," she said.
Her mother, Melba, now 67, worked in various factory jobs until her third child was born. Ms. Hardrick, the oldest child, has two brothers and two sisters, all of whom live in New Jersey.
Ms. Hardrick, a small, soft-spoken woman with short, straight hair and a slightly stiff bearing, seems more like a librarian of old than a cutting-edge novelist for the young. As she spoke to people lined up at her booth earlier this month at the New Jersey Library Association Conference at the Garden State Exhibit Center in Somerset, her shyness evaporated as her voice grew with emotion when she spoke about her race, the inner city and how "fast money and a fast life can lead to a quick death." 
Asked about where she finds inspiration she said: "I drive through Newark, I see a kid who should be in school, shuffling along. The same old winos on the corner that are the next generation of winos from when I lived there and I want to scream. I want to stop and tell them, 'Enough! God did not design you for this. You can be more.' "
There is a fire in the belly and preach in her speech. She is, after all, a deacon's daughter. Then she shrinks back into the unassuming author.
Ms. Hardrick attended Newton Street Elementary School and Central High School in Newark, where she began keeping a daily journal. She was the first in her family to graduate from college when she earned her bachelor's degree in business administration from Seton Hall University, in South Orange. She went to work as a department manager at a Macy's in Plainfield, a human resources supervisor for Anheuser Busch in Newark and then a buyer for Liz Claiborne in New York. 
Yet she was unsatisfied with the daily grind and feeling "like I wasn't contributing anything to the world." She began taking writing courses at a community college and attending writers' workshops where she was required to write short stories. " 'Imani' is the product of one of those short stories," she said.
She took a long look at society and found the materials bombarding the teenage population to be wanting and wanton. 
"Young adults, especially those of color, are drowning in negativism showered upon them by movies, media, lyrics," she said. "These vices are detours that are consuming young adult lives. Nobody is telling them to own up to responsibilities."
So, for two and a half years she spent her free time channeling her concerns and impressions into "Imani." Her manuscript was rejected by 10 literary agents before she decided to use her savings to publish 4,000 copies herself under the Enlighten Publications imprint in 1999. She then published a discussion guide as a companion for the book. The book, $14, is not sold in stores; it can be ordered at (866) 862-8626 or enlightenpub@yahoo.com
"I was no angel as a teen," Ms. Hardrick said. She did some stunts common to teenagers: swiping a cigarette that made her gag, club crawling, lifting candy from a grocery store. "But that didn't last. I was lucky because I had this grounding in the church and very strict parents who made our house like an oasis.
"I had a reference point growing up," she added. "I had two parents, which was rare even then. I had the church and chores and strict rules of conduct to follow." In the Hardrick household, children were in the house before dark "so nobody could get tempted into any kind of trouble."
That is not so in her book.
"Imani" follows the lives of a group of urban teenagers struggling into adulthood. They make the journey over hot coals like pregnancy, peer pressure, rich kid-poor kid dynamics, sexually transmitted diseases and drunk driving.
It is not a titillating romp, but a sober picture of truth and consequences. The book has spun off into a series of workshops called "Keeping it Real" for teenagers.
The sessions began in January with Herb Williams, programs and events coordinator for the Newark Public Library, who had the library buy 300 "Imani" books and distribute them throughout the high schools in Newark. 
He then created a series of book discussions on topics addressed in "Imani." Young actors were on hand to perform skits based on the book. The first event, Feb. 25, drew 300 youngsters. The next event at the library will take place 10 a.m. on May 6. Admission is free. Ms. Hardrick has visited perhaps a dozen schools in central and northern New Jersey, and as a result of her mentions in the magazines, she will be making presentations in Mississippi.
"This is no holds barred," Ms. Hardrick said of the discussions. "I take it as far as they want to take it. Yes, we do talk a lot about sex, but the book and my talks are pro-abstinence. I deglamorize sex. These kids get a lot of bad information on sex."
She also talks to youngsters about stereotyping by race and financial status. Ms. Hardrick views racial profiling by stores, employers and police as one more hurdle.
"Look, I was there," she said. "I worked in retail. I know that as a black woman walking into a store I am the first thing security zeroes in on."
Speaking of the program, Mr. Williams said: "I felt comfortable with it. Nothing went too far and I never felt embarrassed by anything discussed. We looked at issues and Jackie was very good at turning the discussion from sex to consequences and choices."
For her part Ms. Hardrick is jubilant about the sessions. "A girl wrote and said she didn't think she could read a whole book until 'Imani.' I think that's a step. Every teen I reach is a step up and over that barrier. I know I am succeeding when we do a session and the kids refuse to leave."

HEADLINE: There's No Place Like Home 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
MICHELLE CAPUTO, 28, has visited New York City a half-dozen times in her life. On its face, this would hardly seem unusual. She prefers to take getaway vacations to more tranquil locales, most recently to Florida, Cancun and the Bahamas. 
 But Ms. Caputo has lived her entire life in Rutherford, N.J., a 15-minute drive into Midtown Manhattan. 
 She doesn't even pop into Manhattan for a night out. For her, the city's bother -- traffic, crowds, expense, parking problems -- outweigh its benefits. 
"Honestly? It's just inconvenient," said Ms. Caputo, who is a billing auditor at a Paramus telecommunications company. "You have to deal with getting there and getting back. You're surrounded by people and you can't do anything. I hate standing in line. I don't want to wait a half-hour in a station for some train. Here, I can get into the car and go where I want in a half-hour, park right in front, and not deal with a million people."
Ms. Caputo is not alone. Sure, there are tourists who travel thousands of miles and spend thousands of dollars to visit New York City. There are young people in small towns all over America for whom New York is a mecca, whose fervent dream is to move to the city to live, to work, to reinvent themselves. Yet many suburbanites within clear view of the Manhattan skyline remain virtual strangers to the city, rarely venturing in. For many of them, visiting New York City was something you did as a child, going to see the Christmas spectacular at Radio City Music Hall or taking out-of-town relatives to the Empire State Building. 
Easy access to Manhattan is something people pay dearly for. The city bestows upon its suburbs -- north in Westchester and Connecticut, east on Long Island, and north, west and south in New Jersey -- some of the highest housing prices, taxes and costs of living in the world. And indeed, most suburbanites are on familiar terms with that place known to all simply as the City. Yet there are people who do not know the Bronx from the Battery and do not care to. There are plenty of suburbanites, sane, sociable, sophisticated, who will look you in the eye and tell you they simply do not see what the fuss is over Manhattan. 
Dan Rattiner, editor and publisher of Dan's Papers, a free weekly newspaper distributed on eastern Long Island and in parts of Manhattan, moved from Greenwich Village to eastern Long Island in the early 1980's and did not return to the city for 10 years. 
"I decided I didn't need to go back at all, I was so happy here," Mr. Rattiner recalled. "The closest I'd get was J.F.K. Airport. I traveled all over the world but never to New York. I would fantasize that it didn't exist at all, that it was just a big, cardboard skyline." 
Mr. Rattiner said that he now visits the city about every three weeks, but added, "I know people, adults, who've never been out of the Hamptons, much less to New York City." 
Avoiding Manhattan was understandable during the city's more dismal days, when its streets were dirty and crime-ridden, when arriving in Manhattan meant fending off squeegee men, when the subway was scrawled with graffiti, and the sidewalks were full of stereotypically rude, rushing New Yorkers.
The image of the pushy New Yorker may never change, but the city has. Manhattan is much safer and visitor-friendly now. Since Sept. 11 many now regard the city with greater sympathy. But for many of those who once shunned or feared it, the disaster has reinforced their aversions to New York.
Many experts say a suburbanite tendency to avoid the city may be more pervasive than ever. Partly, it is a reflection of societal shifts over recent decades. As the city's economy has decentralized, more jobs have spread to the suburbs. It is no longer so necessary to commute to the city. Many services, once considered the exclusive domain of Manhattan, including fine restaurants and shopping, cultural and fine arts offerings and state of the art hospitals, are now suburban staples as well.
But avoiding New York City seems to have more to do with mindset. Those who shun the city offer various reasons: Some don't want to go; some don't need to; others are afraid to. Some lack the time, others the money. Some have been unnerved by bad city experiences or the terrorist attacks. Certainly, many suburban families have tight schedules, and Manhattan winds up getting pre-empted by a regimented lineup of children's soccer games, karate practice and birthday parties.
This is the case with Nancy and Stephen Pryor who live in Rye with their four children, ages 5 through 13. Mrs. Pryor said that several times a year -- "when we want to do something special" -- the family piles into the S.U.V. (never the train) and takes the 40-minute drive into Midtown Manhattan. That includes the annual Thanksgiving Day parade with the family, and the annual night out for dinner and swing dancing.
Mr. Pryor, an accountant with a practice in Port Chester, grew up in Rye and Mrs. Pryor grew up in New Rochelle. Neither were ever big city people.
"It's not that we don't want to go in more, but we don't really have the time," said Mrs. Pryor. "We have four kids and we're involved in our community, so we tend to socialize around here."

Strange People, Tall Buildings
Psychologists who practice in the suburbs say fear of New York is a common condition among their patients. Fears range from becoming lost or trapped or mugged in the city to being surrounded and suffocated by crowds of strange people and tall buildings. Some patients have been taught by their parents to be wary of the city, and speak of New York as a terrifying foreign land, said Peter S. Kanaris, a Smithtown psychologist who uses various techniques, including relaxation and meditative breathing, to get patients to be able to travel into Manhattan. "When you think of the city, you think of this great diversity of people," Mr. Kanaris said, adding that a typical patient's reaction to that is: "It's a place where I'm going to encounter many types of different people and that feels dangerous to me." 
Beth Wilson, 57, of Amityville, said she has visited the city about 10 times in the past 10 years. Each visit has caused panic attacks, she said, a vertigo that can be relieved only by staring down at the pavement and running "in the direction of Long Island."
"It's a claustrophobic thing," said Mrs. Wilson, a program administrator for Cablevision in Bethpage and a lifelong Long Islander. "I feel like Superman when he has the Kryptonite." 
Nina K. Thomas, a clinical psychologist who practices in Morristown, N.J., said that some suburbanites may become so cloistered that "traveling to Manhattan takes on the air of a major trip, as if to a foreign country."
This is the case for Victoria Linefsky, 44, who has basically avoided New York City since childhood. Mrs. Linefsky, who works part time both in a law office and a preschool, lives in Massapequa, just west of Amityville. The city is an hour's drive to Manhattan in light traffic, but it is worlds away for Ms. Linefsky, who said she has "no clue" how to navigate Manhattan, or even hail a cab. "I don't know my way around," she said. "What's uptown? Downtown? What's a good section?" Her three children, ages 18, 14 and 9, are Long Islanders, and she has no intention of making them New Yorkers. 
"My parents never raised me very culturally," she said. "I've never been to a play in the city. I've never been to Broadway."
Glenville, Conn., said of New York City: "Why would you want to go down there? To pay $6.50 for a beer?" The club charges a decidedly less metropolitan price of $2.25 for a bottle of Budweiser. Mr. Brown, 55, known locally as J. B., is a maintenance worker for the town of Greenwich, but is out on disability. He lives in Byram, Conn., and his last visit to Manhattan occurred about 20 years ago, he said, and that was for his job. 
The bartender, Joseph Salvatore, 61, of Greenwich, said he has only begun visiting the city again in recent years, to take his two young daughters who are learning about Manhattan in school. Mr. Salvatore, a local cemetery caretaker, said before that, he had not been to the city in about 15 years, "and if I wasn't taking them, I wouldn't be going down there." 

The Metropolis in the Backyard
Anti-urban sentiment is not new. After all, the suburbs sprang up largely as an alternative to city life, an escape from crowding, pollution and strangers. Immigrants who came to New York through Ellis Island worked their way from gritty urban tenements to modest, grassy plots in Levittown or New Rochelle. Many of them, and the generations they begot, have never felt the need to look back. 
"I can't tell you how many students I've asked, 'When was the last time you were in the city?' and they've said, 'When I was 5,' " said Gail Satler, a sociology professor at Hofstra University who teaches urban planning and design.
Most of Ms. Satler's students have grown up on Long Island within an hour of the city. But few students were even remotely familiar with New York City, so she began planning class trips into Manhattan to introduce them to the metropolis in their backyard. 
"We were talking about it like it's so far away and it's not," she said. "Unless I make them go, most of them won't." 
In March, the class visited St. Patrick's Cathedral and Times Square.
"Half of them had never seen Central Park," Ms. Satler said. "Some are embarrassed and some are proud. Their attitude is: They've never been in, and they don't have to be." 
For 20 years, Mineola High School in Nassau County, has offered its senior-year students a one-semester class on New York City. The curriculum covers everything from night life to architecture. Students are taken on monthly trips into the city.
Paul Pereira, a social studies teacher, who teaches the class, understands the suburban mindset from firsthand experience. "The only time I went in as a kid is when I went in on a bus for a school trip," he said. "Most of these kids think it's scary and dangerous and dirty like they see in the movies, and that's why we teach the course."
His own parents were from Portugal. "They were happier sending me in my teens the 3,000 miles to see Portugal than sending me 30 minutes on the train to the city," Mr. Pereira said. "A lot of kids pick up stereotypes about the city from their parents who were born and bred here. For them the suburbs equals a better quality of life. But culture's not out in Mineola or Massapequa. It's just lawns and shopping malls and storefronts here. There's no character.
"I get parents coming up and asking, 'Do you offer this class for adults?' Even parents who work in Manhattan, a lot of them just go in and come right out again."

The Suburb to Suburb Commute
Over recent decades, the activity that was once the sole province of New York City has decentralized, allowing people to settle in the suburbs and shun the city, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. 
"The suburbs have become self-contained universes," he said. "There are very few unique things in the city now that suburban people feel they have to access on a regular basis." 
Professor Hughes noted, for example, that in 1950, New York City had 3.4 million jobs, and the state of New Jersey had 1.7 million. But in 2000, New Jersey had 4 million jobs compared to the city's 3.7 million. The trends were similar in Long Island, Westchester and lower Connecticut. 
The proliferation of suburban office parks in the 1980's allowed many commuters to the city to work in the suburbs instead. Mr. Hughes said that the network of office parks in New York's suburbs, including north-central New Jersey, Fairfield County and Stamford in Connecticut, the White Plains area in Westchester, and Route 110 on Long Island has the third largest amount of office space in the country, behind New York City and Chicago.
"The suburbs have really evolved into horizontal cities, replicating the urban market place," Professor Hughes said.
Now most people, he continued, are commuting from one suburb to another. Most people now work in the county in which they live or in an adjacent one. There are now about 50 large regional malls outside Manhattan, accounting for roughly 50 million square feet of retail space. And some New York City dwellers now even travel to the suburbs to shop at big box stores like Ikea in Elizabeth and Home Depot in Yonkers. 

'Everything I Need Is Here'
Some simply stay in the suburbs because of the comforts: the grass, the trees, the space, the privacy -- and the familiarity. 
Patrick Driscoll lives in Millburn, N.J., a half-hour drive from Manhattan. Mr. Driscoll co-owns a bicycle shop in Millburne. His wife, Amy, is pregnant with their third child. Apart from a few business obligations, he has hardly visited the city in the last five years. "I really don't go in any more of my own accord," he said. "The city is just not something we really think about much. I'd rather not deal with that many people. I like a slower environment and having a million people waking around you on the sidewalk, I'd rather be sitting in the backyard in a small town, relaxing." 
Taking the trains can be a deterrent, especially negotiating transfers. "It's not just the people you don't know," he said. "It's a whole system you don't know." 
Suburbanites are used to the privacy of their cars, essential in suburbia but often an impediment to navigating Manhattan, where there are more aggressive drivers and fewer parking spaces. But mass transit looms large as an obstacle to those who don't go regularly to the city. 
Dena Mosiello, 22, a student at Pace University who lives on campus, says she only goes into Manhattan about once a year because 'It's a great place, but there are so many obstacles that stop me from going.'
It is only an hour's drive into downtown Manhattan, she said, but there is often traffic, and she refuses to chance parking her 2002 Jeep Wrangler on most city streets.
"It's very difficult to get there and there's nowhere to park unless you have $30 for a garage," she said. "The last train at night leaves around 1, so you're trapped down there because I'm not leaving a club before 1 a.m."
Many Pace students are more likely to go to the nightclubs in New Rochelle or the bars in Pleasantville or White Plains, and the fear caused by the Sept. 11 attacks has meant even fewer venture into the city.
Ms. Mosiello's father, Alfred Mosiello, lives in Putnam Valley and is a lieutenant in the Pelham Manor Police Department. He goes into Manhattan maybe once a year.
"Manhattan is great if you're into the arts and museums," he said. "It's all down there. I happen to like the wide, open spaces."
"It's got to be in your life style," he said. "There are people living there who wouldn't go anywhere else either."
Burta E. Smith, 70, a retired accountant, lives in Fairfield, Conn., a 75-minute train ride to Grand Central Terminal. She is active (she baby-sits full time) and adventurous (last summer, she drove her car to Texas), but she has visited Manhattan only about four times since she moved to the East Coast in 1991 from the Los Angeles area. Once, she was "bribed" to visit the city with tickets to "Cats," she said, and the other times she agreed to accompany sightseeing relatives.
"I would never go into the city on my own, either by car or train," she said. "I'm really not a city girl. It's nothing personal. I just like my peace and quiet. I have pretty much everything I need here."
Those who do go into the city regularly, just because they want to, not because they work there, are sometimes met with surprise. Geoff Thompson of Briarcliff Manor in Westchester co-owns a public relations firm there whose clients are almost exclusively Westchester businesses. 
Mr. Thompson said he travels regularly into Manhattan to attend New York Rangers games, Broadway shows and films. It never fails to amaze the neighbors, he said. "When I tell them we went into the city, they say, 'Jeez, you did? We haven't gone in for years,' " he said. "I'm always astounded. There are many people who would drive to Cape Cod more readily than drive into the city and see a film. 
"You can see the Manhattan skyline from here, but for many people here, it might as well be the Land of Oz," he said. "It's funny, because so many people in Westchester originally came from New York City, and they talk about it like they moved to Vermont, instead of just Katonah."

HEADLINE: Briefing: Environment; 
DELAWARE DREDGING DELAYED

BYLINE:  By John Sullivan 

 BODY:
 The Army Corps of Engineers has delayed plans to deepen the Delaware River shipping channel because of questions raised about the $377 million project by Congressional investigators. 
The corps said last week that the project was being placed on hold until the questions could be answered. Both the corps and the General Accounting Office declined to disclose the issues that led to the delay, although Homer Perkins, a spokesman for the corps, said they involved "the economics that were used in our study." The corps had intended to deepen the Delaware's channel to 45 feet to accommodate larger ships. Critics have said the plan would cause irreparable environmental damage and little or no economic benefit. John Sullivan

HEADLINE: State Budget Increase Is Really Over 9 Percent 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Governor McGreevey wants to raise more taxes. He is putting the additional burden on business. He also wants to place additional taxes on small businesses operating as flow-through entities (for example, S corporations and limited liability companies). 
The owners of these entities are already paying very high taxes, as evidenced by increases in New Jersey personal income tax collections, which have tripled the rate of inflation over the past decade (92.5 percent compared with 27 percent).
 The governor claims that this year's budget increases spending a mere 1.5 percent by stating that spending for the 2002 fiscal year will end up at $23.32 billion dollars and that 2003 spending will be only $343 million higher at a mere $23.663 billion. That is not true. Included as a line item for Total Resources for 2002 is an item identified as "Lapses." Simply, that is money that is not going to be spent. Hence, at most, only $21.644 billion will be spent for 2002. Thus, the budgeted spending for 2003 is 9.2 percent higher then the amount being spent for this year. 
 Furthermore, even if 2002 is an aberration, the proposals for 2003 are more than 11 percent above the amount budgeted for the 2001 fiscal year, a pace more than double the inflation rate over the past two years. 
So, why does New Jersey need to increase spending nearly two and a half times faster then the rest of us? The answer is that it doesn't. Rather, Governor McGreevey should spend less.

E. MARTIN DAVIDOFF
East Brunswick
