HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Finally, A Good Year To Look Offshore

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE last decade has not been a terrific time to own foreign stocks. 
 From 1992 through 2001, there have been only three years in which foreign stock mutual funds, on average, outperformed diversified stock funds focusing on the United States, according to Morningstar Inc. The most recent was 1999. 
 But so far this year, most foreign markets are doing better than their American counterparts. 
David Bowers, chief global investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, talked last week about the wisdom of investing money offshore. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. In early March, you suggested that foreign stocks were worth a look. Why?

A. The most important reason was valuation. The U.S. looked very expensive. We look at a survey of Merrill Lynch fund managers every month, and in February 62 percent said the United States was the most overvalued equity market in the world.
Even with the drop in the market since then, and the rise overseas, the United States still looks expensive to foreign markets, especially emerging markets. 

Q. Are you worried about the United States market?

A. No, and that is why we did not go to an underweight position.
Until and unless you can make a long-term bear case for U.S. financial stocks relative to the rest of the world, and a bear case for consumer staples and health care, history would say you should not rush to go negative on America. And the performance of what is happening in the financial sector is very, very important. Over the last 25 years, whenever international stocks have done better than American stocks, international financial stocks have done better than U.S. financials. 

Q. What are the prospects for Japan?

A. People are shocked that Japan has outperformed the U.S. so far this year. It is a really interesting situation. We think there are medium-term risks in Japan, but in the short term, if there is any recovery internationally, Japan is a warrant on the synchronized global recovery. But that is a tactical call, not a strategic investment. You don't want to own Japan, you want to rent it.

Q. What are the prospects for Europe?

A. I can see how Europe might benefit as a default call: the United States is too expensive, Japan is too risky, emerging markets are too small. But I don't find it an interesting argument.
There may be some currency benefit, but Europe still has to go through corporate restructuring and other supply-side changes. With elections in France and Germany this year, it is hard to see how you are going to get radical change before those are over. 

Q. Why do you find emerging markets appealing?

A. Emerging markets are an alternative asset that is competing with technology stocks for risk capital. Very few people are making the direct comparison, but we think it is valid. In terms of risk and return, emerging markets and the Nasdaq are similar marketplaces. Ask anybody who has invested in Nasdaq over the last couple of years.
And emerging-market valuations are the most attractive out there. Emerging markets are still trading at only 11 times earnings, versus about 90 times for the Nasdaq composite index. 
What about currency risk? That is nothing compared to what has happened to technology stocks over the last two years. 
We think emerging markets offer opportunity in the short term and the long term: it could take three to four years before the valuation gap between emerging markets and the Nasdaq is substantially narrowed.

Q. Are we near the bottom of the cycle for technology stocks?

A. Our fear is that technology is a long workout. You may get some bounces, but it will be another two to four years before these problems are worked out.
This is the big talking point: How much damage has been done to balance sheets, and how much do I want to pay up for them? 
And you have to distinguish between earnings and profitability. You can get a rebound in technology earnings, but balance sheets take a long time to work out. Going forward, returns on capital are going to be quite low for technology stocks. 
Until we see some of those problems addressed, those who have been investing risk capital in the United States might think about diversifying elsewhere.

Q. What would make you feel better about the prospects for United States markets?

A. If valuations in the United States came down, if the capital spending cycle picked up again and if earnings picked up strongly.
The United States needs to prove that its economic miracle is working. There is still a lot of latent optimism about earnings growth in this country. That could be the case. But at these valuations, it has to be the case.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
The Nanny Is Late. You Have a Speech. What Now?

BYLINE:  By JULIE HALPERT 

 BODY:
ALMOST every working parent has faced the task of finding emergency child care.
 Marcia C. Inhorn remembers all too vividly the quandary she faced six years ago, when her son, then 13 months old, came down with chickenpox. 
 Ms. Inhorn could not miss work but also could not send him to day care. So she toted the feverish toddler in a sling, nursing him as she taught a graduate class in anthropology at Emory University in Atlanta. "It caused a lot of discussion," she said. 
She is spared such problems these days. The University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, where she now teaches, provides backup care for all eligible employees and students. They call a toll-free number, and a child care worker comes to their home.
The university is among a growing number of employers nationwide to offer care, either at home or in centers, when families have emergencies. Some centers, however, do not offer care for sick children.
At least 15 percent of corporations now offer backup care as a perk, according to a recent study by Hewitt Associates. In fact, backup care is considered the fastest-growing part of the child care industry. 
The centers help employers reduce the work hours lost to family emergencies. According to the National Conference on State Legislatures, 80 percent of employees with children miss work at some point because of child care problems.
Law firms, which hate to lose billable hours, were the first to try the idea, and once they demonstrated the savings, other companies followed quickly. Now backup care is offered by all kinds of businesses, from banks to Wall Street firms to retailers. 
Backup centers that care for children up to the age of 12 are considered better investments for employers than full-time centers that care for only very young children, because they help far more employees, said Dr. Susan Ginsberg, who publishes Work and Family Life, a newsletter. In 1988, Dr. Ginsberg helped establish multiemployer backup care in New York City through a group called the Corporate Consortium for Emergency Child Care Services.
GOLDMAN SACHS, which started offering backup care in 1993, says it has seen the benefits. Its centers cost an average of $1 million to build and $720,000 annually to operate. But in 2001 alone, the firm said, the service saved more than 3,500 workdays, or more than $1.3 million.
For J. P. Morgan Chase, the payback comes in more than dollar savings, said Joy Bunson, a senior vice president for human resources. The company's backup program is extensive: it has 14 centers, with three others set to open by next year. In a survey last year, more than 90 percent of employees responding said the program had improved morale and productivity. 
"I'm able to go to work and not have to worry about how my son is doing," said Yolanda Lopez, of Missouri City, Tex., a Chase client-relationship manager who has often used the service for her 10-year-old son.
Corporations typically hire one of a few fast-growing child care companies to run their centers, which are usually at or near the work site. ChildrenFirst Inc. in Boston, for instance, has 250 clients, including Sony, Simon & Schuster, Citigroup, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Lifetime Television and the Massachusetts Medical Society.
Rosemary Jordano, founder of ChildrenFirst, a privately held company, sees a huge need for such services because 70 percent of families rely on care in their own homes or in those of the providers -- the types of care most likely to break down.
To use ChildrenFirst's centers, clients pay annual fees, which might range from $23,000 for a company with up to 100 employees to $264,000 for a 4,000-employee investment bank. For clients, Ms. Jordano said, that is more economical than building a center on site for full-time day care; such a center can cost $4 million to build.
Because backup care can improve productivity, the business is growing even as employers are otherwise cutting costs, said Deborah Dumont, vice president of Aramark Work/Life Partnerships in Philadelphia; it has 30 backup care clients. 
Cindy Lipton, senior vice president of Lipton Corporate Child Care Centers, a private company based in Washington with 250 clients, including The New York Times, said it and rival care providers, like ChildrenFirst and Bright Horizons Family Solutions, could have care centers near one another in New York and all thrive.
Some full-time care centers are also getting into the business. KinderCare, a public company, provides backup care to several clients, including U.S. Cellular, Prudential Insurance and Universal Studios, at 60 of its 1,200 full-time centers.
Bright Horizons, a public company based in Watertown, Mass., runs centers built by its clients. It now operates 33 backup centers, with four more scheduled to open this year, and 25 providing full-time and backup care.
One of its centers is Parke Place Family Center, in Ann Arbor, Mich., serving employees of Pfizer Global Research and Development. The center, designed by Pfizer, is a large, brightly colored space that also offers three playgrounds and provides full-time and backup services.
Most backup care companies lure and keep well-qualified workers with perks like stock options, health benefits, education compensation and profit sharing. Bright Horizons says it has an annual turnover rate of just 10 percent a year for its backup care staff, compared with about 30 to 40 percent in the child care industry. 
Most backup care providers say they aim to keep the ratio of care providers to children low. At ChildrenFirst, for example, there is one care provider for each infant, and ratios of one to four for toddlers, one to six for preschoolers and one to eight for school-age children. Those numbers helped sway Gail Dorn, vice president for community relations at the Target Corporation in Minneapolis, which has started backup care through ChildrenFirst. A mother of five, Ms. Dorn expects to use the service often. Backup care lets parents "relax and focus on their job," she said; the staff has even sent them e-mail photographs of their smiling children during the workday. 
While some centers care for sick children, many, like ChildrenFirst's, do not. Ms. Jordano said parents prefer to take personal days off when their children are ill.
Not everyone has that choice. "We are the option for when you have your back against the wall," said Gail Johnson, who runs Rainbow Station in Richmond, Va., one of many facilities that set aside areas for sick children, cared for by a pediatric nurse.
There are now roughly 350 centers for sick children, said Dr. Jacqueline Stewart, president of the National Association for Sick Child Day Care in Birmingham, Ala., up from 75 eight years ago.
Michele Silbert, a newly separated mother of two young girls in Richmond, was grateful that her new employer, St. Mary's Hospital in Richmond, provided care through Rainbow Station. In her first week on the job, both her children became ill. She dropped them off at Rainbow Station, where they were given medicine, watched videos, took naps and even had chicken soup.
But some employers say children prefer the comforts of home to an unfamiliar center. Harvard University uses Parents in a Pinch in Brookline, Mass. Barbara Marcus, the company's president, relies on part-time workers, including students who go to the employees' homes. Judy Walker, co-manager of work and family at Harvard, said the program had helped attract new faculty members and retain existing employees.
Unlike child care centers, agencies that provide care in a child's home do not require state licensing, according to Pauline D. Koch, executive director of the National Association for Regulatory Administration in St. Paul., so anyone choosing home care needs to be vigilant about qualifications, said Faith Wohl, president of the Child Care Action Campaign in New York, a nonprofit group. The biggest drawback to backup care, she said, is that there is not enough of it.
OTHERS say backup care is not always a perfect solution. Madeline Fried, a principal at Caliber Fried & Sher, a consulting firm in Fairfax, Va., who specializes in child care, said that for children under 4, adjusting to a new center can be "monumental." Ms. Fried says the best solution is a flexible benefits package that allows parents to stay home during child care emergencies. 
Karen Heying, a manager with Child Care Aware in Washington, a program financed by government agencies, said the need for care varies widely among families. The best answer, she said, is a range of options provided by employers.
Citigroup covers many bases, providing full-time and backup care, as well as a service that sends child-care workers to employees' homes. "We realize that one size won't fit all," said Sam Rubino, Citigroup's director of work-life programs. 
To Ms. Inhorn, at the University of Michigan, backup care is the most valuable service her employer could provide, allowing her to perform what she called a "delicate balancing act." "It's not fair to kids to be carried to a work site when they're not feeling well," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alison Hanno, a teacher at ChildrenFirst, a company that provides backup day care, watched children at a center in Minneapolis. (Steve Wewerka for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
The Work Is Temporary, the Memories Lasting

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
For bosses, temporary workers can be a boon or a burden. For temps themselves, their jobs can be a bother or a blessing, and even a movable feast.
 "The company I work for has had nothing but bad luck with temps for years," writes an administrative assistant for a civil engineering and surveying company in the Northeast. As an example, she recalls a temp hired last summer. 
 "We had a nice, personable young woman," she writes. "All she had to do for two weeks was answer the phone and type any simple items people gave her. When she left, we discovered some very interesting things about her.
"According to other employees, she had complained she was bored, but she never asked her supervisor for anything to do. She got annoyed when people asked her to do things because, apparently, they interfered with chatting online and over the phone with her friends. 
"Then we discovered she had been using the company e-mail to talk to her friends and hadn't deleted any of them. Her supervisor and I decided to read some of them. Were we in for a surprise!
"Not only did she have a bizarre, slightly chilling personal life, but, on more than one occasion, she told her friends she wanted to kill certain people in the office. Some of the e-mails were in a language neither I nor the supervisor know. It was a little frightening since we didn't know if she was capable of acting upon her comments (not to mention we didn't have a clue what she said in the foreign-language ones). The supervisor printed some of them and sent them to the temp agency.
"Obviously, we specifically asked that she not be sent to us again."
Until the early 1990's, Barrett Newman, now the assistant general manager of the Warner Theater in Washington, was what he calls a member of the legion of temps, specializing in short-term assignments and racking up more than 60 in just a couple of years. Either because of a desire to diet or a perpetual lack of money, he found himself going through his workdays without eating lunch or even leaving the building, which sometimes led to accolades for his businesslike work style.
But then he began to notice the free food at his various jobs. Cheap danish pastries brought in on Fridays. The occasional birthday cake. The tea. The hot chocolate. One large law firm kept an extensive stock of sodas, juices, soups and other food.
But weren't temps like Mr. Newman second-class citizens, not entitled to partake? He finally decided to seize the day. 
He had stumbled into what he described at the time as "a voraciously satisfying culinary experience." There was the going-away party for a longtime employee -- or maybe it was a return party or a maternity party -- that yielded pasta salads, ziti, a deli platter, assorted sides and desserts. Holidays brought wonderful buffets and edible "tokens of appreciation" that the secretarial corps was happy to devour. 
One company had an informal staff party on the first Friday of every month, with beer, wine, sandwich platters, chips and cookies. Mr. Newman became so experienced at blending into the background as a quiet temp that he returned to sample the feast even after his week-and-a-half assignment ended.
During this period of his life, he concluded his thoughts on the temp and free food by writing:
"Perhaps the free-food concept is turning into an obsession. I now subconsciously decide whether I like an assignment or not based on food quality and availability. Now, if I could only find a way to get free exercise club privileges."
"Several years ago, I had a very bright young man temping for me," writes Annmarie Bavosa, the director for contract purchasing and supplier diversity for Merck-Medco in Franklin Lakes, N.J. "However, each morning I would have to retrain him on the activities of the department.
"After a week or so, I said: 'Henry, you're such a smart guy. Why is it that you don't remember what we do from one day to the next'
"His reply: 'I'm a temp. I'm not paid to retain.' "
In the recession in the early 1990's, the company that for 14 years had employed Jerry Niemeier of Bayside, Queens, as manager of financial planning and analysis sold his division to another company. After the sale, Mr. Niemeier was told he was a permanent employee. 
"However, permanent lasted for only eight months," he writes. "As with a lot of people at the time, it was difficult to find a new job." 
As part of his efforts to find work, Mr. Niemeier registered with several temp agencies.
"What a shock to need to be tested after spending 14 years in corporate financial planning and analysis, four years with a major C.P.A. firm, which meant I had passed the C.P.A. exam," he writes.
"That was with the 'accounting' temp firms. I also registered with a 'technical' temp agency.
After three months, it was the technical agency that called to ask if he knew anything about forecasting and planning, because a company was looking for someone to help it in that area.
Mr. Niemeier went for the interview, thinking temp. But the interviewer began talking about benefits and vacation and Mr. Niemeier began pitching himself as a full-time employee.
He was hired as a temp, for six months. Several people worked for him. He provided guidance. He handed out raises. When the six months had passed, Mr. Niemeier was no longer a temp. He had become an employee.
He writes: "The lesson learned was, never treat an interview as a temp interview but look for the ultimate hiring as an employee.
"Today I am still with the company where I started as a temp and doing better than I would have been doing if I was retained by the old company."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Ronald Baron; 
Baron Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
RONALD BARON pays little attention to brokerage firms' research when he picks stocks for his $948 million Baron Growth fund.
 "It doesn't make sense to invest money based on widely publicized recommendations of big investment firms that seem to arrive at the same conclusions at the same time based on the same information," Mr. Baron said from his office in Manhattan. 
 Such recommendations are often based on earnings reports that beat or missed analysts' estimates by a single penny in a calendar quarter, he said, or on estimates -- unknowable in his view -- of interest rates, inflation and economic growth. 
In choosing stocks, Mr. Baron estimates that he and the 14 analysts who work with him on the fund spend about 25 percent of their time traveling, to research potential purchases. "We try to understand the prospects for the business by talking to customers, competitors and suppliers," he said.
He has no patience for the complex accounting practices revealed in the recent collapse of Enron. He has a rule of thumb: "The more lengthy the required disclosures, the more difficult to understand, the less interesting the investment."
The fund returned 10.4 percent a year, on average, in the three years through Thursday, compared with an average of 7.9 percent for its group of funds that invest in small growth stocks and a loss of 10 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 21.6 percent in the last 12 months, versus a loss of 1.1 percent for its group and a 5.8 percent decline in the S.& P. 500.
Mr. Baron, 58, is the chief executive of Bamco Inc., the fund's adviser and a unit of the Baron Capital Group, which manages about $6.5 billion for institutions and individuals. He also runs the $3 billion Baron Asset fund.
He chooses the roughly 75 issues in Baron Growth among fast-growing, profitable American companies with market values of less than $1.5 billion at the time of purchase.
"We look for unique, well-managed businesses that have huge opportunities created by megatrends," he said. He defines these as long-term social and economic trends, including the growth of for-profit education and the aging of the American population.
When he finds companies positioned to benefit from long-term trends, he buys -- and then tends to hold on. The fund's annual turnover rate is just 20 percent, compared with 132 percent for all small growth funds, Morningstar said.
He tries to buy companies with a long-term competitive advantage -- ideally, one that lets the company double in size over the next three to five years. Because such advantages are rare among technology companies, he said, the fund owns no tech stocks.
To value companies, Mr. Baron takes into account their price-to-earnings multiples, using projected earnings over the next four or five years. His goal is to double his money over five years.
The fund's biggest holding is ChoicePoint, at 4.5 percent of total assets. The company, based in Alpharetta, Ga., provides identification and credential verification services for insurers and other companies; it has also been testing a way to prescreen frequent fliers to expedite their time at airports. 
The company will continue to benefit, he said, from businesses' need to screen potential employees and to identify other security risks, he said.
He started buying the stock in August 1997, and has paid an average of $19.65 a share, adjusted for splits. It now trades at $55.85. 
Mr. Baron began buying shares of University of Phoenix Online in September 2000. A division of the University of Phoenix, it offers 11 accredited degree programs in business, education, information technology and nursing for working adults. Enrollment has tripled, to 36,000, in the last two years, he said, and he expects it to exceed 100,000 in 2003.
He paid an average of $18.09 for the shares, adjusted for splits. The most recent occurred on Friday. The stock trades at $30.74.
AFTER Sept. 11, Mr. Baron added shares of Vail Resorts in Colorado and Sun International Hotels Ltd. in the Bahamas. The two resort operators were both adversely affected by the decline in travel after the terrorist attacks, he said, but he now expects them to benefit from an older, more affluent American population. Aside from its skiing business, he said, Vail is becoming popular as a summer resort. Sun International manages casinos as well as hotels. 
He originally bought Vail Resorts shares in February 1997, and has paid an average of $18.36 a share; the stock now trades at $19.60. He started buying Sun in February 1996. He has paid $24.69, on average; the stock closed on Friday at $28.33.

HEADLINE: Find Home, Sweet Home, At the New Haute Gym 

BYLINE:  By GEORGE EPAMINONDAS 

 BODY:
ON a spring afternoon, Johnna Cummings was basking next to a gas-fired hearth at Clay, on West 14th Street in Manhattan, and leafing through The Face magazine. That Ms. Cummings, 32, a full-time student, chose a gym as a place to relax, drink espresso, watch CNN on a plasma screen television and answer e-mail messages is hardly surprising. Fitness clubs have morphed into ersatz homes, and their luxury services have become as much a selling point as their styles of yoga.
 "Clay is a place where you can work out and chill out," said Ms. Cummings, who spent four hours there that day, including the time she devoted to free weights and the treadmill. The former lead singer of a 90's pop group, Boy Krazy, Ms. Cummings has an Upper East Side apartment and a downtown pied-a-terre, but she prefers Clay. "It's intensely beautiful and aesthetically relaxing," she said. 
 A lifetime ago, gyms were the kind of spartan caves where Rocky Balboa would sweat it out with a punching bag. In the 1980's they became sleek health clubs populated with endless rows of Nautilus machines. In the 1990's, they added spas and juice bars. And now the newest sybaritic clubs are revved up with services such as dog walking, car washing, Botox injections and full-service restaurants. The add-ons will cost you, of course; most clubs bill extra for supplying the comforts of home away from home. 
Think of anything a luxury hotel will do, or a bevy of in-line servants, and a health club somewhere will offer the same. At the Sports Club/LA at Rockefeller Center, you can have your hair blown out ($65), your face treated with blue sea algae ($125), and then enjoy a "healing Thai chicken soup" ($8) at Pulse, the on-site Drew Nieporent restaurant.
Megagyms like the Sports Club/LA, a national chain, and Western Athletic Clubs, with branches in California and Washington, pull out all the stops. One locker-room attendant at the Sports Club/LA in Los Angeles remembers being handed a torn Tracey Feith skirt and being asked to mend it. (She did.) One woman stood naked in the locker room of the upscale East Bank Club in Chicago and asked the club's takeout restaurant to cater a dinner party for eight people. That night. (They did.)
The health club industry's research shows that members tend to work more overtime than average, which suggests why clubs offering overscheduled people one-stop shopping would have a strong appeal. At the tony Houstonian club in Houston, members can ask a travel agent to research a cycling trip to the Amalfi Coast while they're clocking miles on a stationary bike. At East Bank last month, Smashbox's spring make-up line was being showcased in the women's locker rooms, while the pro shop was staging a trunk show of vintage jewelry.
At most branches of the Sports Club/LA and Western Athletic clubs, it is now expected that cars will be washed and detailed by a valet while members work out. A cleaner will take care of laundry. And a concierge will snag tickets to a show.
Upping the ante, at Clay in New York, where orchids are deployed as though it were a Calvin Klein flagship store, a nutritionist will go to your home and replenish your pantry with healthy food, and a private chef will instruct you in the art of cooking an organic vindaloo. "I wanted to create a place where people can be nurtured," said Robin Brown, a co-founder of Clay. Ms. Brown even plans to give dinner parties for club members in her TriBeCa loft. 
Clay charges an initiation fee of $500 and monthly fees of $140 for basic services; spa, nutritional and concierge services are extra, billed to members' accounts. An executive membership at the Sports Club/LA, the top-of-the-line package, has a $1,575 joining fee and monthly charge of $265. The fee includes personalized laundry service and access to all of the gyms around the country.
Laura Aviva, 31, an events organizer who recently joined Clay, her first club, said, "I live in a tiny apartment, and the fact that they're trying to create a sense of community appealed to me." 
For years, health clubs have tantalized single people with the prospect that they might lock eyes across the rows of Stairmasters. Now they can pursue an entire courtship on premises. Jan Evans Richardson, 50, an advertising account executive and former actress, met her boyfriend, Danny Mulligan, 57, a real estate agent, by the Houstonian's pool. They followed with drinks at the Gazebo bar (at the club), dinner at the Center Court Cafe (also on premises), and soon enough, a love match was made. Now they play tennis together there and attend luncheon seminars organized by the club (Barbara Bush is the keynote speaker tomorrow). "Instead of going out on a date Saturday night we might sit by the pool, take a Jacuzzi and look up at the stars," Ms. Richardson said.
Hobnobbing is as important as crunching at the Pacific Athletic Club in Redwood City, Calif., too. It offers ski excursions to Lake Tahoe, wine trips to the Napa Valley and whale watching on Half Moon Bay. The club has a shuttle bus to ferry members on outings, and a 175-seat banquet room. Tom Cruise once staged a birthday party on the basketball court of the Sports Club/LA in Los Angeles.
Is there anything the club won't do in the name of indulgence? 
"Illegal things," said Nanette Pattee Francini, a co-founder of the Sports Club/LA. "And we don't bathe our members; they need to shower themselves."
Architecture and design are used as drawing cards, just as they are for the new Prada store or a boutique hotel. Dodd Mitchell, who designed the restaurants Balboa, Sushi Roku and Katana in Los Angeles, gave the Body and Soul gym there bamboo ceilings, calming water fountains and sleek stone showers. 
Stylistically, a schism exists between clubs that mine baroque themes (the kind of interiors that might be found on an Aristotle Onassis yacht) and those that evoke a downtown, pared-down aesthetic. In the latter camp is the new Equinox, which has touches like industrial plastic that resembles satin for the reception desk, brushed steel pendant lights and iridescent tiles by the pool. "We want to create locker rooms that are more beautiful than people's bathrooms at home, juice bars that are prettier than their kitchens, and spa services people even in the upper markets can't have in their apartments," said Paul Boardman, Equinox's executive vice president. The New York chain opened a gym in Pasadena, Calif., last year and has more planned, for Chicago and Los Angeles. 
Some people are as picky about gym decor as they are about their workout regimes. Alan Orenbuch, 47, a New York architect, switched from what he called ugly gyms to Clay -- based on the renderings alone. "Have you seen the sink details?" he asked. "They really know what they're doing."
For all their domestic flourishes, you still can't sleep in the clubs. But, guests at Ritz-Carlton or Four Seasons hotels in San Francisco, Washington and Boston have access to an adjacent Sports Club/LA. Conceivably, they could nap between hip-hop aerobics classes and an oxygen facial.
The list of added services is potentially as endless as the need to compete with one another. Might health clubs add dating services? Perhaps religious services so members can be married there too? 
The symbiosis between spas and gyms, already well-advanced in many cities, would suggest that comprehensive medical services are the next growth area. "You already have clubs delivering post-surgery rehab, cardiac rehabilitation and minor outpatient plastic surgery," said Bill Howland, research director for the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association. Ahead of the trend, the Marsh, an integrated fitness center and medical clinic in Minnetonka, Minn., opened 17 years ago with an on-site cardiologist and acupuncturist. More recently, it has expanded to include pre- and post-operative rehabilitation, as well as consulting cardiologists, physiatrists and neurologists.
"People are tired of specialization," said Ruth Stricker, the founder of the Marsh. "They're looking more for a manager or somebody to listen and put it together."
Considering all the roles they play, it is perhaps not so astonishing to find that health club memberships are rarely the first thing to be dropped in unsettled economic times. For upwardly mobile types who could not get through a week without Power Pilates, forgoing exercise would be a sign of failure. "When we hit a recession, their membership isn't the first to go -- it's their house," said Ms. Francini of the Sports Club/LA.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Road to Nevada 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Nuclear Waste on the Highways" (editorial, April 21):
 Let the country be forewarned: what awaits is a potential nightmare if we allow the Energy Department and the nuclear power industry to ship high-level nuclear waste to Yucca Mountain. 
 Over a 30-year period, we can expect and make emergency preparations for several hundred accidents in any of 43 states, at a cost to local and state governments of billions of dollars.
Worse yet, what if there is a terrorist strike? Our worst nuclear nightmares would be realized, creating an American Chernobyl.
A disaster could affect an area of about 40 square miles with contamination. Many would die. A local economy would be shattered. Cleanup in an urban area could cost $2 billion. Is it really worth it? 

OSCAR B. GOODMAN
Mayor
Las Vegas, April 25, 2002

HEADLINE: Where the Jobs Are 

BYLINE:  By JENNY LYN BADER; Jenny Lyn Bader is a playwright and essayist.

 BODY:
WHILE numbers may not lie, the people who crunch them sure do. It's harder than it looks. So one job sector keeps growing even as unemployment rises. In an age of accounting scandals, number-crunchers are needed more than ever. Just look at this sampling of recent classified ads: 
 CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER. 
M.B.A., C.P.A. Must be able to report one earnings figure while simultaneously looking at another; massage numbers; lobby; move debt off books; rally stockholders; defer income to a later quarter till the end of time. Ability to name holding companies after birds of prey and action figures a plus. Should be on intimate terms with at least one cabinet member, reachable in one phone call or less and known to you as "sweetie." 5-10 yrs. experience in keeping two sets of books.
 OLYMPIC JUDGE. B.A., N.H.L.
Requires working knowledge of international relations and ice-skating contortions, ability to distinguish a triple axel from falling on the floor sideways, a firm grasp of the numbers 1 through 6. Demonstrated fluency in decimal system and in much higher math, where two gold medals can equal one. Fees and kickbacks negotiable.
CORPORATE SALES, TELECOMMUNICATIONS. B.A. in literature preferred. Creativity essential. Ability to book profits to invented companies, create swaps for imaginary services, hire fictional characters. Proficiency in arranging Illusory Public Offerings (I.P.O.'s) required.
PROFESSOR. University seeks Ph.D. aware of national grade inflation, able to give "C" paper an "A-" without grumbling. Compensation: educating new generation of number-crunchers.
ELECTION OFFICIAL. Why not use your counting talents where it counts? Background in voting booth arcana, indecipherable handwriting, mediation. In case of electoral dispute between two political candidates, official should be able to show in rigorous detail that either one was victorious, but not until months later.
FINANCIAL ANALYST. B.A. or B.S. Investment bank seeks individual able to perform business with a company in the morning, recommend said company's stock that afternoon and have a nice chat with New York's attorney general that evening.
CHILD MENSA PERFORMER.
Needed: High-I.Q. moppet to go on talk shows, attend graduate seminars and perform math tricks at parties. Child should appear utterly childlike, with wan expression and working knowledge of Fermat's theorem. Preferably conversant in Schopenhauer, with mussed hair and the vague light of genius in eyes. Parent should show that child scored 145 or higher on I.Q. test. Barring that, parent may add I.Q. scores of whole family and pretend that sum is child's I.Q. Mental health insurance not available for child or parent.
AUCTION HOUSE DIRECTOR. 
M.F.A. Should possess wide-ranging knowledge of paintings and antiquities, and of people at other auction houses. No ex-convicts please.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
For Real Estate, a Levitation Act

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO 

 BODY:
INVESTORS who made big bets on real estate two years ago may be feeling smug these days. 
 Real estate investment trusts, known as REIT's, have risen more than 50 percent from their low point in March 2000, according to the Morgan Stanley REIT index. By comparison, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down about 20 percent over the period. 
 While REIT's may not repeat such outperformance in the months ahead, they remain a good way to diversify a portfolio, many analysts say. REIT's own and operate income-producing real estate and must pay most of their earnings to shareholders, so they tend to distribute steady dividends. Because of that income stream, they should be considered as alternatives to bonds, according to Steve Sakwa, a senior real estate analyst at Merrill Lynch. 
"I think people that own bonds probably have to consider whether they want to own REIT's over the long term," he said. The group's current dividend yield is near 6.4 percent, according to Mr. Sakwa. By comparison, 10-year Treasury issues yielded 5.05 percent on Friday.
REIT shares trade like stocks but tend not to follow the market's path. They often outperform the market in tough times -- as they have recently -- but may decline when the stock market is strong. Like bonds, REIT's are sensitive to shifts in interest rates and may stumble when rates rise. 
Lee Rosenberg, a financial planner in Jericho, N.Y., said he expects REIT share prices to level off in coming months, "as they come closer to fair value," but he favors them for portfolio diversification. He said he was "cautiously" allocating about 5 percent of client portfolios to real estate, down from about 10 percent two years ago. 
Dee Lee, a financial planner in Harvard, Mass., said most people might be better off in real estate-focused mutual funds instead of individual REIT's, because the funds provide more diversification.
Investors who don't want to pay a manager to find the best choice, however, may begin by examining whether a particular REIT trades at a discount or premium to the value of the real estate it holds. After that, many real estate fund managers recommend examining whether the cash flow from its properties has increased over time. 
Many REIT's that own office properties trade at a 5 percent premium to net assets, said Douglas L. Barton, portfolio manager of the Franklin Real Estate Securities fund. That is half the premium for REIT's over all, including those that own shopping malls or apartment complexes, Mr. Barton said. 
He said the office sector would be in better shape coming out of this recession than it was after the downturn of the early 1990's because there is not as much oversupply this time. Nevertheless, he predicted that once the economy picked up, "it might take nine months to a year for existing office spaces to fill up with employees." 
The highest vacancy rates are in high-technology regions like Northern California, Seattle and suburban Boston, he said. 
HIS top pick is Midtown Manhattan, where the holdings of SL Green Realty, one of his favorites, are heavily concentrated. The company trades at about a 10 percent premium to net assets, he said, much higher than his estimate of 5 percent for office REIT's in general. But, he said, "we're looking for much higher growth rates from that company than from other office properties."
Mr. Barton estimated that cash flow from operations at SL Green would grow about 9 percent in both 2002 and 2003, compared with 5 percent to 6 percent for the overall office sector in 2002 and 6 percent to 7 percent in 2003. SL Green closed at $34.35 on Friday, up 11.9 percent this year.
Last month, SL Green sealed a deal to buy a Times Square building, 1515 Broadway, where Viacom is the major tenant. Stephen L. Green, SL Green's chairman, said he considered it a "core building" that would remain in the portfolio a long time.
The deal is notable because most REIT managers are delaying acquisitions until they gain confidence in the economic recovery, said Samuel Lieber, chief executive of Alpine Management and Research, which advises three real estate mutual funds. 
In the early 1990's, REIT managers gobbled up distressed properties dumped on the market by the ailing savings and loan industry, sometimes assuming heavy debt. After peaking in 1997 at premiums of 30 percent to 35 percent, shares in REIT's plunged in 1998 and spent two years in the doldrums. 
Mr. Lieber said he didn't expect a similar bust this time because premiums had not climbed as high. "I think REIT's will grow into their premiums," he said.
Vornado Realty Trust leads Mr. Lieber's list of office REIT's. Vornado operates in New York and Washington, both strong markets. Shares in Vornado closed at $43.78 on Friday, up 5.2 percent this year.
Other investors recommend Mack-Cali and Boston Properties, largely because of their concentration in the Northeast. Mack-Cali has office properties in New Jersey that benefited from the dislocation of New York companies after Sept. 11. Boston Properties is the nation's second-largest office REIT, after Equity Office Properties. Mack-Cali closed at $32.79 on Friday, up 5.7 percent this year. Boston Properties closed at $38.37 on Friday, up 1 percent this year.
SIZE does not necessarily confer advantages when the economy is struggling. The performance of Equity Office Properties, with 774 office properties in 23 states and the District of Columbia, has lagged behind that of its peer group since last fall, even though it became the first REIT to join the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, in October of last year. Two others have since been added. Inclusion in the index often bolsters a company's share price because many portfolios must invest in the index companies.
But the market has reacted negatively to the implications of the company's purchase of Spieker Properties, which has office properties in Silicon Valley, Seattle and Portland, Ore., all hurt by the tech decline.
In February 2001, Equity Office said it expected the Spieker acquisition to add 10 cents a share to its annual funds from operations, a common yardstick of REIT earnings. In response, Merrill Lynch increased its estimate for Equity Office's 2002 earnings by 10 cents a share, to $3.60. But Merrill now estimates that the REIT will earn $3.19 a share this year, including a nonrecurring 10 cents a share in the first quarter when Sun Microsystems paid a fee to break a lease. "Clearly, the Spieker acquisition created trouble for them in Northern California," Mr. Sakwa said.
Samuel Zell, Equity Office's chairman, said the deal would pay off in the long run.
Equity Office is undergoing a management shake-up. Mr. Zell assumed the added title of chief executive on April 19 after the departure of Timothy H. Callahan. In addition, the company does not have a full-time chief financial officer. 
Equity Office intends to fill both positions, and Mr. Zell says the company remains strong under his leadership. "I'm not exactly a rookie in this business," he said.
Last week, a REIT went public for the first time in three years. Shares of that REIT, Heritage Property Investment Trust, closed at $25 on Friday, the price set before trading began on Wednesday. "This is not a fabulously sexy company with great properties," Mr. Lieber said. "The fact that they were able to take it public, and even expand the size of the deal, is a positive sign for REIT's."

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
Talk in Your Sleep? Is the Radio Listening?

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
AT a time when headlines seem focused on pedophile priests, Enron and the economy, and terrorism and the Middle East, it would be easy to forget the technology revolution of the 1990's. Was it all a bizarre dream? 
 A new book by Richard Hunter, "World Without Secrets: Business, Crime and Privacy in the Age of Ubiquitous Computing" (Wiley, $27.95), is a sharp reminder that the technologies of the 90's are still being deployed rapidly. The collapse of dot-coms and the decline in high-technology stocks -- as well as all the other recent distractions -- have not halted a march toward a time when people are surrounded by computers, sensors, transmitters and cameras linked to extensive networks and databases. 
 Mr. Hunter, vice president and director of research for applications development at Gartner, a research group in Stamford, Conn., has a sweeping view of how this technology is unfolding, altering American society and playing out on the world stage. 
The book could have used more editing. Readers may grow weary of the italics (in some places, it seems that nearly every other word is italicized) and the repetition of material like "Hunter's Laws," a set of assertions by the author. How many times do we need reminders that "the network is an amplifier" and "when everything is known, no one knows everything"?
But the book is important -- it contains fresh thinking, a rarity these days. Imperfections in style can be forgiven.
The book offers many examples of how this new era is already invading our privacy, and in ways we haven't fully grasped. Amazon.com has altered its privacy policies to allow it to share information about customers with companies that want to sell goods and services to them. Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, did not start out doing business that way.
Using software from Visionics, the city of Tampa, Fla., has linked a database of photographs of suspected criminals with a network of cameras deployed in one nightlife district, invoking shades of Big Brother. When will the entire nation be rigged with tiny computer cameras scanning our faces?
On other fronts, Acme Rent-a-Car in New Haven equipped its vehicles with global positioning satellite systems and was able to monitor a customer as he exceeded the speed limit three times. Acme fined the customer, James Turner of New Haven, and drained the money from his credit cards before he knew what had happened. He went to court and won, but the episode showed how technology can be used for snooping in the home, the office and the automobile.
MR. HUNTER is right to argue that if Americans aren't involved in resolving these issues, the issues will be resolved without them. "The amount of electronically stored data about individuals is massive, detailed, and growing," the author writes. He adds: "We don't yet know how to manage a world in which everything can be linked to me, wherever I am."
Perhaps Mr. Hunter's most intriguing idea is that of the "network army." Such a group is similar to an old-fashioned grass-roots movement, he says, except that it is international (not limited by geography) and its members may have different agendas. Relying on the Internet, they come together to exert broad influence on a shared concern.
As explained by Mr. Hunter, this is a new kind of social, political and business structure. The world has already watched network armies on the attack at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle and the Group of Eight meeting in Genoa, Italy, and in the continuing fight by teenagers and college students against the music industry over the rights to recordings -- whether through Napster or somewhere elsewhere.
The network army examined in the most depth, however, is the Open Source movement, a loose coalition of 750,000 software programmers worldwide. Using the Internet, they contribute their software free to whoever wants it.
One significant product of the Open Source movement has been the Linux operating system, which is free and poses a challenge to Microsoft and other companies that sell software. Some Open Source programmers regard Microsoft as an evil empire.
Intriguingly, the army of the Open Source movement doesn't have a general. It has four important "influencers," like Linus Torvald, the developer of Linux, who may shape broad agendas but can't control people who aren't paid.
Below the influencers are six to eight distributors of the software and more than 200 project leaders, who manage the 750,000 true believers. "The ratio between leaders and followers is astronomically high by the standards of any business and is increasing rapidly," Mr. Hunter writes. "A key enabling factor is the use of Internet-based communications, which allows 'influencers' and other important members of the movement to transmit their messages accurately, with zero distortion, to a potentially infinite number of followers."
Microsoft drafted internal documents about how to deny the Open Source movement access to the market, Mr. Hunter writes. Microsoft's critics in the Open Source movement responded by accusing the company of attempting to choke them off, just as Microsoft had been accused of trying to kill Netscape in the Internet browser business. This time, Microsoft's power won't work as well, because the Open Source movement has few generals and few guns. There is no way to reason with it, no way to negotiate with it, and no way to take it to court, at least in the traditional sense. 
One conclusion: "Whatever you do, don't make yourself the cause that unites a network army," Mr. Hunter warns.
Just as Microsoft has a problem with a network army, so, too, does the United States. Mr. Hunter argues that Al Qaeda is an organism that the United States, an "engineered society," hasn't encountered in recent times. "Like the network army, their value systems are various, intersecting on one or more planes (for example, opposition to Israel or the United States) where they exercise significant power," the author writes. "They're international and are united by ideology, not geography."
HOW DOES authority respond to a new creature that operates by different values and systems? With its own network army, Mr. Hunter writes. He offers the example of the New York Electronic Crimes Task Force, created by the Secret Service. The Secret Service doesn't control or dominate the task force in a traditional bureaucratic sense, but rather tries to create a give-and-take among law enforcement agencies, telecommunications companies, academic experts and whoever else has expertise. Altogether, it has more than 150 members and operates as a network army combating perceived wrongdoers on several continents.
Such a task force also illustrates a major theme of the book: for the United States and other "engineered societies" to battle people using the newest technologies to pursue the oldest hatreds, they must redefine how institutions work together.
Mr. Hunter is sometimes irritating in his writing style. But he is always provocative. He gathers impressions and conversations from a surprisingly broad array of sources. He assembles this material into something approaching a coherent whole.
He mentions that "the medium is the message" without referring explicitly to Marshall McLuhan, who invented that concept. But Mr. Hunter is correct in saying that the Internet and associated technologies are a medium that is changing our world order. It is changing how people live and define their boundaries.
The availability of cheap, instantaneous and global communications is having an impact, for example, on mass opinion. Increasingly, Mr. Hunter contends, the world is seeing more fragmentation of viewpoint. Opinions are becoming deeper, narrower and more geographically distributed. Insights like that are well worth the price of admission to "World Without Secrets."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Surveillance technologies are becoming more pervasive, a new book says. Detective Bill Todd Jr., back, used a video system that monitors streets in a nightlife district of Tampa, Fla., an example in the book. (Jim Stern for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Why the Cardinals Kept Mum

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
IN 1963, Cardinal Bernard F. Law was a newly ordained priest in Jackson, Miss., denouncing segregation in the diocesan newspaper. Cardinal Roger M. Mahony was a parish priest in Fresno, Calif., serving mass at dawn to migrant farm workers. Cardinal William H. Keeler was a 32-year-old aide at the Second Vatican Council, helping to usher the Roman Catholic Church into modern times.
 The aging church leaders now trying to atone for their past handling of sex abuse cases were once bold and forward-thinking. They had entered the priesthood in the golden age of American Catholicism, a time when the church was at its most assimilated and respected. In those days, Catholic teaching on equality and social justice meshed with the conscience of the nation, and they, like many young priests, saw themselves as pioneers in a new age of idealism. 
 Their confidence was checked once the cultural revolution of 1968 began emptying seminaries and opening rifts over the church's teaching on sexuality and birth control. By then, Cardinal Law and his peers were on a management track -- and on the defensive. 
This could be another reason why so many church leaders ignored or concealed sexual abuse cases. They were so busy fending off hostile forces in society, that they neglected to root out the enemy within.
What happened to the Catholic Church in the late 60's was a bit like what the American military experienced when public opinion turned against the Vietnam War: its aura of unassailable authority crumbled. The cracks became obvious in 1968, when Pope Paul VI issued an encyclical, Humanae Vitae, reasserting the church's condemnation of contraceptives. It became a lightning rod for all the divisions simmering within the church -- separating papal loyalists from dissenting clergy, many ordinary Catholics and large segments of society.
Cardinal Law and others who became priests when the church was at the peak of its prestige suddenly felt under siege.
"There was this dream among many of us that we were going to be integral parts of a new society, that we were in the vanguard of social and economic justice," said the Rev. Frank P. Lane, 62, a vice rector of the Pontifical College Josephinum in Columbus, Ohio. "Then these other moral issues surfaced, abortion, divorce, sexual liberation, that brought back that old sense of separation."
As some of the best priests left the church to marry or explore other kinds of freedom, those who remained were charged with protecting the church, its moral teachings and its reputation. The most loyal defenders were rewarded with promotions. All 13 living American cardinals were appointed by John Paul II, and most of them also received their bishops' miters from this pope.
Like the generation of men who grew up with one expectation of a wife's role, only to be confounded by the women's movement, this generation of cardinals was prepared for a far more docile, supportive laity. Their shock when their flock grew defiant was compounded by the fact that they viewed their status as literally God-given.
The impulse to circle the wagons and fend off scrutiny, on the other hand, was all too human. "For that generation, the diocese is like a family business -- Uncle Charlie may be incompetent but you can't fire Uncle Charlie and you can't fire a priest," said Rev. Thomas J. Reese, editor of the Jesuit magazine America. "Somewhere along the line some of them forgot that parents and their kids are also part of the family."
They are the pre-Vatican II generation, born in the 1920's and 30's, when anti-Catholic prejudice was evident (the Ku Klux Klan rose up against Alfred E. Smith's 1928 presidential campaign), but also when a priest's authority was absolute in his community.
In a recent essay bemoaning laxity in the church, the Rev. James A. Kelly, 86, founder of the Fellowship of Catholic Scholars, recalled somewhat nostalgically what it was like to be a priest in America when he was young. "By World War I the Catholic pastor was the lord of his neighborhood with lifelong tenure," he wrote.
By the time Cardinal Law and his peers entered seminaries in the 1950's, the non-Catholic world was almost as deferential. Movies starring Bing Crosby, Spencer Tracy and Pat O'Brien as priests shaped popular culture. So did Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, whose TV show was one of the most popular of the 1950's, competing with Milton Berle.
Back then, priestly celibacy seemed admirable even to non-Catholics. "Celibacy for he-men like O'Brien and Tracy is clearly an act of massive self-discipline," Charles R. Morris wrote in his book "American Catholic: The Saints and Sinners who Built America's Most Powerful Church," "but one that confers an earned righteousness that sets them apart from other men."
Catholicism blended well with the anti-Communism and the churchgoing ethos of the Eisenhower era. Congress declared "In God we Trust" the national motto in 1956, the same year Cardinal Adam J. Maida was ordained a priest in Pittsburgh, Pa.
In 1960, President John F. Kennedy was elected. Catholics were almost as triumphant a few months later when John Courtney Murray, a Jesuit philosopher, was put on the cover of Time magazine. (He was considered more important than an exclusive piece on the making of the movie "Cleopatra" with Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, which ran inside.)
In 1962, the year Cardinal Mahony was ordained and Cardinal Edward M. Egan was studying in Rome, John XXIII summoned his bishops to the Vatican for the first such meeting since the Vatican Council of 1869, when Pius IX cemented papal infallibility into church doctrine.
"The Americans strode into the Vatican Council II like they owned the place -- they thought the American church was a model for Europe" said Francis Russell Hittinger, a professor of Catholic Studies at the University of Tulsa, explaining the confidence and moral certainty of those times. "The mindset of that generation was so optimistic, there was not a cloud in the sky."
CARDINAL Law and his colleagues had finished their studies for the priesthood long before the theological dissent and social change of the late 60's and 70's invaded the seminaries. When they studied for the priesthood, those topics were taboo.
"There was this unspoken fear of homosexuality," recalled Reverend Lane, who in 1961 entered a seminary that was later closed as vocations dwindled. "As a result, we were very controlled -- we were not allowed to visit each other's rooms, we were seldom allowed off campus, we couldn't go to movies or restaurants. The whole question of sexuality was repressed and denied."
Perhaps not surprisingly, the cardinals carried this tradition of silence with them as they rose in the hierarchy.
Catholics whose anger was not appeased by the expressions of regret in Rome can take some comfort that the cardinals are not going unpunished. Many will almost certainly be remembered best for their role in the worst scandal in the history of the American church.
As young men, they had seemed destined to make a mark -- only more gloriously. "Mississippi in the 1960's was all that one might imagine and more," Bernard Law wrote to his Harvard '53 classmates at their 25th reunion. "To have been part of that significant moment in our history is in itself a grace, a gift."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Scouting for Work, But Close to the Nest

BYLINE:  By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:
Are Americans shedding their peripatetic ways? In a recent survey, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the job placement firm, found that just 14 percent of job seekers relocated for new jobs in the first quarter. That was the lowest level since Challenger began such tallies 16 years ago, and was down sharply from the 22 percent average of recent years. 
 There are two basic reasons for the change: choosy employers don't need to go far afield, and jumpy Americans don't want to. With more workers available, "employers cut back on sending recruiters to distant college campuses as well as the costs of flying candidates in for interviews," said John A. Challenger, chief executive of the firm. "Even when they found a desirable out-of-town candidate, they were less willing to cover his or her relocation expenses." 
 Some Americans wouldn't have moved anyway. With Sept. 11 still reverberating in their psyches, and the economy shaky, many people feel better just staying put. These days, "the last place you want to be if you lose your job is a strange new city," Mr. Challenger said.
What if people remain immovable once the economy rebounds? Mr. Challenger, for one, sees a return of 1990's-style job shortages and possibly "a repeat of the unfettered buildup of extraordinary perks, such as signing bonuses and expensive cars." Hubert B. Herring

HEADLINE: Of College and Status 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Ivy League or Also-Ran? Does It Matter?" (Economic View, April 21), in which Tom Redburn described his teenage daughter's deliberations in deciding on a college:
 As a guidance counselor for 30 years in a highly competitive public high school that routinely sent more than 95 percent of its graduates to college, I was faced with parents who would not like my endorsement of their child's choice. 
"But that's not a good college," they would say. (Translation: That is not an Ivy League or otherwise prestigious school.) 
 Many parents were upset with me when I told their child that "it's not where you go to school; it's what you do with where you go." Mr. Redburn basically says the same thing when he writes, "It's the person, not the place, that matters."
I am glad to see the recent research showing that students who chose schools with lower admissions standards over more competitive schools make just as much money as those who attend the elite college. It proves that my thinking was in the right place 20 and 30 years ago. In fact, I can name students who attended state colleges who went on to become renowned experts in their fields. No, Harvard is not the best school for everyone.

NAOMI SCHLESSEL
Boynton Beach, Fla., April 22

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Looking for Dinner in a Hurry

BYLINE:  By JULIA E. MEURLING 

 BODY:
 Overworked Americans have little time for cooking. Instead, they are choosing convenient, already prepared meals, which they eat at home. 
The average American ate 74 frozen meals last year, compared with 56 in 1992, a 33 percent increase, according to a survey on eating trends by NPD Foodworld. 
 Americans also rely heavily on restaurants for takeout meals, but the average number of takeout meals fell last year, to 70 from 72 the previous year. The decline, the first since the 1980's, was attributable in part to economic concerns, according to the survey. In the weakened economy, more people decided to forgo the convenience of takeout to save a few dollars. JULIA E. MEURLING

HEADLINE: Street Fairs, Pre-empted By Sept. 11, Are Back 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Hakim Muhammad says he does it to build experience and savings to open a restaurant or other business.
 Mike Dadaivd runs a gift shop already, but says he does it because "I have eight children, and I have to take care of them." 
 Joseph Okolie says he has never made a profit, but he does it once or twice a month to "expose Americans to African culture." 
Mr. Muhammad, with his fish and chips; Mr. Dadaivd, with his backpacks and belts; and Mr. Okolie, with his large woven baskets from his native Nigeria, were among nearly 150 vendors lining Second Avenue from 16th to 23rd Streets in Manhattan at a street fair last Sunday. 
It is once again street fair season in New York City. After an autumn in which all but 4 of the nearly 100 street fairs scheduled after Sept. 11 were canceled, New Yorkers are seeing the earliest of about 400 such events, ranging from a single block to more than 20, that are to be held through November. 
While New Yorkers are of two minds about the fairs -- some love them, others consider them a plague -- they are certainly a fixture of city life and a source of income for vendors, for the nonprofit groups that sponsor the events, for the city and for the handful of professional organizers that put fairs together.
"Most vendors are immigrants, and this is their livelihood," said Mort Berkowitz, president of Mort & Ray Productions, which organizes and runs fairs. "Very few travel to other cities."
Mr. Dadaivd, a Russian immigrant, said he works weekdays at a small gift shop he operates in Brooklyn, and then spends Saturdays and Sundays purveying his fair wares. "A good day is selling $1,000," he said as he minded his stand.
He said that he could not estimate the worth of his inventory, but that his expenses that day were the $350 fee for his spot and $155 for a rented truck to carry his goods from his father's warehouse. There are no labor costs; members of his large family work the fairs with him, he said.
He declined to discuss his revenues, but said that last year had been a losing one because the autumn season had been aborted. Previous years had allowed him to "make a living -- not save money in the bank, just a good living."
Mr. Berkowitz said that companies like his had significant losses when last season was cut short, though he declined to specify his losses. Todd Berman, president of Clearview Festival Productions, which ran the Second Avenue fair for the 13th Precinct Community Council, also would not give his losses, but said he had had to lay off his entire staff of seven full-time employees and as many as 20 part-time seasonal workers.
Others who lost money were the civic, political and charitable groups and local religious institutions that sponsor the fairs as fund-raisers. The 13th Precinct Community Council, made up of residents and businesses, took in $10,000 as its share of the proceeds from the similar fair it held last year, said Jeanne Tregre, the council's president.
She said she did not know how much this year's fair had raised. The council used last year's proceeds for expenses like a playground attendant and computer equipment for the 13th Precinct station house.
City records show that $10,000 was about one-third of the revenue from last year's fair, which came from the fees paid by the vendors. Mr. Berman said the rest of the proceeds went to expenses, including cleanup, promotion and Clearview's fee.
The city also lost money when the fall street fair season was cut short. The city gets 20 percent of the fees that a fair charges its vendors. Last year, the city's take fell to $1.4 million from $2.1 million in 2000, said Jonathan D. Greenspun, commissioner of the Mayor's Community Assistance Unit. 
The current street fair season began as scheduled last month because the police force was no longer consumed by the terrorist attack's aftermath, said Mildred Duran, an assistant commissioner.
But city residents are divided on the fairs, which have become so ubiquitous that as many as a dozen can be held on a single weekend.
Supporters call them colorful contributions to the city's street life and economy. They say the bazaars permit mom-and-pop businesses to operate with little overhead, and visitors to stumble onto that perfect piece of handcrafted jewelry or pottery, all while helping worthy groups raise money.
Critics say the fairs have lost their early charm as occasional events dominated in most cases by homemade food and crafts. Today, they assert, the fairs are mostly a traffic-disrupting glut of cookie-cutter commerce heavy with tube socks, sunglasses and other mass-produced mundanities.
In 1995, the city limited the street fairs to 400 annually, the number reached that year, Ms. Duran said.
Such matters were not the focus of Mr. Okolie and Mr. Muhammad as they offered their wares at the fair on Second Avenue, under heavily overcast skies that Mr. Berman said had kept the crowds smaller than expected.
Mr. Okolie, 36, an employee of a health club chain, said profit was not the reason he attended fairs to sell his large Nigerian baskets, which he said helped people appreciate the work of other cultures.
"It's always been a loss," he said. By late afternoon he had sold fewer than five baskets, which were priced at up to $20. His fee for his street space was $160.
Mr. Muhammad, 38, a Brooklynite, said that this was his third year doing street events during the outdoor season. He works indoor fairs in the winter. He said he was able to offset some of his losses from last year's aborted season by obtaining help from a program for businesses whose losses could be attributed to the Sept. 11 attack. 
Mr. Muhammad would not discuss his vending income, but said his costs for his fish-and-chips stand last Sunday were $200 to $300 for the food, about $225 for his space and $80 to truck in his operation. Since he was charging $4 an order, he had to sell 125 to 150 orders to break even.
Whatever the outcome, he said, he would stick with vending at fairs because it was "more satisfying" than the messenger, security and other jobs he had held in the past. And, he said, it was a "step in the direction" of opening a restaurant or store.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS; 
Trout Are Endangered Because of the Drought

BYLINE:  By Pete Bodo 

DATELINE: HANCOCK, N.Y. 

 BODY:
As New York's drought emergency continues unabated, and the prospect of a long, hot summer continues to morph into that of an infernal, bone-dry one, trout anglers are facing a variation on that most famous of Shakespearean, existential questions: to fish or not to fish.
 With the upstate reservoirs that supply New York City only about half full (customarily, the large impoundments on the East and West branches of the Delaware River are so full at this time of year that water is spilling over their dams), city officials loathe as ever to release any more cold water than they must, and no state regulations in place to protect trout at times when they are thermally stressed, the stage is set for an ecological catastrophe. 
As disaster scenarios go, this one is pretty simple. When New York City planners had the foresight -- and imperial moxie -- to buy up vast tracts of water-rich Catskill land and create a reservoir system for the growing metropolis, they conquered and radically transformed the ecology of large river systems like those of the two waterways that meet at Hancock, N.Y., to create the Delaware River -- the East and West branches. 
Now those watersheds, which have become premier flyfishing destinations and significant contributors to the struggling upstate economy, are utterly dependent on cold-water releases from the large dams that block the rivers. The less water the rivers get, the more quickly and severely they become thermally inhospitable to the creatures that have flourished there since the dams were built.
This past week, the West Branch at Hale Eddy a few miles below Cannonsville Reservoir was flowing at 142 cubic feet a second, when the 80-year mean for this time of year is about 1,210 c.f.s. As of last week, water managers were releasing just 23 c.f.s. from Cannonsville, the minimum required during drought emergency. The irony is that the unseasonably dry weather and unusually low and warm water have created excellent early-season flyfishing, with fly hatches well ahead of schedule. But only a myopic angler would fail to recognize the alarming signals in those unusual conditions.
"If the city continues to release the minimum amount of water and forecasts for a hot and dry summer prove out, there's a real threat of a severe fish kill as early as May," said Nat Gillespie, Catskills coordinator for Trout Unlimited. "That big kill-off could be avoidable if New York City and and the D.R.B.C." -- the Delaware River Basin Commission, representing the interests of the four Delaware-river user states of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware -- "can be convinced to release more cold water."
The battle between conservationists and other user groups and the Delaware water managers, principally those for New York City, has been lengthy, acrimonious and perhaps needless. After all, the city even has the vast reserves of the upper Hudson river right on its doorstep. That New Yorkers are profligate with water is clear: according to statistics compiled by Trout Unlimited, the per capita consumption in New York City is 160 gallons a person per day -- almost three times that of a resident of Boston, and about five times that of a European.
As Jim Serio, executive director of the Delaware River Foundation, said: "Normally, upstate New York gets about 45 inches of rain per year. The bottom line is that there's plenty of water for everyone, including trout."
In fact, the shortcomings and the conflicts bred by the current water management system are such that the Delaware commission has been ordered to create a new, comprehensive management plan. But that does not help the Delaware River trout in the projected drought-plagued short term. In order to survive this summer, the fish will need cold water, and they may need compassion not just of water managers but anglers too -- particularly catch-and-release flyfishers. For there is little point in releasing a fish that is going to die because it has been caught.
Trout are cold-blooded creatures that function most efficiently in water temperatures in the high 50's to upper 60's. When the temperature hits 70 degrees, rainbow and brown trout begin to suffer the effects of thermal stress, and as it rises above that critical number, their bodily functions begin to shut down. Gillespie said that studies have shown that brown trout simply cannot eat enough to sustain their body weight once the water temperature reaches 72 degrees.
Left to their own devices, trout might be able to survive such high temperatures by conserving their energy and seeking refuge in deep, shaded pools or riverbed spring seepages. But the additional stress they experience by being caught can be, and often is, lethal. This, incidentally, is why many Canadian Atlantic salmon rivers routinely are shut down when the water becomes dangerously low and warm. Although state trout managers in the United States avoid such closures, an increasing number of flyfishers voluntarily desist from fishing when the water temperature reaches 70.
You may see them next month, standing in the river holding up thermometers like Hamlet once held the skull of poor Yoric, asking themselves the question that all flyfishers now more than ever before should address.
