HEADLINE: Migrants Feel Chill in a Testy Europe 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 27 

 BODY:
When he strolls the boulevards of his adoptive French city with his 9-year-old daughter, Belkacem Djedid senses in her a kind of loss, or maybe just a notion that she is different from the people around her. "I see it in her eyes, in the sadness there," said Mr. Djedid, an Algerian. 
 Maybe, he said, speaking by telephone from Lyon, it is the fact that her clothes are Red Cross hand-me-downs, or that he cannot afford the fancy trainers and toys that betoken Europe's prosperity, or the vacations that her classmates enjoy. "Sometimes she says, 'Why am I not like them?' " Mr. Djedid said, speaking of her classmates. "And I say that, one day, the time will come and you will be like them." 
 What basically makes the Djedid family different, though, is that they are asylum seekers, hoping to qualify as refugees. That status means that they and hundreds of thousands of others like them across Europe are denied normal lives because of a web of bureaucratic constraints and ambiguities sometimes worthy of Kafka. Now, more than ever, as it seeks to expand its own membership, the 15-nation European Union confronts a crucial decision on whether to embrace outsiders as the United States does, or reject them as intruders. 
But with rightist forces gaining ground, people like Mr. Djedid and his daughter are also the subject of a rising resentment, like that preached by the archrightist Jean-Marie Le Pen, who shocked France last weekend by earning a place in the second round of national elections for president.
The issue is a sore point not just in France. The emotive debate over asylum and immigration have led to rightist political advances in Austria and Denmark, Italy and the usually liberal Netherlands. Britain is concerned that voter apathy in forthcoming local elections will give an advantage to the xenophobic British National Party.
Last year alone about 350,000 people from such faraway places as India and Congo openly sought refugee status in Western Europe, according to United Nations figures.
Many claim instant rights to housing, education, health care and welfare checks, yet they are denied the up-by-the-bootstraps right to work that, by contrast, has always underpinned the immigrant's hope for access to the American dream. 
That flow adds to the untold millions settling in Europe illegally and legally, going back to the 1960's and 1970's when people from Pakistan or Turkey or North Africa were embraced as cheap labor only to outstay their welcome.
European nations generally limit or even outlaw the kind of immigration that once attracted waves of Irish or Italians to the United States, so people wanting to escape to a new life in Europe cast themselves as asylum seekers instead. 
In Britain and Germany, new legislation is under debate to regulate the inflow. 
On Thursday, the European Union tried to draw up a code harmonizing the way Europe copes with the situation, which a British minister referred to as the "swamping" by outsiders, while liberalizing some of the myriad laws ensnaring asylum seekers.
But after Mr. Le Pen's first-round upset, said Kay Hailbronner, an expert on immigration at Konstanz University in Germany, any moves to liberalize European practices seem to be subject now to "more restrictive tendencies."
In some ways, Europe's practices have contributed to the reaction. Mr. Djedid, for instance, cannot legally work while his application for political asylum is being processed. For many asylum seekers, that means a life of idleness, perceived by right-wing Europeans as evidence that foreigners are leeching onto their welfare systems. 
In Britain, tabloid newspapers routinely inveigh against "bogus" asylum seekers out to bilk the social systems and gain unearned prosperity.
Yet conversations in recent days with asylum seekers and experts in France, Germany, Switzerland and Britain suggest that asylum seekers do not have it easy in a continent that has progressively reduced their right of access.
"There's no soft touch," said Neil Amos, a spokesman for a British group that helps asylum seekers find work. Voters for Mr. Le Pen obviously disagree. 
Variations abound in how European countries treat asylum seekers. In relatively poor Greece, for instance, asylum seekers may work as soon as they apply for recognition as refugees, but they receive no welfare checks. 
In prosperous France, Britain and Germany, where unemployment is high, fugitives receive benefits, but their path to a job is littered with restrictions, some of the bizarre. 
For example, Erik Muradian, now 18, moved with his family in 1993 from Armenia to Frankfurt to escape the wreckage of the former Soviet Union. He was refused refugee status and is now applying for residence rights on humanitarian grounds. 
His mother and father both may work, although their jobs in Germany are not highly paid; back at home, by contrast, she taught music and he worked as an engineer. By contrast, Mr. Muradian and his sister Ella, 17, may not work.
Frankfurt's social affairs office, where Mr. Muradian picks up a $200 welfare check every month, keeps telling him to find a job. But the office that deals with foreigners tells him he is not permitted to work, he said. 
So he spends his days playing soccer as a midfielder with a local team and hanging out with other foreigners. "I want to work as a salesman in an office, but I'm not allowed to," he said.
Ursula Sinderman, an adviser at a charity called Workers Well-Being, said, young men like Mr. Muradian are caught "in a devil's circle." Particularly in what was once East Germany, she said, where asylum seekers tend to live in segregated homes, "people can see they are unemployed and say, 'Look at them taking everything from us. They come here to our social state just to cash in.'
 "But these are people who are motivated to find a new life but the law condemns them to inactivity," she said. 
Differences in the way that the various countries of Europe handle the right of asylum seekers to work fuel "asylum shopping" where fugitives look for the best place to settle. For many, that place is apparently Britain.
It allows asylum seekers to work after only six months, a luxury unheard of for people like Mr. Djedid and Mr. Muradian. That is evidently one reason so many asylum seekers try to spirit themselves into Britain through the Channel Tunnel on a perilous, high-speed journey as stowaways on passenger and freight trains.
Mr. Djedid in Lyon wants to put down his roots in France. He came to France, he said, as the director of an Algerian cultural institute in 1998, and simply stayed on, not wanting to return to the war in Algeria that has raged between secular authorities and militant Islamic foes.
Every two weeks, he said, he gets about $140 to feed his wife and daughter, who live with him in a small, two-room apartment in a refugee center in Lyon. They share a kitchen with a Sudanese family. 
He does not pay for the apartment, or for full-coverage, state-provided health care or for schooling for his daughter, Hadjar. 
Neither, he said, does he work illegally, as many asylum seekers do, in menial jobs like dishwashing in restaurants.
"I don't want any trouble," said Mr. Djedid, 37. "I don't want anything to influence my application for asylum. But it's very, very difficult. If my wife needs something or my daughter needs something, I cannot give it to them."
Another case is that of Hadas Woldeghiorgis, a onetime guerrilla fighter who fled Eritrea in 1990, helped by smugglers in Sudan who gave her false papers that got her as far as Frankfurt, where foreigners make up a quarter or more of the population.
But since then her application for asylum has gone unresolved. While she has been allowed to find some work under laws permitting asylum seekers to work after one year, she must seek the permission of the authorities for every job she takes to ensure that she does not take work from a German or from a foreigner with greater rights.
She has not been permitted to leave Frankfurt without permission. "We have been here for 12 years," said Hani, her 18-year-old son. 
He is a high school student who has grown up with the same aspirations as his well-heeled German classmates. "All my friends go on vacation," he said. "They can go anywhere. I can't."

HEADLINE: Recovery? It's Here Somewhere; 
Economists Look for Signs in Storefronts and Even Bars

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
If you think the weather has been wacky this spring, consider the economy. One week it seems to be rebounding, the next week the signals are dismal. Manufacturing is up. No, it's down. Housing is strong. No, it's weak this month, but was even stronger last month than anyone thought.
 Economists, who have a lot in common with weather forecasters, are either cheery or dreary; often they alternate between the two moods day by day, or even minute by minute. They do seem to agree that New York City has not yet emerged from the recession. But when it will recover remains a matter for dispute (and economists love disputes). 
 As they wait and debate, they are keeping their eyes on some crucial sectors and early warning signals that you may be hearing a lot about in the months ahead. These are the places where you might see signs of recovery first and areas that must rebound if the city's economy is to bounce back. 
For starters, Wall Street: its revenues, deals, trading volumes and stock prices. Advertising in general, help-wanted ads in particular. Temporary employment agencies.
Tourism-related indicators, like hotel occupancy (back up) and room rates (still down). Retail sales (mixed). The moods of consumers and executives, as measured by confidence surveys.
Real estate -- including office buildings, co-ops and apartments for rent -- is being watched, as is the city budget.
And, of course, there are the hard-to-measure but easy-to-spot economic indicators, like empty storefronts on Fifth Avenue or the bar scene on the Upper West Side.
Average people and economists can probably agree on the most important measure of economic health: jobs. If you feel that you could find a new job tomorrow, the economy is booming. If you are worried about spending months out of work, the economy is bad.
The problem with focusing only on employment is that, for the most part, it is a lagging indicator. Companies are slow to lay people off when the economy turns down, and slow to hire them again even after business picks up. 
One exception is the market for temporary jobs, which are leading indicators on the way down and on the way up. "We're usually three months ahead of the curve," said James A. Essey, president of the TemPositions Group of Companies. There are no signs of a surge yet, he said, "but it's not getting worse."
Help-wanted ads are sending a similar signal; they have basically been flat since November, according to the Conference Board, a business research group. Over all, advertising remains weak, as reflected in the poor earnings of publishing companies.
Employment in New York City peaked last spring and has been declining ever since; about 135,000 jobs have disappeared, at least some because of the aftershocks of Sept. 11. Still, the losses slowed in March and the total drop is just 3.6 percent, because the city has more than 3.5 million jobs.
On a historical basis, even a year of declining employment is a mere blip. During the bleak years of the 1970's, employment in the city dropped for seven years, as more than 650,000 jobs disappeared -- about 17 percent of the employment base. Similarly, between the end of 1988 and early 1993, employment dropped by about 442,000, or 12 percent.
Then there is the dreaded "double dip," which occurred in the early 1960's in New York. After a bad year for jobs, 1962 showed improvement, all of which was wiped out in 1963 as the economy sputtered again.
Some economists worry that could be happening again. One of them is Frank Fernandez, chief economist for the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's trade group. "This is one of those times I want to be wrong," he said last week.
Wall Street itself is not in great shape, and that is bad in a city where financial services and real estate generate about 30 percent of all yearly income, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The stock market, which had seemed to be rebounding earlier in the year, has been falling for five weeks. Companies are not selling much stock, or hiring investment bankers to help with mergers.
Individual investors, already shell-shocked by the two-year stock market meltdown, are now further discouraged by revelations that the game was rigged against them by companies like Enron and by "analysts" who were really just shills for their firms' corporate clients.
The securities firms are surviving because they have cut costs -- employment on Wall Street is down by at least 20,000 since August. "We think we bottomed in the first quarter," Mr. Fernandez said, but signs of recovery are "very spotty."
The data he is watching most closely are Wall Street revenues, because if those pick up, it will mean business is improving. So far this year, however, revenues have continued last year's pattern of decline.
Part of Mr. Fernandez's gloom stems from the city's budgetary problems, which he and others fear will lead to a sharp erosion in New Yorkers' quality of life. "The sad part is that businesses and individuals don't really need much encouragement to leave New York City at this point," he said. "Things don't look too good; we're west of a rock and east of a hard place."
One way to figure out if people are abandoning the city is to look at real estate. A new report prepared by Miller Samuel Inc., the appraisal firm, for Insignia Douglas Elliman, found that the average price of an apartment in Manhattan edged up 1 percent in the first quarter of 2002, and remained 10 percent below last year's (very high) levels. Sales sped up. Meanwhile, rents fell by 10 percent to 20 percent.
Interpreting the housing market can be tough, especially in New York City, where relatively few people own their own home.
"The fact that New York is getting price increases while the economy is down suggests the glass is half-full," said Jason Bram, an economist at the New York Fed. "A pessimist would look at it and say housing's a lagging indicator." Still another way to look at it is to note the disparity between rents and prices, which suggests that people are still willing to make long-term commitments to the city, he said.
The office market is a different story. Vacancies, which are much higher than last year, jumped in February but only edged up in March, according to Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist for The New York Stat, a newsletter on the local economy.
Consumers have continued to spend, which economists contend has helped keep the downturn relatively mild. In New York, especially, consumer confidence plunged after Sept. 11, but seemed to rebound as the most dire predictions about the future failed to come true.
But on Friday, a national survey found that consumers were becoming more pessimistic again. On the other hand, the federal government announced that the national economy fared better in the first quarter than most analysts had expected.
The good news/bad news syndrome may well continue for a while; economists did not become confident that the 1991 recession had ended (in March of that year) until December 1992. 
Meanwhile, like most of us, economists have their own informal ways of gauging the economy, like counting the empty storefronts in their neighborhoods. Ken Goldstein, the chief economist at the Conference Board, suggested watching apartment rents -- and bars -- on the Upper West Side. "If they are selling more beer out of bars on Amsterdam Avenue," he said, "things must be starting to pick up."

HEADLINE: If This Is the Swap Meet, Then It Must Be Monday 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: HANFORD, Calif. 

 BODY:
The spring-green almond and pistachio trees in this Central Valley town about 35 miles southwest of Fresno are bursting with new life. So is the swap meet.
 Spring is the time when the marquetita -- otherwise known as el swap meet -- is in bloom, displaying the breadth of human creativity in a staggering array of inexpensive goods. From Visalia, Porterville, Selma and dozens of other communities they come, seeking caps, sandpaper, Mexican soccer socks, Pink Miracle tennis shoe cleaner, tropical love birds (four for $100) and cockfighting videos. 
 Every Monday, rain or shine, the former site of stockyards outside town is transformed into an instant city, where aluminum taco carts become sidewalk cafes and table-soccer games become ad hoc amusement parks. 
"It's a tradition -- you go to church on Sundays and the flea market on Mondays," said Luis Ramos, 30, whose four Foosball tables are a major draw. "The guys come to meet girls and basically gather. It's like the plaza."
The country's roughly 2,500 swap meets -- including flea markets, as they are known in the East -- are like fingerprints, with slight variations. The character of el swap meet is distinctly Mexican. 
Reymond Morales, 64, a janitor from Visalia, was strolling down an avenue of wedding dresses and cowboy hats the other day. In his hand was a fruit cup brimming with watermelon, cucumber, jicama and cantaloupe sprinkled with chile powder. 
"You can't get this there," Mr. Morales said, referring to the mall. "This is real Mexican."
While swap meets are flourishing all over, they take on special significance in places like Hanford, population 45,000. Here in Kings County, farm laborers make up roughly a quarter of the work force and the unemployment rate hovers at 16 percent, with Spanish spoken in well over half the households. A quarter to a half of the 200 to 300 vendors feature Mexican goods.
"Migrant workers often don't have telephones, or subscribe to newspapers, and many do not have cars," said Carol Whiteside, president of the Great Valley Center, a policy group in Modesto. "At the swap meet, they come together and network." 
The Hanford meet will grow even larger next month, as goods emerge from post-spring-cleaning garage sales and migrants begin working the fields after a winter lull.
"You see everyone at the remate, especially on a holiday," said Dolores Gallegos, a Hanford City Council member, using a Spanish term for swap meet. "The superintendent of schools, the prison warden, the teachers. The youth are always there, buying CD's."
On a recent morning Vanessa Vega, 18, was with her mother, Candelaria, eyeing Mexican coconut candy. Marisol Urbina was sizing up a skinny denim skirt. Maria Peres, 32, was shopping with her cousin Lupe Peres, 23, from Sacramento, stocking up on limes, tomatoes and nopales -- fresh cactus paddles, a springtime delicacy. Maria Peres is a fruit sorter who moved to the Central Valley from Guanajuato three years ago. 
"We come here to walk," she said, clutching a plastic bag plump with produce. "It's the same as home."
To Michael Peter Smith, a professor of community studies and development at the University of California at Davis, swap meets like the one in Hanford represent "a new kind of public space, a grass-roots form of urban revitalization." In agricultural communities they become town squares, American zocalos, where violet lingerie might share space with an '83 pickup truck alternator or a bouquet of silk roses.
"It's not just about buying and selling," Professor Smith said. "It's the sounds, the smell, the vitality of street life and the sentient memory of place."
The swap meet also represents a parallel economy. Though California requires vendors to buy resale licenses and pay sales tax, the lack of overhead and the ability to bargain can result in cheaper merchandise. The Hanford vendors pay $6 for a space, $7 for a covered one, for the day. 
"It's a large part of the local economy that doesn't get reflected in employment statistics," said Ted Bradshaw, an associate professor of community studies at the University of California at Davis. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jose Louis prepares nopales -- fresh cactus paddles -- for sale at a swap meet in Hanford, Calif.; Marisol Urbina and her sister Ali check out clothing at the swap meet, known as the marquetita or remate, which is held every Monday. (Photographs by Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: South Koreans Invest In Propping Up the North 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DORASAN, South Korea 

 BODY:
With barbed wire blocking railroad tracks here, most tourists on the "Security Tourism Train" see this brand new station as the end of the line.
 But South Korean officials now plan to help North Korea remove land mines and lay tracks across the Demilitarized Zone this summer. Under this new construction plan, freight trains will rumble through here to North Korea this fall, the first inter-Korean rail traffic since the Korean War, half a century ago. 
 While Bush administration officials make little secret of their wish to see North Korea's repressive government collapse, South Korea is taking a different tack. Seoul is pushing joint business and infrastructure ventures, hoping that economic engagement will moderate North Korea's behavior, build economic dependency between the Koreas and make life easier for North Korea's largely destitute population. 
In early April, South Korean companies opened North Korea's first car assembly factory and North Korea's first Internet lottery game. In May, representatives of five South Korean communications companies plan to visit North Korea to compete for a half-billion-dollar cellphone project. This fall, a South Korean sports entrepreneur plans to start flying hundreds of South Koreans to North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, to play at North Korea's only 18-hole golf course.
As smaller companies weave links with North Korea, inter-Korean trade rose 15 percent during the first quarter of this year over the same period the year before. Last year, South Korean companies sent 203 technicians north to work on joint-venture projects, more than double the previous year's level. In addition to 450,000 South Koreans who have visited North Korea's Mount Kumgang resort since 1999, about 6,200 South Koreans are visiting North Korea yearly. Only 270 visited yearly in the decade before 1998, the year South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, adopted a "sunshine policy" toward North Korea.
"The main objective for us is to make sure North Korea does not collapse," Han Duk Soo, the main economic adviser to President Kim, said in an interview here. "If they collapse, we know it will mean a huge cost to South Korea."
To revive North Korea's economy, Jeong Se Hyun, South Korea's unification minister, recently proposed that South Korea "should transfer industrial technologies to the North without royalties."
To help prop up its northern neighbor, which has a population of 23 million, South Korea recently shipped north 100,000 tons of corn. In May, it expects to complete shipment of 200,000 tons of free fertilizer and to start sending 300,000 tons of rice. In March, South Korea's government agreed to pay a monthly subsidy of $1.4 million to keep alive the tourism project at Mount Kumgang, a major foreign exchange earner for the North.
On Sunday, after an 18-month hiatus, Mount Kumgang is to be the site of a fourth round of reunions of family members separated by the Korean War. Courting South Korean public opinion, North Korea is allowing the reunions to be televised live for the first time.
On May 7, economic delegates from both Koreas are to meet in Seoul to negotiate the opening of railroad and road connections, including a road to the Mount Kumgang resort. With the two Koreas technically still at war, land links would be a major breakthrough for the peninsula.
This sudden thawing of inter-Korean relations comes after North Korea responded with alarm to American battlefield successes in Afghanistan and President Bush's subsequent listing of North Korea, Iran and Iraq as an "axis of evil."
"North Korean people are starving and hopeless," President Bush told South Korea's state-run KBS television before coming here in February. Mr. Bush added that he doubted that Kim Jong Il, who inherited leadership of the Communist nation from his father, "represents the will of the North Korean people."
In one of a series of harsh reactions, North Korean radio said: "For the Bush gang to dare talk about changing our system is intolerable."
Some people here believe that Washington's tough talk has pushed North Korea to restart overtures to the South, hoping to defuse American confrontation with a new show of moderation.
"North Korea likes strong talk," said Son Man Bong, a South Korean Army veteran, on a recent visit to this town where he was wounded during the 1950-53 Korean War. Then, with a giggle, he made his hands quiver as he added, "But out of sight, they are scared."
For its part, South Korea is not putting all its eggs in an economic harmony basket. With an eye to North Korea's one-million-strong military force, South Korea recently decided to spend $4.5 billion to buy 40 F-15K fighter jets, enough air power to knock out North Korea's rusty Soviet-era air force in the course of an afternoon.
Despite this expensive military insurance policy, South Korea is perhaps North Korea's best benefactor, economic partner and business promoter. When North Korea held its First International Computer Software Expo in Beijing in mid-April, the South Korean government sent a seven-member mission to explore areas of joint cooperation.
Constantly trying to draw North Korea out of isolation, South Korea wants to invite North Korean athletes to the Asian Games in Pusan in September and to the Asian Development Bank annual assembly in Shanghai in May. The United States opposes North Korea's participation as an observer in the bank meeting, charging that North Korea still supports terrorism.
With the path to economic cooperation littered with unfulfilled promises by North Korea, the most striking recent development was the April 5 opening in the North Korean port of Nampo of a $55 million car assembly plant by a group of investors associated with the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon. Pyeonghwa Motors Corporation, in a joint venture with a North Korean company, opened the plant, which is capable of a yearly production of 20,000 Siena cars, a compact designed by Fiat Spa.
There are only about 3,000 passenger cars in North Korea, compared with about 9 million in South Korea, which has roughly twice the population of the North. Pyeonghwa, which means peace in Korean, plans to build three gas stations and North Korea's first car dealership.
"This country was so closed that nobody, not God, not Buddha, could get in in the last 50 years without a visa," Park Sang Kwon, president of Pyeonghwa, told reporters in Seoul, where the company has its headquarters. "Nobody, even in my own company, believed it was possible to build an automobile in North Korea. Only I believed.
"We are bound to succeed," continued Mr. Park. "There are no unions, low labor costs. The workers are very clever, very quick to learn, and they are harshly controlled by their superiors."
Such joint ventures signal a departure from North Korea's ruling philosophy of juche, or self-reliance. In an important policy speech in March, North Korea's prime minister, Hong Song Nam, said that his country needed to "improve trade and economic cooperation and widely conduct joint ventures and collaboration with different countries and international organizations."
From Seoul, Dr. Han, the economic adviser, said: "I think they are very much interested in promoting investment from the South. As we move along with these seemingly small projects, confidence can be built."
The biggest economic investment with a realistic chance for success is the North-South railroad. Russia, in pressuring North Korea to restore rail links to the South, hopes to make the Trans-Siberian Railroad a money maker by shipping goods from South Korea to Europe. Korean authorities estimate that shipping containers by rail from South Korea to Europe would be twice as fast and one-quarter the cost of shipping by boat.
Last winter, a team of about 200 Russian railroad experts surveyed the state of North Korea's rail network. Simply to rebuild the railroad on North Korea's east side, which links directly to Russia, would cost $2.2 billion. With South Korea and Russia expected eventually to finance rail rebuilding through North Korea, the three countries are planning a railroad conference in the Russian Far East in September.
With work now completed to the Demilitarized Zone on the west coast here, South Korean authorities have decided to start a seven-year, $1 billion project this summer to build 80 miles of railroad on the eastern side of South Korea to the Demilitarized Zone.
After meetings in Pyongyang with Kim Jong Il in early April, a South Korean negotiator reported that North Korea's leader said the western rail link, connecting with this station, would be ready by October and that an eastern rail link should also be re-established. Mr. Kim also said a road should be opened across the Demilitarized Zone to Mount Kumgang, a link that could help make tourism there profitable.
Mr. Jeong, the unification minister, predicted that rail and road work could start within the Demilitarized Zone as soon as May.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: JETS NOTEBOOK; 
Puzzle Is Completed With Webster Signing

BYLINE:  By JUDY BATTISTA 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., April 27 

 BODY:
The Jets filled the final hole in their defense today when defensive tackle Larry Webster agreed to a one-year contract for $675,000.
 Webster, who was a backup with Baltimore last season, chose the Jets over Washington and could start next to Jason Ferguson. 
 Webster, 33, had 17 tackles in 15 games last season. He has started 36 games in his 11-season career and has been suspended three times for violations of the N.F.L.'s substance-abuse policy. 
Webster will almost certainly represent the final significant move in the Jets' extraordinary reshaping of their defense. They have now signed seven defensive free agents, five of whom are likely to start next season.

A Son, but No Extension
There is little to trouble Wayne Chrebet now, not when he passes around a photo of his 5-month-old son, Lukas, not even when he discusses his intriguing contract situation. Chrebet, who is entering his eighth season with the Jets, will be in the final year of his contract and will count $4.4 million against the salary cap. That would seem to scream out for an extension, but there have been no negotiations and no indication from the Jets about their plans. 
Chrebet said he hoped to play out his career with the Jets, but he was untroubled by the lack of talks.
"I signed a four-year extension, and in my mind I plan on playing the four years," Chrebet said. "I'd like to have the security of knowing I'll have a job here for the next five years. I know they had other pressing issues. I'll wait my turn. I don't think there's a rush. I'm not threatening to hold out. I don't blame them. It's not like I'm not going to make a good living this year."
The obvious question is whether the Jets think Chrebet, who is coming off what he termed a disappointing season, is a correct fit. Until the final quarter of last season, Chrebet was nearly invisible in the version of the West Coast offense devised by Paul Hackett, the offensive coordinator. Chrebet's 56 catches were the fewest he has had except for the 1999 season, when he missed five games because of injury.
Chrebet said that because the Jets did not significantly change their offense through free agency and the draft, that indicated they were generally content with their personnel. Chrebet said that while he would prefer to get a contract done before the season so that he was not distracted by negotiations, he could also envision playing out his deal. He said he would like to learn what other teams thought of him by testing free agency.
"That might hurt them," Chrebet said. "I might have a career year. Other people appreciate my play in the league. What are you going to do? My obvious first choice is playing here."
Chrebet, who grew up in New Jersey as a Giants fan, jokes that he and his friend Michael Strahan, a defensive end for the Giants, have often talked of playing together. But Chrebet also said he felt particularly settled now, with the birth of his son.
"I'm just so happy all the time," Chrebet said. "My life is set -- I've got a great job, got a great wife, I have an adorable son."
The Jets have several big decisions to make this season. Center Kevin Mawae and guard Randy Thomas are entering the final years of their contracts, and Curtis Martin has two years remaining. Enormous cap numbers are involved in the contracts. Coach Herman Edwards said he did not worry about contracts, but immediately after the draft he and General Manager Terry Bradway said they would discuss their course of action in coming meetings. 
"The feeling of the organization is we want Wayne to be here, and we're going try to do everything to keep him here," Edwards said. "There is no timeline for the organization. I expect it will get done. I hope he has a great year. Who says it's not going to get done before the season?" 

Fabini Goes to His Right
Offensive tackle Jason Fabini received a new contract this year. Now he has a new position, too. Fabini, who has played left tackle for the last two seasons, is playing right tackle. The second-year player Kareem McKenzie will play left tackle.
Fabini, who did not object to the move and said he had no problem with it, played right tackle as a rookie. The Jets consider him their best run blocker. Because the Jets frequently run to the right, they feel Fabini is best used on the right side.
That is quite a move, considering the Jets gave Fabini a five-year, $17.5 million contract with a $6.5 million signing bonus, the kind of money usually reserved for the guy who has to protect the quarterback's blind side. Instead, McKenzie, a third-round selection, will be trusted with Vinny Testaverde's back. It is the latest shake-up on a line that allowed just 19 sacks last season but lost its coach, Bill Muir, and left guard, Kerry Jenkins, in the off-season. 
"If we can't stop the guys from sacking the quarterback, we'll go back," Coach Herman Edwards said. 

Hello, Manhattan
The Jets, who used to stay at a hotel in New Jersey the night before home games, will stay at the Marriott Financial Center in Lower Manhattan next season. The owner, Robert Wood Johnson IV, had the idea to move the team back to the city to show the organization's commitment to helping the local economy.

HEADLINE: A Fitting Tribute to the Victims 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A United Way report showing that indirect victims of Sept. 11 are struggling to obtain services because of narrow eligibility requirements confirms the tragedy's widespread impact (news article, April 23). 
 Settlement houses and other community organizations have seen people all over the city in distress. 
Counselors report steep increases in teenage pregnancy; children acting out; adults with sleep and eating disorders; and apprehension due to economic hardships from job loss and reduced work hours. Organizations that have served communities report unprecedented signs of anxiety.
The mayor's proposed budget cuts would shrink the safety net that was in place on Sept. 11 to help people cope. The mayor and the City Council should use all revenues like those identified by the Independent Budget Office to ensure continuity of services.

EMILY MENLO MARKS
Executive Director
United Neighborhood Houses
New York, April 24, 2002

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
GETNICK, IRVING M.

 BODY:
 GETNICK-Irving M. Of Freeport, New York, passed away at the Jewish Home and Hospital in New York City on April 26, 2002. He was the loving and beloved husband of Zita, who passed away on April 30, 1993, after fifty-four years of marriage. Mr. Getnick completed his undergraduate education at the City College of the City University of New York, graduating with honors in government and law. He was a graduate of Harvard University Law School and admitted to the New York Bar in 1937. An early leader of the political reform movement in New York City, he helped build and was president of the largest Liberal Party Club in Brooklyn, New York. A strong believer and advocate for pro bono service, Mr. Getnick taught business law and was pro bono counsel to a minority business development organization in New York City. Mr Getnick had a longtime involvement in synagogue affairs, having served on the Board of Trustees and as president of the Men's Club of the Baldwin Jewish Center, Baldwin, New York. An avid reader, his favorite book was his family bible. He was honored by the Baldwin Jewish Center for his leadership by example. An active trial lawyer, he developed a broad practice, and in 1983 was joined by his son, Neil, in establishing the firm, Getnick and Getnick, currently with offices in Manhattan. His son, Michael, a lawyer in Utica, New York, is counsel to the firm. 
His high abilities in the practice of law were matched by his love and devotion to the profession he so respected. He is survived by his sister and brother-inlaw, Ethel and Irving Minsky. His brother, George, and sister, Sylvia, predeceased him. He has an adoring family of three children: daughter, Stefanie Getnick; son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Susan Getnick; son and daughterin-law, Neil Getnick and Margaret Finerty; four grandchildren, Brian and Kevin Getnick, Courtney and Katherine Finerty, and many nieces and nephews. The bonds and devotion he shared with his parents, Hyman and Becky Getnick; brother and sisters; his special relationship with his motherin-law, Clara Ellman; sister-in-law, Connie Hoffman and brother-inlaw and sister-in-law, Julius and June Ellman have enriched the lives of everyone in the Getnick and Ellman families. "To do justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your G-d." His life inspires and guides us. His favorite saying was: "It is one thing to be blessed, but another to know you have been blessed." All of his family, loved ones and friends know they have been blessed by his life. A funeral service will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home at 175 Long Beach Road in Rockville Centre, New York, at 12 noon, on Sunday, April 28, 2002. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York City, New York.

HEADLINE: In the Shadow of Indian Point 

BYLINE:  By ALICE KENNY 

 BODY:
THE newlyweds worked two, sometimes three jobs, piecing together a down payment to buy a home in the village where they grew up. Finally last month, cash in hand, the couple, Johnna and Martin Foster, made an offer on a sturdy brick ranch but lost the house to a higher bid. So when they found a two-bedroom cape a few blocks away, they offered the full asking price, $265,900. Another bidding war. But this time they won. 
 While bidding wars have become typical in pricey Westchester County, what is surprising is that the Fosters' competition took place in Buchanan, home to Entergy Corporation's Indian Point nuclear power complex. Buchanan, a one-and-a-half-square-mile village in the town of Cortlandt, whose borders push into the Hudson River, gained national prominence Sept. 11 when an American Airlines jet passed over the power plant following the river's dark outline en route to the World Trade Center. 
 Most people living within 10 miles of the plant worry about a terrorist attack, and believe they would be unable to evacuate, according to a poll taken last month by the Riverkeeper environmental group. Residents, however, are staying put and outsiders seem to view the area as an attractive place to live. Demand for real estate outpaces availability. Patriotism, fatalism and market forces appear responsible. 
The same forces fueling the hot Westchester housing market affect the market around Buchanan. The search by New York City residents for more affordable housing puts pressure on Westchester. Low interest rates -- a little more than 7 percent for a 30-year mortgage -- also spur buyers' interest. And the lack of land to develop in Westchester creates a market where the demand for housing, any housing, far exceeds supply.
"Everybody thinks Buchanan's going to slow down and it hasn't," said Carole Kope, president of the Westchester Board of Realtors and the Fosters' sales agent at Coldwell Banker in Yorktown Heights. "Houses come on and they're gone." 
Valerie Leis, an associate broker at Coldwell Banker Perry Kennedy in Croton-on-Hudson, said: "It used to be that people would say, 'I like the house but not the kitchen, let's keep looking.' Now they say, 'It's got four walls and a roof, let's buy it before someone else does.' " 
For Mrs. Foster, 32, having a family and lifetime friends just down the road outweighed her fears about Indian Point. "Yes, it poses a danger but that's not something that's going to steer us away from staying here," she said. "This is our home. We don't want to be pushed out."
While Buchanan's relatively affordable housing allowed Mrs. Foster to stay in her hometown, New York City's robust real estate market continues to push city dwellers into the suburbs, depleting Westchester's inventory. Last month the average home for sale in Manhattan cost $920,000 compared with $760,000 the year before, according to Rismedia in Manhattan. The average single-family Westchester house sold for around $470,000, according to Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service figures. In Buchanan, single-family houses sold for an average of $205,000, according to the service.
Moving from Manhattan began as an economic decision for Justin Edelson, 26, and his fiancee, Elizabeth Hires, 27. Tired of paying $2,010 per month for their cramped Chelsea one-bedroom apartment, the couple began house hunting. Two weeks before the terrorist attacks, they found a $375,000 three-bedroom colonial house on an acre of land in Crompond, a hamlet in the town of Cortlandt, roughly five miles from Indian Point. The couple closed the deal in November, ignoring warnings from friends and families about the house's proximity to the power plant.
"I felt it was important to remain committed to the greater New York area," Mr. Edelson said. "I happen to believe that there is no place any more or less safe than any place else. Anything can happen at any time."
Steve Clausen, 33, a lifelong Buchanan resident, shares Mr. Edelson's point of view. He put his three-bedroom colonial house in Buchanan on the market in August and two months ago bought a lakefront property in the adjoining community of Verplanck. 
"Where else am I going to go?" Mr. Clausen asked. "I'm not going to pick up my family and move 2,000 miles away where it would be safe or 150 miles away and get nasty radiation burns and die of cancer. I'd rather die quick, I guess."
The terrorist attacks have not spurred an exodus from Buchanan and nearby communities. Nearly the same number of houses was up for sale in the area and took the same amount of time to sell last month as in March last year. Last year 111 houses in Buchanan, the surrounding town of Cortlandt, Peekskill and Yorktown were on the market, an average of 159 days. Last month 108 houses were for sale, staying on the market an average of 160 days.
At 11 one recent morning, Angela Lanni, a broker with the Jefferson Valley office of Houlihan/Lawrence, pushed an Open House sign into the lawn of a four-bedroom colonial in an upscale development in Cortlandt Manor. By 3:30 p.m. that day she received a full-price offer of $559,500. The next day another full-price offer came in. In 1994 when the sellers, Lori and Dominick Peraglia, bought the house they paid $289,000.
The Peraglias sold their house to buy a bigger one just down the road, not to escape the power plant situated less than five miles away. Before Sept. 11 they had planned to move across the county to Katonah. "Our commitment to staying is a direct result of Sept. 11," Mrs. Peraglia said. "It showed me what's really important, our wonderful friends and wonderful neighbors."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A house on McKinley Street in Cortlandt looks across Route 9 to the Indian Point nuclear power plant. Inset: A house on Gallagher Street in Buchanan. (Photographs by Suzy Allman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Big-City Paydays At 'Farmer Mac' 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
DURING one particularly nasty agricultural recession, as farmer after farmer was forced to abandon the land, Congress reached out to help, creating a company to offer them easier credit, the same way it had made mortgages cheaper and more plentiful for millions of homeowners.
 Fourteen years later, this obscure little company, which still depends on government guarantees, has turned into one sweet honey pot -- though not for the intended beneficiaries. What Congress publicly set up to help the country's farmers has quietly been used by its officers and directors to help themselves. 
 The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, traded on the New York Stock Exchange and known as Farmer Mac, barely makes the cut of the nation's largest 2,000 companies, ranked by market capitalization. It has all of 31 employees. Nonetheless, its chief executive, Henry D. Edelman, last year hauled home salary and stock options conservatively estimated at $1.8 million. Drawing increasingly lavish pay packages, Mr. Edelman, a former Wall Street investment banker, controls $27.6 million worth of Farmer Mac stock, even after selling $2.8 million worth since last summer. 
Farmer Mac's directors, entrusted to keep management in line, themselves got a piece of the action in 1997, when they began awarding themselves options. The 15 board members, all politically connected and including five presidential appointees, sit atop average holdings valued at $816,249. Nine have made millions more selling shares.
Without spending a dime buying stock, insiders now own 13 percent of the company -- all from stock option and restricted stock grants. An additional 2.63 million shares are available for grant, so insiders could end up with 35 percent without further authorization.
That's not all. Farmer Mac's health is somewhat dicey, and it operates with the barest of financial cushions beyond standards set by regulators.
"When I hear stories like this, I wonder how many more of these there are," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity in Washington. "This is why you have such skepticism about government, that you can create something like this and allow it to run rampant, something with $4 billion in obligations and $15 million in reserves."
Mr. Edelman does not see it that way. "I always thought Farmer Mac was a great story," he said. If he and other executives are making money, he said, "it's a result of the way management has guided the company." 
Farmer Mac is the country cousin of two much better-known government-sponsored entities, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Always far bigger, and growing by the day, they have spawned a cottage industry of critics who deride them as costly examples of government do-goodism that could backfire on taxpayers if their implied government guarantees were ever tested.
Just last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of systemic risks posed when the public sector underwrites business activities that mainly benefit the private sector -- especially if investors, creditors and others who do business with them fail to scrutinize transactions because they assume that the government will step in should the deals misfire. Government-sponsored enterprise debt, including guarantees on mortgage-backed securities, now exceeds the size of the Treasury market, government statistics show.
But almost none of that furious debate ever centers on little Farmer Mac, whose ambitions are just as big and business practices even more troubling. Many sophisticated people have never heard of it.
"It is under most people's radar," said W. David Hemingway, a Farmer Mac director.
The company seems to like it that way. Jerome G. Oslick, the $1-million-a-year general counsel for Farmer Mac, agreed to answer only questions submitted in writing. After many requests, Mr. Edelman granted a phone interview and then cut it short. And when Mr. Oslick was asked to deal with queries Mr. Edelman could not get to, he snapped, "I've worked four 10-hour days this week and I'm not sticking around." He later sent written replies.
Mr. Edelman initially agreed to be photographed, saying he'd "be flattered," but his office later reported that he was too booked.
Farmer Mac was born in 1988, part of a larger bailout for the farm industry. The nation's farmers were reeling from years of double-digit interest rates that had cost many their farms. They wanted the government to help them obtain long-term, fixed-rate agricultural loans.
The loans didn't come directly from the government. Instead, Farmer Mac bought agricultural loans made by lenders and repackaged them into tradable securities. Just as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac helped to increase the supply of low-priced mortgages by giving lenders a quick way to move them off their books, Farmer Mac's job was to build up the secondary market for agricultural loans. 
Back then, Mr. Edelman was a 39-year-old investment banker at Paine Webber whose firm was being paid $66,000 a month by Farmer Mac's board to help get the concept up and running. A lifelong New Yorker and lawyer by training, he had never spent much time on a farm. But by April 1989, the board had settled on him as Farmer Mac's president.
"Henry has received quite an education," said Stan Forbes, a retired peanut farmer who was part of Farmer Mac's first management team. "He's learned not to wear hiking books with deep cleats on livestock farms." He and his colleagues recall vividly how on one fact-finding trip to a dairy farm, Mr. Edelman insisted on helping with the artificial insemination of a cow. When he next saw the director who owned the cow, he asked about her, and the director, Bill Mainer, could not resist kidding Mr. Edelman that the cow had died, felled by the Rolex watch an autopsy discovered inside her.
UNDER its original charter, Farmer Mac handled only the safest loans, mortgages issued by banks that agreed to retain the riskiest 10 percent; it was a sleepy, money-losing business.
So, in 1996, amid talk that Washington might pull the plug, Farmer Mac instead persuaded Congress to loosen some rules that were keeping it from growing. It also talked Congress into delaying new risk-based capital requirements that had been in the works since 1991. The repeatedly delayed rules will take effect only next month.
In the meantime, Farmer Mac made the most of its freedom.
It reported its first profit in 1996 and has improved earnings every year since. Wall Street analysts pitch the stock as a "toddler" Fannie or Freddie, invoking two names that have made fortunes for investors. 
Farmer Mac does enjoy many of the same perks. It is exempt from most state and local taxes. Most of all, it pays just over half a percentage point more than the United States Treasury when it borrows.
But all that was not enough to ensure success. Initially, the company strove to issue a new bundle of standardized farm loans every 60 days. But unlike residential mortgages, farm loans are idiosyncratic. And when they trickled in too slowly to meet the goal, the company embarked on a high-wire strategy of borrowing first, lending later. The better its name recognition, Farmer Mac figured, the lower its cost of capital would be.
AT first, according to public filings, Farmer Mac plowed the extra cash into the highest-grade short-term investments, so it could shift money into farm loans as opportunities arose. But each year, Farmer Mac has assumed more risk in its investments. For instance, a footnote to the 2001 financial statements shows $166 million of preferred stock lodged in assets. Even a mere 5 percent drop in the value of those holdings could dent the scant $15 million equity cushion the company has before it would have to invade its minimum capital mandated by regulation.
This borrow-big "Field of Dreams" strategy has often prompted Farmer Mac to stray from its mission. In 1998, when two-thirds of its assets had drifted into preferred stocks, bonds and other nonfarm investments, mostly securities, the General Accounting Office criticized Farmer Mac in a report to Congress. Since then, Farmer Mac has lowered the figure to 45 percent, though it is still far higher than both Fannie's and Freddie's.
To increase returns, the company also finances many of its long-term obligations with cheaper short-term funds -- never a stable situation.
These days, nearly 70 percent of its debt financing comes from roughly $2.3 billion worth of commercial paper that rolls over every eight days, on average. To minimize risk, the maturity and yield of assets and liabilities should generally match. But most of Farmer Mac's assets are illiquid multiyear mortgages. Farmer Mac has no bank lines to draw down if the commercial paper market were to grow skittish. And by Farmer Mac's own acknowledgment, its prized government guarantee would be of no use in a squeeze.
If Farmer Mac had created a thriving secondary market for agricultural loans, none of this might matter. But that dream is still elusive. 
Even critics allow that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have created some value for homeowners by buying loans from banks, repackaging them into securities and selling them to investors, a process known as securitization. Long-term money flows from public investors to homeowners, and institutions in the middle can keep making fresh loans.
Farmer Mac started securitizing loans in earnest in 1996. But since 1998, when the collapse of a hedge fund called Long-Term Capital Management unnerved the markets, making investors extremely choosy, Farmer Mac has held more securities than it has sold. The situation was supposed to be temporary, according to Farmer Mac's 1998 annual report, but $1.6 billion of securitized loans, representing 82 percent of Farmer Mac's outstanding mortgage-backed securities, are still on its books. 
In fact, of the fee income generated by its guarantees that Farmer Mac reported as earnings, a substantial portion was money it paid itself -- 25 percent in 1999 and 19 percent in 2000 -- ostensibly to guarantee loans that never left its possession. The company would not disclose the comparable figure for 2001.
Farmer Mac has done well on Wall Street, which prefers earnings derived from fee income to those derived from more volatile interest-rate spreads. On Friday, its stock closed at $43.99, nearly 27 times trailing earnings.
But Fannie Mae, which has also had to eat its own baking on occasion, has fared even better. It has always applied conservative accounting practices, never describing as fee income the portion of income it receives for guaranteeing the securitized loans on its books. As of April 2001, when new accounting rules took effect, Farmer Mac has had to adjust to the same standard.
FARMER MAC has also diversified. When investor demand for its securitized loans cooled, it offered loans to hobbyists and part-time farmers. And it unveiled a popular product that extends a guarantee to banks on loans that never leave their books. Banks love it. For a maximum half-percentage-point annual fee, and one-fifth the regulatory capital they would otherwise need, they have no downside and keep all the profit on the loans.
These liabilities, delicately described in Farmer Mac's public filings as "long-term standby protection commitments," are off-balance-sheet obligations, and Farmer Mac now has $2.1 billion of them. They could just as easily be called "put options," because they give Farmer Mac's customers the right to "put back" bad loans to Farmer Mac.
Some of the biggest customers for these promises are lenders affiliated with Farmer Mac's directors. John Dan Raines, one of four members of Farmer Mac's audit committee, is a director of AgFirst, which received $213.3 million of these commitments last year. Paul DeBriyn, another audit committee member, is chief executive of AgStar, which received $94,700. Under stock exchange rules, audit committees must have at least three directors who have no business ties to the company unless the board deems the link immaterial. In its written response, Farmer Mac minimized the conflict.
For all the risky business practices, Farmer Mac has remained fairly immune to the few voices in Congress and the executive branch that have found fault with it over the years.
Its most stubborn critic has been Representative Richard H. Baker, a Louisiana Republican who heads a House subcommittee charged with overseeing government-sponsored enterprises, the so-called G.S.E.'s. Having seen the damage done to his home state when savings and loan institutions used government-insured deposits to venture into risky businesses, he has sought to rein in Farmer Mac and the other G.S.E.'s, without much encouragement from others on the House Financial Services and House Agriculture Committees. 
In 2000, after Mr. Baker proposed overhauling government-sponsored enterprises, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac swamped Congress with donations. He soon lost every one of his co-sponsors, according to an aide, and could not get legislation out of his subcommittee.
Farmer Mac's spending on political gifts and lobbyists pales next to that of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. But Farmer Mac found ways to play ball besides calling on friends in the farm belt. In 1989, it hired Thomas R. Clark to handle government and public relations. Mr. Clark had been an aide to Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who was, and still is, a powerful member of the Agriculture Committee.
That relationship came in handy in 1995, when Farmer Mac's relief package died and Senator Lugar salvaged it by tacking it onto other legislation. 
In December, Mr. Clark retired from Farmer Mac a rich man. He has made $5.2 million just cashing in most of his options.
Individual shareholders, confined to the "C" class of stock, have no say in the company's affairs. Voting power is held entirely by the financial institutions that own "A" and "B" shares. 
Of those, the biggest is Zions Bancorporation of Salt Lake City, which sells more loans to Farmer Mac than any other lender and has entered into interest-rate swaps with Farmer Mac that, at current rates, favor Zions. Despite those and other financial entanglements, Mr. Hemingway, as executive vice president of Zions, serves on Farmer Mac's compensation committee -- though the proxy notes that he deliberated but "did not vote upon management compensation decisions." 
Because the company ends its fiscal year in May and because the options it grants executives vest quickly, much of what shareholders glean from the proxy is too late to be of much use. Proxies arrive in April in time for annual meetings in June. By then, two-thirds of all the options listed in the proxy have already vested. 
And when these options are described, Farmer Mac suggests a very conservative value for them, assuming that they will have an expected life of five years, when executives have 10 years to use them, understating their probable value by at least 25 percent.
Farmer Mac has always been a good directorial gig. It is part time; it is a chance to serve the president without having to move to Washington, and, unlike most presidential honors, it pays. Of the five presidential appointees, whose average age is 70, four were chosen by Bill Clinton and one by Ronald Reagan. All are described in the proxy as farmers, but other credentials probably had more to do with their ascension to the board. 
One director, C. Eugene Branstool, as chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party, delivered the votes that put Bill Clinton over the top at the 1992 convention. Another, Lowell L. Junkins, managed his winning campaign in Illinois the same year. 
A third, Clyde A. Wheeler, is described in the proxy as a public affairs consultant. His former employer, the Sun Company, once described him as one of the oil industry's "most effective" lobbyists. According to Mr. Clark, Mr. Wheeler won a slot on the Farmer Mac board in 1994 after Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader at the time, told the Clinton White House that none of its other nominations would budge until Mr. Wheeler, a Republican, was added to the list.
LAST summer, President Bush got around to naming two of his candidates, Grace Trujillo Daniel and Fred L. Dailey. Their appointments are awaiting Senate confirmation. Ms. Daniel was chief deputy appointments secretary to Pete Wilson, the former governor of California. Mr. Dailey, Ohio's agricultural director, was pushed by Gov. Bob Taft in recognition of the fact that Ohio was the most populous state that President Bush carried in 2000, after Texas and Florida. 
Farmer Mac has been benefiting from low interest rates and a stable farm sector. But should the business environment change, it is hard to know how much of Farmer Mac's many guarantees, on and off the books, might turn into i.o.u.'s.
As of the latest quarter, the percentage of delinquent loans was 2.3 percent, just shy of the high of 2.6 percent reported a year earlier. But the company's definition of "delinquent" has shifted often. For instance, in late 1998 the company volunteered that past-due loans that were "in the process of collection" were not counted as delinquent. Last year, the company's language in public filings implied that all past-due loans were delinquent. Mr. Oslick, Farmer Mac's general counsel, said "the substance" of the definition had not changed in recent years.
Expanding the business so rapidly may also be masking trouble in the loan portfolio, because loans usually take a few years to sour.
Reserves, which are supposed to cushion the company against future loan losses, were a mere $15.9 million at the end of 2001. That means that Farmer Mac will have to recover at least 73 percent of the $59.6 million of the loans that have already soured -- a tall order -- or it will not have anything left to deal with other problems that emerge in its $4.5 billion in outstanding obligations.
It could increase reserves. But as of now, Farmer Mac has only that $15.5 million equity cushion over its minimum capital set by regulators.
FARMER MAC says that its reserves are adequate, and that the long-awaited risk-based capital requirements will not materially affect it either. 
Mr. Edelman, who has been known to answer tough questions from investors by looking at his watch and announcing that he has another meeting to attend, said the government was adequately shielded from trouble in the portfolio by its $137 million net worth. "We already have a lot of private equity capital at risk and they lose all their money before the government loses a penny," Mr. Edelman said. 
But even John R. Dahl, a cattleman who was its first chairman, said Farmer Mac's reason for being just might be fading. "One of the reasons for Farmer Mac was double-digit interest rates," he said. "But interest rates came down." Besides, he added, "there are getting to be fewer and fewer people in agriculture."
Two investors who shared those doubts participated in the conference call Mr. Edelman had on April 19. They said they had repeatedly pressed "*1" on their phones and received confirmation that they were in the queue to put their questions to management.
Their turn never came. After entertaining a few questions from friendly stock analysts and investors, Mr. Edelman cut off the call moments after a woman intoned, "There are no other questions at this time, sir."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Antitrust Laws an Issue In Airline Alliances

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
IT is a curious paradox that the world's airlines, which are a primary enabler of the global economy, cannot become global companies themselves. Many are international, but they are not truly global. While most corporations are free to set up shop around the world, airlines are hobbled by regulations that restrict where they can fly.
 But with their customers continenthopping more often, the world's major airlines have moved to circumvent these restrictions by forming international alliances. Three groups -- Star, SkyTeam and Oneworld -- have carved up the globe, linking airlines in the United States, Europe and Asia into giant networks that can carry passengers from Alpina, Mich., to Brussels, or from Toulouse, France, to Savannah, Ga. 
 The alliances vary in size and degree of integration but nearly all are involved in code sharing -- offering seats on one another's flights -- and allow passengers to earn frequent flier points and elite status on their home carrier when flying with alliance members. Members also offer reciprocal access to their airport lounges and in many cases have moved their operations into the same terminals to ease connections. 
In January, after the Transportation Department demanded that they give up valuable landing and takeoff rights at Heathrow Airport outside London, American Airlines and British Airways, two founding members of Oneworld, abandoned their second attempt to win an exemption from U.S. antitrust laws so they could combine their operations across the Atlantic.
The two airlines and the six other Oneworld members, including Iberia, Cathay Pacific and Lan Chile, insist that they will increase their cooperation, but some analysts are skeptical. They think that American and British Airways will have no choice but to link up with new partners, which could break up Oneworld. Without the antitrust exemption, which the key members of Star and Skyteam have, American and British Airways cannot coordinate pricing and scheduling and combine reservations and ground operations -- cost-cutting measures that are the main attractions of an alliance to airlines.
As for customers, what they want in a global alliance, said Paul Matsen, senior vice president for alliances at Delta, is easy connection by linking schedules and lounges, and global passenger recognition. 
A report issued by the Transportation Department in October 2000 concluded that alliances have led to new passenger traffic and sharply lowered fares.
For example, traffic between Birmingham, Ala., and small cities in Europe nearly doubled between 1995 and 1999 and fares declined 34 percent. Traffic more than doubled between Portland, Ore., and Europe while fares fell 33 percent, the Transportation Department says. 
The alliances have also made it cost effective for airlines to fly new routes, or to expand service on existing routes. Delta and Alitalia, two members of the SkyTeam alliance, started code-sharing on a flight between Atlanta and Milan this month, a route neither airline considered popular enough to fly alone. 
The alliances began in the early 1990's, when Washington and the big domestic airlines wanted to liberalize the scores of bilateral agreements that restricted landing rights abroad. But most foreign governments feared that more competition would undermine their flag carriers.
Negotiations with the Netherlands produced a novel compromise. Washington agreed to exempt Northwest Airlines and KLM from antitrust laws, allowing them to combine their operations across the Atlantic, if the Dutch government would open its airports to any American airline.
The deal became the model for "open skies" agreements between Washington and more than 50 countries. Antitrust immunization has been granted to several carriers, including United Airlines and Lufthansa, which formed the Star Alliance with 13 other airlines, and Delta and Air France, which belong to the six-carrier SkyTeam. 
Antitrust exemption is now seen as crucial to the success of an international alliance because it allows the airlines to coordinate their schedules and fares, combine operations, pool revenue and offer volume discounts to corporations.
That is what American and British Airways now lack. But the airlines insist that Oneworld remains competitive. "From the service perspective, we feel we are fully competitive with the other alliances," said David Cush, vice president for alliances at American.
This month American began selling seats on flights operated by Swiss, the new airline that emerged from the bankruptcy of Swissair. Swiss will also sell seats on American flights and may soon join Oneworld.
Analysts say that airline partners will gradually become more deeply enmeshed, making it much harder to switch alliances.
"I don't think we have reached the point of no return," said Chris Tarry, an airline analyst with Commerzbank in London. "Until we do, anything can happen."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Fed Ponders What to Do If It Runs Out Of Bullets

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AFTER spending 2001 confronting the first recession in a decade and the economic aftershocks of Sept. 11, Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve took some time a few months ago to ponder the possibility of another crisis.
 What options would be open to the Fed, they asked themselves at their meeting in January, if the economy suffered another blow at a time when the official interest rates controlled by the central bank were already approaching zero? 
 It was not an entirely academic question. Japan has been dealing with just such a situation for several years, with prices falling, the economy stalled and rates just a notch above nothing. 
The Fed itself has pushed official rates in the United States to their lowest level in four decades, with no assurance that the nascent recovery will continue -- and with any number of threats hanging over the outlook, including a spike in oil prices and the risk of further terrorist attacks.
If the worst happened, officials fear, the Fed would quickly run out of monetary policy ammunition, because it cannot push interest rates below zero, a self-evident limit known to economists as the "zero nominal bound." Should the economy become so weak that it experiences deflation -- a general decline in prices -- even holding interest rates steady amounts to tighter monetary policy.
To understand why, consider how economists look at interest rates during normal times. Right now, the Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks is 1.75 percent. That is what economists call the nominal rate. The inflation rate, depending on what measure is used, is somewhere in the same vicinity. 
Subtracting the inflation rate from the nominal rate yields the "real" interest rate, a better measure of the effect on the economy than the nominal rate. In this example, the real rate is around zero.
But what if prices are falling? In that case, inflation is, arithmetically speaking, negative. So if the nominal rate was 1 percent and the deflation rate was 1 percent, the real interest rate would be 2 percent.
In such a case, the economy could become prone to a deflationary spiral, in which a lack of demand, falling prices and paralysis in nominal interest rates lead to more restrictive financial conditions, weaker demand and further downward pressure on prices.
Senior Fed officials began looking in earnest at this dire, if remote, possibility at a conference in Woodstock, Vt., in October 1999. They decided to take it up again last fall, after Sept. 11, and they devoted much of the first day of their two-day meeting in late January to the topic.
They did not come to any firm conclusions on how to deal with such a situation. But they generally agreed that the best approach was to do everything possible to avoid letting the economy slip into a deflationary funk, even if that meant cutting rates more aggressively than usual as they approached zero.
In other words, the consensus was that the Fed would do better to shoot off whatever limited ammunition it had left if faced with an economic flameout, rather than to conserve its remaining rate cuts in case things became even worse later. That thinking even played a role in the Fed's decision in November to cut rates by half a percentage point rather than just a quarter of a point.
BUT what if aggressive easing does not work, and the economy is dead in the water with zero nominal interest rates? Could the Fed do anything to conduct monetary policy without cutting rates?
The minutes of the January meeting refer only to a discussion of "unconventional policy measures" whose "efficacy was uncertain." Those no doubt included trying to inject money into the financial system by buying long-term government or corporate bonds or even stocks and real estate -- steps that would be technically complex and politically explosive.
The good news is that such a crisis seems less likely now than it did a few months ago. The economy rebounded smartly in the first quarter, growing at a 5.8 percent annual rate, the government reported on Friday, and the Fed has continued to pump money into the economy, fueling concern among some analysts that the threat later this year will be of overheating.
There are even glimmers of hope from Japan, meanwhile, that it is at last pulling out of its slump, suggesting that a brush with the zero bound does not have to be terminal.
