HEADLINE: Foundations for Lower Manhattan 

 BODY:
After months of delay, there has been noticeable progress recently in plans to rebuild Lower Manhattan. Gov. George Pataki, whose name tops the list of public officials in charge, has finally sent a strong message to the various governing boards that it is time to set up a workable process for reimagining and rebuilding downtown. The focus has already begun to show in many areas, such as requests for design concepts by July for the memorial and surrounding buildings at ground zero. But the most encouraging sign is that city and state leaders have given their attention to the area's transit needs. 
 Transportation is the foundation of the revival of Lower Manhattan -- the underpinning of any real renewal. The Pataki administration's first effort at a transit plan left a sour aftertaste in Washington, since the governor's $54 billion wish list stretched as far as Schenectady. Louis Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, narrowed the possibilities considerably when he recently presented Congressional leaders with proposals for $7.4 billion in transportation fixes in the area. 
 Even that price tag struck some Washington officials as a fantasy. It is ambitious, but it at least opened a crucial conversation between Mr. Tomson's group and the people in Washington. Congressional leaders will now need to see the more detailed and artful projections about timing, cost and workability.
The most important projects, taken together, would vastly improve the flow of people through the city's downtown tangle of rail and subway lines. The first priority is a new PATH terminal that would include an underground corridor and moving walkways to a downtown transit center near Fulton Street for an estimated $2.8 billion. There is also a $400 million expansion of the South Ferry terminal linking subways to ferries. The ferries are providing emergency service for more than 60,000 people, almost the same number who took the PATH trains before the line was damaged.
Other proposals need more debate and certainly more fleshing out. They include $80 million for the "Rector connector," which would link the 1 and 9 lines to the N and R lines along Rector Street, and $2 billion to put West Street underground so that it passes under Chambers Street, making more room for a park or memorial. Another proposal would use $200 million for a study and new underground "portal" structure, which could be used if rail service was ever expanded from Long Island. Mr. Tomson's group did not include a Second Avenue subway, an expensive proposition that would relieve serious overcrowding along Manhattan's East Side. While this is a worthy project that deserves attention, it is unrealistic to expect the bill to be paid by federal funds designated to rebuild Lower Manhattan.
To start work on the most vital transit projects, Congress should shift some funds so that urban transportation experts can follow through on their next round of planning. At this point, the 1 and 9 lines are being restored with insurance money. Beyond that, President Bush has proposed only $1.8 billion in federal support for downtown transportation. Congress could start by freeing up enough of the $21 billion coming to the city to finance the most crucial transit items at a cost closer to $4.5 billion. The construction crews have virtually cleared ground zero, and Mr. Pataki and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation have begun to tackle their task. Congress needs to pitch in to make it work.

HEADLINE: The Chinese Regime's Heir Apparent 

BYLINE:  By Bates Gill; Bates Gill is a senior fellow in foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution and author of the forthcoming "Contrasting Visions: The United States, China, and World Order."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
He is the heir apparent to leadership of the world's largest country and largest standing army. He is expected to oversee a spectacular national socioeconomic transformation. Depending on your viewpoint, his country presents the United States with its greatest economic opportunities, most thorny foreign policy dilemmas or most serious long-term security challenges -- or all three. But do we know who he is?
 The vice president of China, Hu Jintao, will spend this week in the United States, meeting with President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney, the Bush administration's top foreign policy and defense advisers, and Capitol Hill leaders. It is rare for a second in charge to receive such high-level official attention. But at a relatively young 59, Mr. Hu could be pivotal to United States-China relations for the next decade or more. 
 Yet expectations about this visit should be modest. Mr. Hu is little known in the United States or elsewhere outside of China and remains an enigmatic figure even among Chinese. And there are reasons to be cautious about his future leadership.
Born in one of China's poorest provinces, Mr. Hu studied hydraulic engineering before the disastrous Cultural Revolution in the 1960's. His career has been characterized by youthful ascent through duty in remote and backward places. At 42, he was the youngest provincial governor when he took charge of Guizhou in 1985. In 1988, he was appointed to govern Tibet, where, in 1989, he oversaw the violent suppression of Tibetan unrest and then maintained control in Lhasa during the Tiananmen crisis. His tough tactics in Tibet quickly won him kudos at home, but is the reason that protesters will dog his trips abroad.
Mr. Hu's ultimate rise came out of that period of turbulence. The Communist Party was shaken by Tiananmen, and in recovering stability, saw the need to promote younger but loyal men. Mr. Hu, tapped as a star of the "fourth generation" by Deng Xiaoping, was elevated 10 years ago to the Communist Party Political Bureau Standing Committee, where he joined a handful of others -- including President Jiang Zemin, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and Li Peng, the head of National People's Congress -- at the pinnacle of power. Now he is not only vice president, but vice chairman of the Central Military Commission, a step away from leadership of the world's largest military.
Like others of his generation, he has little memory of pre-1949 China and the struggle and victory of the Chinese Communists, upon which much of the party's legitimacy stands. Instead, his formative years saw the most dreadful blunders of the Maoist era: the calamitous Great Leap Forward, the Cultural Revolution and the mad schemes of the Gang of Four.
But in succeeding in politics during the reform years after 1978, Mr. Hu had to recognize the need for China to pursue a pragmatic course. Many observers, both in China and abroad, have high expectations that he will be a reformer, leading the Chinese regime toward greater openness and political change. Those who meet him agree he cuts an impressive figure: businesslike, confident and able to speak with authority. And yet his career has been successful because he has not made waves and has been a dutiful supporter of Jiang Zemin and the top governing group.
If selected to head the government, party and military, he will need to defer at least in the early years to the "elders," especially Jiang Zemin, who is expected to step down as party chief in October and to leave the presidency next spring. Like Mr. Jiang, Mr. Hu will operate as "first among equals" in a collective, consensus-oriented leadership structure, which will include many close proteges of Mr. Jiang. Having no military experience, and having served only three years on the Central Military Commission, Mr. Hu will need to be especially careful in his relations with the People's Liberation Army. And since he is a loyal and well-vetted product of the system, his moves toward political reform are likely to be tentative.
Still, Mr. Hu may be in a stronger position than Mr. Jiang was when he took over in 1989. Mr. Jiang was considered a compromise candidate hurriedly selected in the aftermath of Tiananmen. Mr. Hu has spent a decade observing and surviving the highest reaches of political power; Mr. Jiang returned to Beijing as something of an outsider from his post as mayor of Shanghai. And Mr. Hu's endorsement by Deng gives him a distinct advantage with China's elites, who see him as a welcome change from the self-absorbed Mr. Jiang.
But of course, nothing is certain given the tortured history of anointed successors in China: Liu Shaoqi was executed in prison, a victim of the Cultural Revolution; Lin Biao was killed in a mysterious plane crash after a coup attempt; Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang were both humiliated and politically exiled for pushing political reform. Reaching for too much can be a dangerous thing.
Mr. Hu's visit is an important opportunity and a bit of a test. American diplomats will be able to take measure of the presumptive leader while conveying messages about the promise and problems in United States-China relations. Mr. Hu's performance will be keenly analyzed in Beijing. He will have to use the American stage to perform a three-part balancing act: make a good impression; adhere to core Chinese positions on touchy issues like Taiwan, human rights and missile nonproliferation; and avoid upstaging his bosses back home.

HEADLINE: Going Is Tough for Clinton Library Campaign, Backers Say 

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28 

 BODY:
Bill Clinton has reached the home stretch of his campaign to raise $200 million for his presidential library, with about $145 million pledged so far, supporters of the library say. But some supporters are concerned that Mr. Clinton, the Democratic Party's most formidable fund-raiser, is facing an uphill struggle to reach his goal, because only $21 million that has been pledged is in the bank and they expect the last $55 million to be the hardest to raise.
 "People are very worried about the library right now," said one of Mr. Clinton's longtime friends, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The farther away you get from Jan. 20, 2001, the harder it is to raise these big dollars. Fifty million is a hard nut when you no longer have the Oval Office." 
 After months of little fund-raising by Mr. Clinton and others, supporters of the library have begun gearing up for a final push to help the library meet its steep financial commitments in time for its scheduled opening in Little Rock, Ark., in 2004.
With its $200 million price, which includes the library foundation's endowment, it will be the most expensive of the country's 12 presidential libraries.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Clinton, Julia Payne, said that despite the concerns about the pace of the campaign, the former president has not had any trouble raising money or getting commitments for his library. Instead, he has devoted very little time in the last 15 months to the pursuit, focusing instead on raising money for dozens of other causes. Ms. Payne also predicted that Mr. Clinton would ultimately have no trouble raising the entire sum. 
Nonetheless, several factors have slowed the pace of commitments, including the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the furor over his last-minute pardon of Marc Rich, the fugitive commodities trader.
At a recent fund-raising dinner here for the library, Mr. Clinton seemed distracted and, in the words of one guest, "a little peeved." His spokeswoman said Mr. Clinton was exhausted after a long day of speeches and events. But some guests took his mood as a sign that all was not well with the campaign.
One of the 40 guests, most of whom were ambassadors during the Clinton administration, offered to help jump-start the fund-raising effort. Since the dinner, several prominent Democratic fund-raisers have expressed concern about the library foundation's financial health.
Last weekend, Mr. Clinton's friend Skip Rutherford held a two-day retreat in Little Rock to help organize the final push for contributions.
"We went over the 2002 fund-raising plan, and we looked at 2003 and 2004, where we are and where we need to be, what's been working and what needs fine-tuning," Mr. Rutherford said.
Most of the donations for the library have come from public sources, though large sums have been committed by several foreign governments, including Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. Both nations also contributed to former President George Bush's $83 million presidential library on the campus of Texas A&M University in College Station.
The largest donations are being solicited by Terry McAuliffe, one of Mr. Clinton's closest friends and chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Rutherford is supervising the small-donor direct-mail campaign and efforts to raise money from Arkansans. Last month, the foundation hired Warwick Sabin as director of development to concentrate on donations of $5,000 to $100,000.
Mr. Clinton's supporters acknowledge that the efforts to raise money were sidetracked last year, and said that was by Mr. Clinton's choice. They said he believed that it would be inappropriate to press for large donations in the months after he left office after the House Committee on Government Reform, led by Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican, subpoenaed records of all contributions and pledges of more than $5,000 to the library foundation.
Several longtime fund-raisers for Mr. Clinton said the Rich pardon had hampered fund-raising efforts. 
"The damage was awful," one supporter said. "It's hard to raise money when you have a grand jury subpoenaing documents from the library foundation." 
Ms. Payne, the Clinton spokeswoman, said: "If some people are concerned about not giving because they are still angry about the Marc Rich situation, we understand that. But people should look at the president's work during his post-presidency on religious and racial reconciliation, economic empowerment and citizen service here and around the world." Mr. Clinton has devoted himself to helping other causes raise large sums of money, she said.
Since leaving office 15 months ago, Mr. Clinton has attended 116 fund-raising events for the Democratic National Committee and other nonprofit organizations. He has helped raise money for a wide array of causes, including Emily's List, a national organization that supports candidates who are women and favor abortion rights, and the Rainbow PUSH coalition, which is led by the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
After the terrorist attacks, Mr. Clinton and former Senator Bob Dole established an education fund for the victims' children that is close to meeting its goal of $100 million. Mr. Clinton is to attend 10 fund-raising events for other groups in May.
Maggie Williams, chief of staff to Mr. Clinton, said, "From a common-sense point of view, the idea that he would have trouble raising money for his own library and no trouble raising money for the rest of the civilized world is kind of crazy."

HEADLINE: Walk Back The Cat 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Intelligence analysts have a technique to reveal a foreign government's internal dissension called "walking back the cat." They apply what they now know as fact against what their agents said to expect. In that way, walkers-back learn who "disinformed" or whose mistake may reveal a split in a seemingly monolithic hierarchy. 
 Let us apply that examination in hindsight to a front-page article in last Thursday's New York Times with the headline "Arab Politics; Saudi to Warn Bush of Rupture Over Israel Policy." The source was identified only as a "person close to the crown prince" and "a person familiar with the Saudi's thinking." 
 The reporter, Patrick Tyler, is among the most experienced foreign correspondents in the business. Pat has resisted manipulation and seen through deceit during years in Moscow and Beijing, and we can trust his description of the Saudi source and the accuracy of the quotations. 
On the eve of the royal visit to President Bush at his Texas ranch, the "person close to Abdullah" declared that the crown prince would tell the president that unless U.S. support for Israel's military policies was moderated, the strategic relationship between their two countries would be threatened. The source warned "there was talk within the Saudi royal family and in Arab capitals of using the 'oil weapon' against the United States, and demanding that the United States leave strategic military bases in the region." Worse, "if that means we move to the right of bin Laden, so be it; to the left of Qaddafi, so be it; or fly to Baghdad and embrace Saddam like a brother, so be it."
Tough talk, but as we saw only a day later, the "expected" threats were not delivered. On the contrary, official spokesmen assured the world that no such "oil weapon" or booting-out of Americans was discussed. Instead, an eight-point Saudi memo was leaked restating positions the prince has taken for months. Rather than agree to the uncompromising terms, Bush spoke of a strong personal bond that he had developed with the prince. (When diplomatic stock falls, bond.) 
Now to walk back the cat. Here are some possibilities: 
1. The Saudi source was an uninformed hothead, speaking with no authorization from anyone close to the ruler, deliberately misleading us with no concern about the effect his smoke-blowing would have on his credibility. Highly unlikely. 
2. The Saudi source was indeed "familiar with" Abdullah's thinking, but that thinking changed radically in the day or two between the time the source spoke to the reporter and the time the Saudi ruler spoke to the president. Also unlikely. 
3. The Saudi source was acting on Abdullah's direct instructions to panic the president into one-sidedly denouncing the Israelis and treating Yasir Arafat as victim rather than terrorist. In this scenario, Saudi threats to the U.S. economy and military deployment would be issued but not attributed, allowing the crown prince to get the intimidating benefit of a threat he was too sly or squeamish to deliver personally. Possible. Or -- 
4. The Saudi source (and I'll never ask my colleague who it was, because the rule of background is more absolute than the rule of Saudi rulers) was trying to push Abdullah into getting tough with Bush. By putting out semiofficial word that Abdullah was "expected to tell" the president that America's oil supply and troop deployment were in jeopardy, he was putting pressure on the crown prince to issue just those warnings. 
That last cat walk is the most intriguing. It suggests that the Saudi leadership is not a monolith -- that those masters of manipulation, Prince Bandar and his powerful father, Defense Minister Sultan, disagree with Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal and with Adel al-Jubeir, the courtier who jumped from the Bandar camp into Abdullah's. 
Could it be that a struggle for power in Riyadh is being revealed? Last week's false "expectation" suggests that some royal sponsors of payoffs to terrorists worry most about losing control to bin Laden and rabble-rousers, while others near the throne worry most about losing U.S. military protection and markets if the kingdom pushes the U.S. too hard. 
As a result of the Saudi disinformation campaign, we can no longer be so certain which faction is in charge in Riyadh.

HEADLINE: At City Hall, Hot Debate On Tax Rise 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
When people talk about the causes of New York City's nearly $5 billion budget deficit -- that's billion, as in a five with nine zeroes after it -- they usually talk about the recession, the attack on the World Trade Center, and city spending that has risen faster than the rate of inflation in recent years.
 But a large chunk of the city's shortfall is, by some reckonings, self-inflicted: tax cuts enacted since 1995 will cost the city about $2.6 billion next year. 
 Now the question of whether the city should re-raise taxes is perhaps the most hotly debated issue in city government. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says no, with the exception of a steep cigarette tax. The City Council says yes, and is calling for an income tax increase to pay for new schools. 
Even with the $2.6 billion in tax cuts, New York remains the most highly taxed big city in the nation, according to the city's nonpartisan Independent Budget Office. The Giuliani administration cited the tax cuts as one of the reasons the city's economy boomed in the late 1990's. The economy was so strong then, and incomes rose so fast, that the city was able to collect more in taxes and spend more on services, even as it cut taxes.
Now that the economy is not so hot and tax revenue is down, with vital services like the Police and Fire Departments and the schools facing budget cuts, some fiscal watchdogs are pointing to those tax cuts as a source of the city's current fiscal woes.
"With the economy contracting, tax cuts that seemed affordable before now appear to be contributing to the city's substantial budget imbalance," warned a report released last month by the New York State Financial Control Board, which oversaw the city's budgets during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and now monitors them.
The issue, to tax or not to tax, inspires passionate arguments not only between the executive and legislative branches of government, but between business and labor groups, conservative and liberal groups, and economists.
Those against higher taxes argue that they would drive businesses and residents away just as the city is struggling to retain them. 
"You can't tax your way out of the problem," said Edmund J. McMahon Jr., a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research and policy center. "It will drive down the economy."
Those in favor of raising taxes argue that service cuts would pose an even greater risk of driving businesses and residents away, and add that the city should not cut services for its poorest residents without also asking sacrifices of the wealthy.
Glenn Pasanen, the associate director of City Project, a liberal public policy group, says that deep service cuts would endanger the quality of city life.
"It seems to us that it is just as likely that businesses would leave because of poor services: a poor educational system, poor housing, poor maintenance of bridges and roads, public safety issues," he said.
It is a sharp divide in a city where, more than most places, the phrase "tax and spend" has not always had negative connotations. And New York has unique spending requirements: it is the only major city that must pay a large share of the cost of public and medical assistance, costs usually covered by the state and federal governments. Several recent polls have suggested that New Yorkers would be open to some tax increases. But Mr. Bloomberg says he does not govern by polls.
The mayor has made three main arguments against raising taxes.
The first is pragmatic. To raise most taxes, the city must first get permission from the State Legislature, and Mr. Bloomberg notes that it is simply not realistic to expect state officials to approve tax increases in an election year. But critics say that this could, in effect, become a self-fulfilling prophesy: if you do not ask, they say, you will not receive. 
The mayor has dismissed such arguments. "Some people would say, 'Well, if you don't ask, you'll never find out,' " he said this month when he released his budget. "I have had extensive talks. I do not think in an election year there is any chance of Albany letting us raise taxes with the one exception of the cigarette tax."
Mr. Bloomberg's second argument is that taxes would dampen the city's economy, a theme he has hit on since his first day in office. "We cannot drive people and business out of New York," he proclaimed in his inaugural address. "We cannot raise taxes. We will find another way."
Experts of different ideological stripes differ on how damaging taxes are to the economy. Mr. McMahon, of the Manhattan Institute, estimates that one in four jobs created in the city since 1993 can be attributed to economic activity spurred by tax cuts.
But a report by the Fiscal Policy Institute, a liberal research organization, says that the connection between tax increases and job loss in New York City is overstated, because in the past the city has tended to raise taxes when its economy faltered, so the underlying weak economy probably caused much of the job loss. And a report by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal policy group based in Washington, concluded that tax increases on high-income families were less damaging to the economy than reductions in government spending on goods and services.
But Timothy J. Bartik, a senior economist at the Upjohn Institute, a nonpartisan research center based in Michigan that studies employment issues, noted, "The effects of taxes on jobs might vary quite a bit from suburb to suburb, city to city, or even for the same city at different periods in time."
Mr. Bloomberg's third argument against raising taxes is that a tax increase could lead the credit rating agencies to downgrade the city's bond ratings, and possibly lead to a takeover of the city's finances by the State Financial Control Board. Instead of raising taxes, the mayor's plan calls for borrowing $1.5 billion to help pay for the city's operating expenses, a practice usually frowned on by fiscal experts.
"And if the rating agencies saw you raise taxes as well as borrow, you would find you would lose your rating, which would dramatically increase our debt service cost, may freeze us out of the municipal markets, would start a control period," Mr. Bloomberg said recently.
Several ratings agency analysts disputed that, saying that higher taxes would not necessarily trigger a downgrade. One of them, Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service, said: "We are concerned about structural budget balance. We are indifferent as to which side of the budget equation is used: It can be done either on the revenue side, on the expenditure side, or both."
Taxes are sure to be in the center of budget negotiations between the mayor and the City Council, which must pass the budget in June for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, maintains that people are more likely to leave the city because of its troubled school system than because of a tax increase. The Council wants to earmark an income tax surcharge to pay for new schools. But the mayor wants control of the school system before he fights to get more money for it, aides say. 
The Council has no control over the two main taxes it wants to raise: the income tax surcharge, and the re-imposition of the commuter tax on people who work in the city but live elsewhere. Both actions would have to be approved in Albany.
And the Council has not proposed raising the one tax that it could raise without Albany's help: the property tax, whose rate has been frozen for a decade. Mr. Miller said he would prefer to raise the income tax so it could be staggered to hit the poor and middle class less.
Strictly speaking, neither tax that the Council is proposing would close the budget gap. The Council wants to borrow $5 billion to build new schools, and to use the $400 million that would be generated each year by its proposed income tax surcharge to pay off the debt. And it wants to use the $400 million to $500 million it expects from a re-instatement of the commuter tax to reduce the size of the $1.5 billion in borrowing that the mayor has proposed.
The budget math for the future is unforgiving. Even if Mr. Bloomberg is able to close the current deficit without resorting to higher taxes, he will still face larger deficits in the next few years projected to grow to more than $6 billion in 2006.
Perhaps this is why the mayor has taken to speaking about the difficulty in raising taxes "this year."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
On the Holding Of Coats, And Tongues

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
CANDIDATE Cuomo's camp, in a defensive mode since Andrew M. Cuomo described Gov. George E. Pataki as a valet, has come up with a creative notion for why the remark drew near-universal ire -- not because it was off the mark, as detractors contended, but because Sept. 11 has put even constructive criticism of the incumbent governor off limits.
 The very concept of a New York campaign turning into an exercise in eggshell-treading sounds a little like predicting that the Atlantic will be as calm as a lake all summer. Could Mr. Cuomo and his opponent in the Democratic primary for governor, H. Carl McCall, really be forced to practice rhetorical restraint? The larger question is whether the catastrophe of last September has changed the public dialogue altogether, whether certain people are considered unassailable and certain subjects unapproachable. 
 Short answer: no. The long answer: oh come on.
Just a cursory look at New Yorkers over the last several months suggests some course corrections, but no inclination to rewrite the rules of political engagement. 
Some things really have changed, especially the tendency to denigrate police officers after the torture of Abner Louima in a Brooklyn station house and the shooting death of the unarmed Amadou Diallo in the Bronx. Police officers won new respect; they, along with the always popular firefighters and other emergency workers, became national heroes. 
But even newfound respect for the police probably does not mean that if an allegation of police misconduct emerged tomorrow, the public would ignore it because of a groundswell of good will in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
Same with politicians, if not more so. Mr. Pataki's popularity rose significantly after the attack, polls show. But so did President George H. W. Bush's standing during the gulf war. Then he lost to Bill Clinton. 
The public's memory is notoriously short, and its sophistication can be notably nuanced. It is worth recalling that most New Yorkers opposed former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's pursuit of an extended term last year, despite their regard for his masterly leadership during the city's crisis.
Given that precedent, there seems little chance New Yorkers would object if either Mr. Cuomo or Mr. McCall questioned Governor Pataki's record on health care, the budget, education, contributions to improving the flagging upstate economy or role in rebuilding Lower Manhattan.
SO why the outcry when the eager Mr. Cuomo said that Mr. Pataki stood in Mr. Giuliani's shadow and "held the leader's coat" after Sept. 11? Objections centered as much on substance as on tone; what Mr. Cuomo said was at odds with the prevailing assessment of the governor.
Mr. Pataki did not show the commanding leadership that Mr. Giuliani did, but though he and the mayor had not had a good relationship, the governor seemed to deliberately and generously defer to the mayor. And though he made that embarrassing request for $54 billion from Washington for pork-filled aid, he also gave the city what it needed, like the authorization to break borrowing limits and quick public access to Medicaid.
With his insult, Mr. Cuomo sounded as though he was trying to take political advantage of the city's suffering. It was a bit like the campaign incident last year when a mayoral contender, Mark Green, was widely ridiculed for boasting that he would have done "as well or better" than Mr. Giuliani did guiding the city in the aftermath of the terrorist attack. He sounded brash, as Mr. Cuomo did this year.
The public does not like candidates to be brash about sensitive subjects, but that does not mean, as the Cuomo defense would have it, that Sept. 11 is above politics. It's just that, like race and religion, it is one of those sensitive subjects that force politicians to be on firm ground before they speak out.
"With respect, Andrew picked the wrong topic," said Maureen Connelly, a consultant who advised Michael R. Bloomberg during his campaign last year. "9/11 does not exempt any elected or appointed official from criticism. We still have a democracy; elected and appointed officials are still accountable for their actions. You can criticize anybody. It's up to the press and the public to determine if it's appropriate."
Which is what happened with the one-liner about the coat, and why Mr. Cuomo quickly shifted his language to focus on Mr. Pataki's leadership of the rebuilding effort. Could be that the campaign will be a tribute to substance, for once. Then again, the Atlantic is not and never has been calm.

HEADLINE: As Elections for Governor Loom, G.O.P. Leaders Worry 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis. 

 BODY:
Republicans' eight-year domination of governorships could end this fall, party leaders say, and they fear such a turn would carry serious consequences for other Republicans in November and hinder President Bush's re-election drive in 2004.
 Many Republicans are even predicting that considerable losses for the party in November are inevitable, particularly in the Midwest, which for nearly a decade has been a stronghold for Republican governors. 
 Of the 36 governor's offices at stake this year, 23, or nearly two-thirds, are held by Republicans. Party officials concede that they could lose governorships in Michigan, in Illinois and here in Wisconsin. Polls show that Republicans also face daunting battles in Pennsylvania, Tennessee, New Mexico, Arizona, Kansas and Rhode Island -- all states with Republican governors. 
"We'll have a tough time keeping what we've got, there isn't any doubt," said Clinton Key, executive director of the Republican Governors Association.
The discouraging outlook for Republicans, who have the governorships of every major electoral powerhouse except California, stems partly from past triumphs. In 1994, when Newt Gingrich led Republicans to seize control of the House, they also swept a majority of governorships. In 1998, many of those governors were re-elected.
This year, some of them are not allowed to run again because of term limits. Some governors have moved to other jobs, including in the Bush cabinet. Still others who are seeking re-election face economic storms that could imperil their chances.
Some officials expressed fear that voters may have tired of Republicans who arrived in office with heady promises of reform. They also said some voters might question whether Republicans are the best qualified to address budget tribulations.
The states where polls show Democrats are most endangered are not considered particularly critical on the electoral map: Alaska, Hawaii and New Hampshire. In the race for the most prized governorship, that of California, the White House had backed a losing candidate in the Republican primary and party officials now say it will be difficult, but not impossible, to oust Gov. Gray Davis. 
At the top of the list of endangered Republican incumbents, Mr. Key said, is Gov. Scott McCallum of Wisconsin, who moved up from lieutenant governor after Gov. Tommy G. Thompson resigned in February 2001 to become Mr. Bush's health and human services secretary.
First elected governor in 1986, Mr. Thompson had loomed as an enormously popular figure who had drawn sufficient support from moderates and Democrats to win re-election easily.
The climate is not so hospitable for Mr. McCallum. Many polls have shown him trailing likely Democratic opponents, although the most recent poll shows that he would run neck and neck with the two best known of his four potential Democratic rivals: Jim Doyle, the attorney general, and Representative Thomas M. Barrett. Moreover, Mr. McCallum's unfavorable ratings are higher than his favorable ratings.
In a sign of the uneasiness that has engulfed his organization, Mr. McCallum's two senior strategists and his chief fund-raiser quit recently, concerned about how the campaign was being run. A few days earlier, Mr. McCallum fired his chief of staff. 
Republicans here so miss Mr. Thompson that some commissioned a poll to see how he would do if he quit the cabinet and ran again for governor against his successor.
"Just my luck," Mr. McCallum replied when asked in an interview if he felt cheated that he became governor at a time of economic crisis.
Since he was not elected in his own right, Mr. McCallum noted, he had no honeymoon with voters, the news media and the Legislature.
"Lieutenant governors are very low-visibility," Mr. McCallum said. "In my case, particularly," because of "a very active, very dominating governor." He was speaking in his high-ceilinged Capitol office, which is remarkably uncluttered, as if he were a temporary occupant -- a marked change from when Mr. Thompson covered the office with stacks of papers and files accumulated over the years.
In 14 years in Mr. Thompson's shadow, Mr. McCallum, 51, who is most animated when chatting about coaching his children's sports teams, never established much of a political identity of his own. He and Mr. Thompson were not close, so the former governor never helped prepare his lieutenant to take over.
"With Thompson, he was never given anything substantial to do," said Don Kettl, a political science professor at the University of Wisconsin. "It's the Republicans' worst nightmare: McCallum came in without name recognition, without a real record and on the heels of Tommy Thompson's popularity. And then he's facing all these problems."
Mr. McCallum inherited a budget deficit of more than $1 billion. He addressed it by proposing deep cuts in aid to local governments, infuriating municipal and county leaders. He defends his approach, saying he would not dare raise taxes.
Mr. Thompson would have faced similar budget difficulties if he were still governor, Mr. McCallum said, adding that his predecessor "said he would have made many of the same decisions I made."
Asked if Mr. Thompson would have enjoyed more good will from the voters, Mr. McCallum said he would not speculate, but added, "Maybe they'd be more open to say it's time for a change."
White House officials say they are focused on Wisconsin because Mr. Bush would stand a better chance of capturing this state in 2004 if there was a Republican governor whose state operation could help the ticket. The last Republican presidential contender to carry Wisconsin was Ronald Reagan in 1984. But White House officials say it is in reach: Al Gore barely won Wisconsin in 2000 with 47.8 percent, to 47.6 percent for Mr. Bush. That explains why Mr. Bush traveled here in February in one of his first fund-raisers since Sept. 11 to raise about $1 million for Mr. McCallum.
Mr. McCallum has responded to criticism from many Republicans that he initially surrounded himself with advisers who were not ready to run the state. Mr. Bush's advisers said they welcomed the governor's decision to install Darrin Schmitz as his campaign manager. Mr. Schmitz, a former Thompson aide, is close to the White House; he ran the Bush campaign in Wisconsin in 2000.
"He's had some relatively new and less experienced people and decided to make some changes," said Jim Klauser, a utilities executive who for years was Mr. Thompson's top adviser. Contrasting Mr. McCallum to his old boss, he said: "It's hard to follow in someone's footsteps. Remember the coaches that followed Vince Lombardi? It's not easy to do." Mr. Klauser added: "The next governor will be measured by how hard Tommy worked. He was everywhere."
Mr. McCallum is not quite as attuned to business of the state as his predecessor, and he was known for his regular afternoon basketball games when he was the No. 2. He said, "My mantra has been that if President Bush runs two hours a day, why shouldn't I be able to play basketball two times a week?"
As evidence of how little Mr. McCallum has to run on, his aides issued a roster of his accomplishments in 2001. But the first item on the list was that he "held three historic inaugural events," including "the first ever" in Fond du Lac and Milwaukee. 
Democrats are savoring their opportunities. Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, said his party was in a commanding position in part because of "just the serendipity of the numbers." But he said there were enormous implications because "with great deference to many U.S. senators, the states in the last two decades have been the incubators for future presidential candidates."
Reviewing the landscape, Mr. Glendening said: "We should regain a majority. The question is, how many? At minimum we should pick up four; at best seven."
Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said of the governors' races: "That's going to be our greatest win this year. This is our biggest strategy for '04: winning governorships." 
Mindy Tucker, the communications director of the Republican National Committee, who was an official in Mr. Bush's campaign, said she was worried that the party was more preoccupied with winning back the Senate.
Of the governors' contests, Ms. Tucker said: "This is an impossible task for us and not everybody is focused on it because they're spending so much time on the Senate. The Republican governors were a large force in the president's election in 2000 and would be in 2004. They're also important policywise because much of what we're doing on welfare and other things is returning power to the states."
Mr. McCallum insisted that he was not shrinking from taking painful steps to improve his political position. He confirmed a report in The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel about the exchange he recently had when he fired Mike Rogowski as his chief of staff.
"Who did this to me?" Mr. McCallum said his aide asked him at a private meeting.
"I did," the governor responded.

HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH/Eric J. Heller; 
Not-So-Quantum Leap From Physics to Art

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA DREIFUS 

 BODY:
For years, Dr. Eric J. Heller, 56, fostered Walter Mitty-ish fantasies of someday emerging as an acclaimed visual artist. Between his regular scientific work for institutions like Los Alamos, Harvard and U.C.L.A., Dr. Heller managed to win for himself occasional showings of his landscape paintings and photos.
None of the exhibitions, however, led to much. Indeed, for many years, Dr. Heller could best be described as a scientist with a serious hobby.
 Then, in the mid-1980's, while employed at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, Dr. Heller began creating something new. Using recently developed computer technologies as his paintbrush, he started making images of his visions of the physical world. 
 The pieces, often resembling 1960's Op Art, began to be shown to gatherings of scientists around the country and attracting critical attention.
"Eric Heller is drawn to the subatomic world the way Monet was drawn to water lilies," Harvey Blume, the critic, wrote in Art New England after viewing a show. "Electron flow, subatomic collisions, the being and nothingness of quantum foam these are the abiding concerns, the haystacks and sunsets of his art."
Dr. Heller, who still works at his day job as a physics professor at Harvard spoke over coffee in New York. His most recent show, "Approaching Chaos," is at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington until May 12. It then travels to the Chicago Academy of Sciences.

Q. As a child, did you want to be a scientist or an artist?

A. Scientist. I had a famous father, Walter W. Heller, John F. Kennedy's chief economist. Though I admired my father, I wanted to do something different from what he did. I was good at math and science, and my father, paradoxically, was not. You'd think that an economist would be. He was good at numbers. But that's different from calculus.
At first, I wanted to be a biochemist. But when I studied physics, I abandoned biology. I loved the simplicity of physics, the feeling that I could understand almost everything about a problem.

Q. Did you want to be Richard Feynman?

A. I would have loved to have been. He was mathematically brilliant and had the most amazing physical intuition. But he wasn't the one I was exposed to. It was Julian Schwinger, because I did my graduate studies at Harvard. Schwinger and Feynman shared the Nobel Prize with Sin-Itiro Tomonaga in 1965 for basically the same kind of development.
But Schwinger's approach was extremely formal and mathematical, and Feynman's was almost intuitive and visual. He invented the Feynman diagrams, which are beautiful ways of depicting interactions between particles. Schwinger rarely used pictures, and the story goes that he forbade the use of the Feynman diagrams at Harvard.

Q. What kind of physics do you do?

A. I'm sort of a low-energy physicist. I'm concerned with ordinary energies, not the kind of things that are done with accelerators. I've worked on quantum corrals, which are beautiful things invented by Don Eigler at I.B.M. They are made by moving atoms around one at a time and building tiny fences. So I worked on a theory of those, explaining the electron wave patterns that are seen in quantum corrals.
I love quantum mechanics, and all that I've done has been based on matter really being a wave and trying to understand the implications of that. My work has mostly been with what are called "semiclassical approximations."
This involves trying to understand quantum mechanics by using the previous theories of classical mechanics. We've learned to go from the ray tracing of the trajectories or particle paths of the classical mechanics of the 19th century to the wave mechanics of the 20th century.

Q. At what point in your physics career did you start making art?

A. When I was out at U.C.L.A., teaching in the 1970's. I was doing oil paintings and photography, mostly Western landscapes. In my free time, I had shows. I even sold work.
By the late 70's, I took a job at Los Alamos because I wanted to do more art and check out the New Mexico art scene, which turned out to be tough to break into. I had no serious art credentials. And there were no bridges between the scientific and the art world. 
At Los Alamos, however, by accident, I found myself building my own bridge by doing better and better graphics to explain my science. As I was doing this, I kept wondering if there was any real interaction between the science and the art?
And indeed, it turned out, there was. In making more refined diagrams about the science, I discovered new phenomena. For instance, I found this phenomenon called "scarring," where quantum waves bear definite "scars" of classical trajectories, by doing artistic rendering of data. 
I was -- and still am -- studying something called "random waves," which are an aspect of quantum chaos that happens when waves come in from all directions at once. People knew the properties of these waves mathematically. But they had never actually looked at the waves. I made pictures and found some amazing things and then published papers about them. 
So by 1985, I was thinking, O.K., I'm a scientist, but I can have fun and even do science while making these images. 

Q. Tell us about your artistic work methods?

A. The best images come serendipitously. I'm working on some scientific principle, some project, and I notice that the visualization has some possibilities. I stop working on the science and start doing images, instead.
The images are first seen on a computer screen. I take this data and render it in various ways, experimenting. There is a point when I say, "I'm stopping now in making pictures for my scientific article, and I am doing art."

Q. Do your pictures transform themselves?

A. They have a life of their own. There's a certain thing about nature which I love. It's the way nature repeats itself in many different contexts and on many different scales. A simple example would be the "electron flow" image series I've made.
It looks like so many other things I've seen: land forms, looking through curtains of kelp. It's as if the electron flows mimic a medium of some sort that does some of the drawing for me just as watercolors, with skilled use, can mimic many objects we recognize without much effort.
So, I think that in some sense the physics I'm investigating becomes a medium through which I can create images.

Q. Many professional scientists have said to me, "If only people could see what I see, they'd understand science better." Is that what you are trying to do?

A. That's exactly what I am trying to do. It's a little like the artist Albert Bierstadt, whose 19th-century paintings of the American West became well known in Europe. Through hard work and effort, he got to see things that Europeans couldn't easily see, but through his eyes they could. I feel like I'm doing that. I feel that through hard work and effort I am able to see these wonderful aspects of nature and I want other people to see what I can see.
Through art one can sometimes get straight to the essence of the matter and almost get an intuitive comprehension that might otherwise take years of study.

Q. Are you saying to the viewer, "This is what the invisible parts of the universe look like"?

A. Of course, I can't actually. This is why it's "art." Someone else could come up with a different representation of what they think this looks like.

Q. So you are saying, "This is what I believe this stuff looks like"?

A. No. I don't believe it looks like exactly what I'm doing. I have an emotional response. It's based loosely on what is "really" happening. I want the viewer to have that same feeling and emotion.

Q. John Maeda, the M.I.T. computer artist, has claimed that in the future all artists will have to be computer programmers. Do you agree?

A. I hope not. But I am one. All the images are created originally from some low-level computer program. In other words, it is written by hand to create data. Almost all of it I've written myself. Only later, much later, when I'm adding the final touches, I might use Photoshop.

Q. What do your Harvard colleagues think about your beautiful new career?

A. Ten years ago, I would have gotten a lot of skepticism and wondering, "Is this guy flaking out?" But people see me working hard and publishing, as well as doing this art. They've been supportive. Besides, everyone recognizes how important science communication is.
The National Science Foundation actually requires you to write into your grant proposals how you intend to communicate your work to the public. So my colleagues think, If Heller can communicate to a broader public through art, that's great.

Q. Do you feel you are happier now that your second career is thriving?

A. I'm a busier person. There was a moment at the opening of the first show where there were about 100 people milling around the gallery, examining my images with the same intensity that I had studied other people's work, and then it suddenly hit me: I am an artist!
You know what, that was like a lifelong ambition satisfied in a few moments. I loved it. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Eric J. Heller, a physics professor, with one of his works. His show, "Approaching Chaos," is in Washington and will move to Chicago. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nothing's Easy for New Orleans Flood Control 

BYLINE:  By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS 

 BODY:
Caught between the Mississippi and the long shoreline of Lake Pontchartrain, this low-lying city has long depended on levees and luck.
 Now engineers say those are not enough to protect New Orleans, much of it below sea level, from a devastating flood that could threaten it if a storm surge from a powerful hurricane out of the Gulf of Mexico propelled a wall of water into the lake and the city. 
 That event could place vast sections under 20 feet or more of water, engineers and scientists say, with worst-case computer predictions showing death tolls in the tens of thousands with many more people trapped by high water that has no natural drainage outlets.
"There's no way to minimize the amount of devastation that could take place under such circumstances," warned Walter S. Maestri, director of emergency management of Jefferson Parish, a suburban region with 455,000 residents on the city's western and southern sides.
Perhaps the surest protection is building up the coastal marshes that lie between New Orleans and the sea and that have been eroding at high rates. But restoration will require time, a huge effort and prohibitive sums of money, perhaps $14 billion, according to a study by a panel from federal and state agencies, universities and business. 
Engineers are considering other ways to protect the heart of the city and provide an island of refuge in the French Quarter and government centers. Though such approaches are less expensive, they come with their own problems. One plan involves walling off an area to keep out water. But where would the wall be built and who would benefit from it? 
Many residents give little thought to such matters, counting on the knowledge that New Orleans has escaped hurricane disaster in the past.
The most nervous people are those paid to worry about such things, like Dr. Joseph N. Suhayda, director of the Louisiana Water Resources Research Institute at Louisiana State University. Like other coastal researchers, he has been using the latest geological and meteorological data to refine computer models of how different storms would damage the city.
On a bright spring day with fair skies and no trace of the sultry air that will dominate the weather in the months ahead, Dr. Suhayda and a few colleagues drove city streets 1,000 yards from levees that hold back Lake Pontchartrain.
At New York Avenue, near the lakefront campus of the University of New Orleans, the car stopped, and the engineer walked over and unfolded a wood measuring stick to its 25-foot length. He planted one end on the pavement and raised it until it was vertical. The other end poked into the sky well above a corner light pole, but it was still well beneath the level of a concrete wall that rose on top of a grassy slope 100 feet away.
"Behind that," Dr. Suhayda said, indicating the wall, "is a canal that runs into Lake Pontchartrain. Its surface is roughly about the same as the lake's surface."
In a hypothetical situation projected by his computers, Dr. Suhayda continued, a slow-moving Category 4 hurricane, with winds up to 155 miles an hour, or a Category 5 hurricane with even stronger winds could leave water 30 feet deep on this neighborhood street, which is more than five feet below sea level. Though Category 5 hurricanes are very rare, Camille in 1969 devastated Pass Christian, Miss., just 50 miles east of New Orleans, and killed scores of residents with winds that exceeded 200 miles an hour and a 35-foot storm surge.
In most areas vulnerable to hurricanes, the water would drain away quickly. That is not the case here.
So city planners and engineers continue to work on ways to improve an evacuation plan for the 1.3 million residents in the metropolitan region and to soften a storm's blow. Most long-term projects intended to blunt a hurricane involve slowing the loss of marshlands. One method calls for additional control gates to let the Mississippi pour sediment-rich water into surrounding lands, a process that would eventually raise or at least maintain their elevation.
Other proposals are to rebuild eroded offshore barrier islands, erect a wall of levees across much of the lower delta, plug the dredged containership channel that gives the Gulf of Mexico waters easy access to the vulnerable eastern shore of Lake Pontchartrain and help defend that shore with higher flood gates.
Perhaps the most unconventional is the "community haven" concept advanced by Dr. Suhayda and others in the belief that radical remedies may be necessary to soften a knockout punch by nature. More theory than an organized campaign, it envisions a two-story-high wall with flood gates at crucial intersections to seal off the southern part of the city from a bend in the river at the French Quarter to another one eight miles west.
If the rest of the city flooded, Dr. Suhayda said, the "island" between the wall and the river's levees could become a refuge for thousands of residents fleeing their homes, as well as preserving the cultural and government center.
But obtaining the money on the scale needed is far tougher than devising plans, especially if some skeptics dismiss the worst-case predictions as scare tactics to help finance university research or for further environmental intrusions on the coast.
Researchers, though, say they are not making up the city's potential peril, which arises from geology and history. As tight as a pimento in an olive, most of New Orleans is stuffed between the Mississippi and the lake, and it is settling as fast as the rest of the delta or faster, said Dr. Roy Dokka, a geologist at Louisiana State.
Although much agonizing has gone into problems of the river, and its metaphoric temperaments have become part of songs and folklore, it is the 300-square-mile lake that troubles him, Dr. Dokka said.
As New Orleans grew as a seaport, petrochemical hub, tourist destination and cultural phenomenon, neighboring marshes were drained and the levee system expanded to keep the water out of new suburbs and industrial parks, hastening the drying that led to sinking, and making a bad situation even worse.
A computerized cross-section of the city's topography recently created by L.S.U. scientists and engineers shows a shallow bowl-like profile. On the southern edge along the river, the rim rises about five feet above sea level for most of the French Quarter, a half-mile-wide sloping plain created by the river's natural earthen banks. A flood wall built by the Army Corps of Engineers to hold back a cresting river -- which on normal days moves more than 300,000 cubic feet of water a second past the city at an average depth of 90 feet -- raised the levee to a uniform height of 25 feet above sea level, or 10 feet above the average annual high water surface level of the river, when water can rush by at the rate of one million cubic feet of water, or more, a second.
Most of the city north of the French Quarter was reclaimed from a boggy morass. The lowest sections -- residential areas and shops that sit on drained marshland at 5 to 10 feet below sea level -- form a wide band near the lake's southern shore.
New Orleans International Airport to the west and industrial complexes and residential areas to the east are at sea level or below it.
Spider webs of city canals and wide ditches that measure 185 miles in length feed 22 pumping stations that lift water to a height where it can flow into the lake, over levees built more than a half-century ago that stand 15 to 17 feet above sea level.
Water cascading over the levee wall or flooding from swollen marshes at the lake's eastern and western ends is just one part of the nightmare, the experts say. Draining the city after the storm moves away may take weeks, they point out. The city would be trapped inside the levees, steeped in a worsening "witches' brew" of pollutants like sewage, landfill waste, chemicals and the bodies of drowned humans and animals.
Bourbon Street could remain under 10 feet of water, with water swirling above two-story houses in neighborhoods closer to the lake.
Dr. Ivor van Heerden, deputy director of the L.S.U. Hurricane Center, said that in a worst-case situation with incomplete evacuation "we could have up to 45,000 killed and 400,000 trapped on roofs, with 700,000 evacuees who would now be homeless." 
Dr. van Heerden said it would take at least nine weeks to pump the city dry.
Pumping stations, which sometimes fail in heavy seasonal downpours in a city that receives nearly five feet of rain a year, would be inoperative under those conditions for days if not weeks, Dr. van Heerden said. The chemical stew that would be pumped into the lake and surrounding marshes would be an environmental disaster by itself, he added. He said that the cost in human misery might be incalculable but that the bills for insured damages, public works repairs and replacements and the economic effects might total $50 billion.
Despite the specter of such losses, it has been difficult to find enough money to build up the protective marshlands, said Jack C. Caldwell, head of the state's Natural Resources Department. Washington has been disinclined to earmark billions to protect the marshland and has resisted appeals from Baton Rouge to share revenues from offshore oil production with the state for that purpose, Mr. Caldwell said. 
In the meantime, residents take their chances every hurricane season, which starts on June 1. According to his computer models, Dr. Suhayda said, the odds that the city will be hit by a cataclysmic storm in any given year are less than 1 in 100. 
The American Red Cross is taking the threat seriously. It has declared it no longer will provide hurricane shelters in the New Orleans area, saying that placing staff there in a killer storm will represent too much risk for its employees, volunteers and the general public.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 6, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about flood control in New Orleans referred imprecisely to the reliability of the city's pumping stations. While they sometimes fail to keep up with the rain in very heavy downpours, the pumps themselves rarely stop working.

HEADLINE: NASA to View Interaction of Earth's Water and Climate 

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29 

 BODY:
Viewed from space, some of the earth's most pronounced features are the blue of the vast oceans, the white swirls of moisture-laden clouds and bright swaths of ice covering the poles. Much of what the planet is stems from its water, and NASA is about to launch a satellite to study the many ways that water affects the climate and how that relationship may be changing.
 The Aqua satellite is a large spacecraft with sensors designed to follow the cycle of the earth's water in its many forms to determine whether it is being affected by climate change. Six types of instruments aboard Aqua are to scan through the atmosphere down to the surface, gathering the most detailed data ever on water vapor in clouds, ice crystals in the air, evaporation, water in the oceans, icebergs and other sea ice, as well as glaciers and snow pack on land. 
 Scientists said the $952 million program, planned to last six years, should also help in understanding biological systems dependent upon water, like plankton in oceans and vegetation on land. In addition, they said, the data should help improve long-term weather and climate forecasting, and should help in understanding the workings of severe storms. For example, temperature changes on sea surfaces can signal widespread weather shifts like El Nino. 
"The Aqua satellite will tell us about water in all of its forms," said Dr. Claire Parkinson, a sea ice expert and Aqua project scientist at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., which is in charge of the program. "This comprehensive approach enables scientists to study the interactions among key elements of the earth system so as to better understand our planet."
Seventy percent of the earth is covered with water, but only a tiny amount occurs in the atmosphere as vapor or ice crystals. Yet atmospheric water is one of the most important greenhouse gases controlling the radiation and heat balance of the earth, Dr. Parkinson said. Because it is so little understood, its impact on global warming is hard to gauge.
Another unknown is how global warming may be affecting the cycle of water from sea to sky to earth, with some scientists suspecting that this hydrologic cycle may be speeding up.
Different forms of water greatly influence the amount of heat absorbed, retained and reflected away from the earth, scientists say. Clouds containing tiny particles of water and solids like ash and sea salt influence weather patterns by absorbing or scattering solar energy, or reflecting some of it back into space. Sea ice can reflect solar energy to reduce surface warming or insulate water against heat loss.
Snow cover can keep heat from escaping from the land, allowing the formation of cold air masses and limiting frost's penetration into the ground. Variations in sea temperatures can reflect shifts in heat exchanges between the ocean and the atmosphere.
Aqua carries some instruments identical to those on a sister satellite, Terra, and is to provide data that will be cross-referenced with information it is gathering. Launched in 1999, Terra carries instruments that concentrate on landmass studies, monitoring vegetation and the spread of deserts, among other things. The third major satellite in this system, a craft called Aura that will focus on atmospheric studies, is to be launched in 2004. (The three satellites carry Latin names that correspond to their missions: Aqua for water, Terra for land and Aura for heaven.)
Dr. Ghassem R. Asrar, NASA's associate administrator for earth science, said Aqua's data, combined with information gathered by the other satellites that are part of the agency's Earth Observing System, would help resolve scientific conflicts about global warming and how much of it could be attributed to human activity. The comprehensive, uniform information provided by this system will give policy makers more confidence in making decisions about influencing global warming that can have worldwide economic impact, he said.
Dr. Parkinson, the Aqua project scientist, says some of the uncertainties about global warming and climate change arise from conflicting data gathered by different instruments at different times in different parts of the world. "Satellites are the best way to get a good global view," she said. 
Aqua is to be launched on Saturday from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California aboard a Boeing Delta II rocket. The spacecraft, weighing 6,468 pounds at launching, is to be placed in a low polar orbit 428 miles high that has it circling the earth top to bottom every 99 minutes. Flying in this orbit, Aqua will take readings of every part of the globe every 16 days, building a comprehensive database that allows scientists to assess changes and drastically improving computer models for long-term forecasting.
In space, the big satellite, built by TRW Inc., will deploy antennas and booms to measure 16 feet by 26 feet, with solar power panels unfurling to stretch 55 feet across.
Aqua's suite of instruments include devices that will measure cloud properties, the wetness of land surfaces, land and sea temperatures, humidity and temperature at different levels of the atmosphere, the properties of particles in the air, fluctuations in solar energy absorption and many other parameters.
Two instruments are provided by other countries. The National Space Development Agency of Japan contributed a microwave scanning radiometer to measure water vapor content and precipitation rates, and Brazil's space agency provided a device to measure atmospheric humidity.
While Aqua's measurements are geared toward understanding long-term problems like global climate change, the satellite is also likely to have an immediate effect on everyone.
The spacecraft's Atmospheric Infrared Sounder, an instrument that measures infrared heat radiation as it leaves the atmosphere, is expected to provide vastly more and better temperature and humidity readings worldwide than are available now from weather satellites and other sources. These readings in 2,378 infrared wavelengths, compared with 24 from most other satellites, will give forecasters greater quantities of more accurate data to put into their computer models.
Dr. Asrar said five major forecasting groups around the world, including the United States' National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and its National Weather Service, have arranged to get the Aqua data to see if it improves weather forecasts. To meet this need, he said, NASA has arranged to process this data and make it available to forecasters within two hours after it is received.
Scientists said the data could greatly improve the accuracy of three-day to five-day forecasts of temperature, precipitation and humidity, perhaps making the three-day forecast as accurate as today's 24-hour one.

GRAPHIC: Photo: NASA will begin a six-year, $952 million study of the earth's water with the launching of the Aqua satellite. (TRW Inc.)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In a major switch, Hyundai Motor America dismisses Bates and signs with Richards.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN a startling switch, Hyundai Motor America said yesterday that it would dismiss the only agency the company had worked with since starting to sell cars in the United States 16 years ago. The agency, Bates, which had recently helped Hyundai significantly increase its sales as well as burnish its image, is being replaced by a shop that had strived time and again for a prestigious automotive account but fallen short -- until now.
 Hyundai, part of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea, ended a closely watched three-month review by naming the Richards Group in Dallas to handle its national creative account, with billings estimated at $160 million, effective May 1. Richards, which had missed being selected in half a dozen automotive reviews in the last decade, for brands including the BMW Mini, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche (twice) and Volkswagen, will take over those Hyundai duties from the Irvine, Calif., office of Bates USA West, part of the Bates Worldwide division of the Cordiant Communications Group. 
 The abrupt change, which comes as Cordiant is struggling to recover from a disastrous business performance in 2001, is further evidence -- as if anxious agency executives needed any additional proof -- of how volatile relationships can be with clients during tough economic times, particularly in battleground marketing categories like automobiles, soft drinks and fast food. 
Bates is being dismissed even though Hyundai sales are 205 percent higher than five years ago and the company outscored its chief Japanese rivals -- Honda, Nissan and Toyota -- in the annual customer satisfaction ratings released last week by AutoPacific, an influential automotive consultant. Trade publications had reported that executives at the Hyundai parent in South Korea pressed for the review because they wanted fresh thinking on the creative tasks as competition intensifies.
"Our goal mid- to long term is to take Hyundai to a 'Tier 1' brand, one of the top companies not only in the United States but worldwide," Dave Weber, vice president for marketing at Hyundai Motor in Fountain Valley, Calif., said in a telephone interview.
"While the work Bates has done is very strong," he added, "we thought this was a good opportunity to look around and make sure what we're getting was as strong as it could be."
Richards was selected, Mr. Weber said, for reasons that included "a great strategic platform, a depth and breadth of creative capabilities and the people chemistry, which was really good."
Dismissing Bates, which had worked for Hyundai in the United States since 1986, "was not the most enjoyable thing I've done," Mr. Weber said. "But the consensus of the group of five people on the selection committee," which included a Hyundai dealer, Tom O'Brien of Quincy, Mass., along with Mr. Weber and three other Hyundai Motor America executives, "was that Richards had the best programs for us," he added.
As for the risks attached to leaving an agency with 16 years of automotive experience for one that had been a perennial bridesmaid in car reviews, Mr. Weber said he would prefer to use the word "opportunity" rather than the word "gamble," adding that Hyundai was impressed by "case studies showing how Richards builds strong brands for other companies" like Chick-Fil-A, Home Depot, 7-Eleven and Nokia.
Other clients of Richards, which had billings estimated at $560 million before landing Hyundai, include Motel 6 and two driving-related newcomers, the Pep Boys vehicle-repair chain and GO RVing, a group representing marketers in the recreational vehicle industry.
Richards will begin working on campaigns for the cars Hyundai will sell for the 2003 model year, to be introduced in the fourth quarter. The campaigns for the 2002 model year, which carry a theme Bates created, "Driving is believing," are completed, Mr. Weber said.
The decision is a bitter blow for Bates, not only because Hyundai was its second-largest client, behind only British American Tobacco, but because the agency can ill afford to lose such a high-profile account as its parent, Cordiant, seeks to regain its footing after a sharp decrease in revenue and renegotiating debt agreements with its banks.
Asked why the agency was being dismissed, Bill Whitehead, chief executive for the Americas at Bates in New York, replied: "You've got me. Sales are up 205 percent in five years, intentions to purchase Hyundai are up 770 percent, awareness of the brand is up 29 percent and opinions are up 68 percent."
"With those kinds of results, which are spectacular in the industry, you've got to ask why," Mr. Whitehead said, but "at the end of the day we wish Hyundai and the dealers' group well."
The Irvine office has about 80 employees, Mr. Whitehead said, and an additional 30 work for Hyundai in field offices nationwide.
"We're certainly going to have to take a look at the office out there and the opportunities," he added. "We'd sure like to take those resources and find a car business that would like for us to do the same for them as we did for Hyundai."
At Richards, which is one of the few remaining large privately held agencies, the thoughts are of expansion as the staff of 520 is to grow by about 10 percent and an office is to be opened in Los Angeles.
"We waited a long time for this, and we are absolutely delighted," said Stan Richards, principal.
"We had a stairwell meeting this afternoon with the entire staff and there was jubilation," he added, laughing. "Productivity has fallen to zero."
When Richards was passed over by Mercedes-Benz of North America in 1992, Mr. Richards said, "I don't think we as an agency were ready" to tackle a major national automotive account, but when the agency fell short in the Volkswagen review three years later, "I think we were ready and were terribly disappointed."
This time around, "we're that much further along as an agency," he added, "and we felt we had a great deal to bring to the table."
Richards did not lay off employees last year during the industry downturn, preferring "to take a dramatically reduced level of profitability," Mr. Richards said, "to keep our strongest players" if possible. That strategy paid off yesterday, big time.
Bates had previously lost two other parts of the Hyundai assignment. In January, the media planning and buying duties were consolidated at Carat North America in New York, part of the Carat division of the Aegis Group, along with the media services for a Hyundai sibling, Kia Motors America. Last week, the assignment to handle collateral work for Hyundai like creating brochures was shifted to Hamon Associates in Los Angeles. The finalists in the creative review were Richards, Bates and two agencies owned by the Publicis Groupe, Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, which recently lost its longtime automotive account, the Saturn division of General Motors, and Publicis in the West in Seattle.
The review began in late January with 20 to 25 agencies expressing interest, then was narrowed to 10 semifinalists in February and 5 finalists in early March. One dropped out, leaving the four from which the decision was made yesterday. Select Resources International in West Hollywood, Calif., helped manage the review for Hyundai.

HEADLINE: Income and Spending Growth Ease, Hinting at Slow Revival 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29 

 BODY:
Personal income and spending grew in March at the slowest rates in three months, the Commerce Department reported today, suggesting that the economy began to cool somewhat entering the second quarter.
 The 0.4 percent gain in income came after a 0.6 percent increase in February, the report said. Spending also rose 0.4 percent after a 0.6 percent gain, as purchases of durable goods, like appliances, as well as those of services and nondurable goods slowed. The rises matched forecasters' expectations. 
 "Consumers should be a stabilizer for the economy for the balance of this year, but they will not provide a big boost," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo in Minneapolis. Mr. Sohn had expected 0.5 percent gains for income and spending last month.
The rise in spending was the smallest since a 0.1 percent increase in December.
At the same time, the report showed that businesses are keeping prices in check in an effort to maintain sales. The personal consumption price index, excluding food and energy, rose 0.1 percent for the third consecutive month.
Consumer spending grew at a 3.5 percent rate in the first quarter, as the economy expanded at a 5.8 percent pace. First-quarter spending was slower than the 6.1 percent rate in the final three months of 2001.
Disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased 0.5 percent in March after rising 0.7 percent a month earlier. Wages and salaries rose 0.2 percent in March, half the increase in February.
The personal savings rate rose last month to 2.2 percent, the highest since 4.7 percent in September 2001 and up from 2.1 percent in February. The savings rate weighs current income from wages, salaries, businesses and government payments against spending.
It does not account for borrowed money, income from investments, or withdrawals from any previous savings.
